### Tools - Check Lid

Topic included in MM and UP for Conv. Kit Openings

Equipment Status

Program Step step zero

Special Equipment

Calibrated micrometre 0 mm to 1.00 mm  
Opening force tester, TP No. 2768297-0100

Checking the lid thickness and opening force gives a good indication of the condition of the lid forming unit (**LFU**).

If the opening values are within limits according to specified values in the **OM-PC**, no further setting is necessary.

The lid thickness gives a good picture of the condition of the tools knife edge.

*   Thick, tight lids with a low opening force indicate good condition.
    
*   Thin lids with a high opening force indicate bad condition or settings. See [LFU - Troubleshooting](#section724).
    

#### Opening Force

1.  Pick eight consecutive packages from each side.
    
2.  Perform an opening test with the opening tester. Follow the instructions in the OM-PC.
    
    To identify from which mandrel/tool the lids come from, look for the mark inside the lids. For more information about tool identification, see the OM-PC.
    
3.  Note the tool number on the lid.
    

#### Lid Thickness

1.  Use the same packages used for the opening force test.
    
2.  Measure the lid thickness according to instructions in the OM-PC.
    
3.  If problems occur, check the lid thickness on the membrane and on the top, as near the top sleeve overlap as possible. Check on the LS side and on the opposite side.
    

#### Check Neck Thickness

**Valid for:** A38 Cap

1.  To be able to perform a neck thickness test, the following equipment is needed:
    
    *   a thickness gauge
        
    *   a knife
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001197499.png)

2.  Copy the test form [Test Form for Neck Thickness](#section933).
    
3.  Fill in the general information.
    
4.  Collect packages after the packaging machine or after the Capper 60 (remove the cap from the package).
    
5.  Remove the membrane. Use a knife to pierce at the recess. Carefully tear off the membrane.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002262506.png)

6.  Write down the inner tool number. For more information, see the OM-PC.
    
7.  Mark the measuring positions according to the illustration.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002262505.png)

LS side

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002288235.png)

Front side

8.  Cut the top in half, along the line between the front tool and the rear tool.
    
9.  Cut off the dome (see the following illustration).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002262503.png)

10.  Measure the thickness of the neck at the six marked positions, in the shaded area.
    
    Opening
    
    Minimum Thickness (mm)
    
    Maximum Thickness (mm)
    
    MiniV Nallo A38
    
    0.65
    
    0.8
    
    Mini Taishan A38
    
    0.65
    
    0.8
    
    Midi Idum A38
    
    0.65
    
    0.8
    
11.  If any of the measured values are out of range, set the centre of the external tools and measure the thickness again. See Procedure [External Tools - Set Centre of Tools](#section872).

Cooling Water System LFU
------------------------

### Description

The internal cooling water system is only used for the **LFU** and cools the hot channels, the injection cylinders, and the transfer unit. The system uses city water together with propylene glycol.

### Cooling Water System LFU (Glycol Circuit)

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002876826.png)

**Valid for Hot Channel Pistons Without Cooling**

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002876825.png)

**Valid for Hot Channel Pistons With Cooling**

### Cooling Water System - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step step zero

1.  Check for leakage and wear in the water installation (1).
    
2.  Check all the water connections (2):
    
    *   Leakage from the swivel. See arrow in the illustration.
        
    *   Pull the water hoses (3) outwards.
        
        **Note:** The water hoses must not come loose.
        
        If a water hose comes loose, cut off a little bit of the end, and put the hose back.
        

3.  Risk of fire.
    
    Make sure that no packaging materials or hoses touch these hot surfaces.
    
    There are several hot surfaces on the LFU that can cause fires.
    
    Check the hoses and make sure that they do not touch any of the hot surfaces. Make sure that all the hoses are installed and routed in a similar way to how they were when the LFU was delivered. Take the movement of the mechanism into consideration.
    
4.  Remove any packaging material in and around the LFU.
    
5.  Check that the brackets and holders for the water installation are tightened, and not causing any unnecessary wear.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002645033.png)

Lubrication System LFU
----------------------

### Description

The lubrication system distributes lubricating oil to all machine parts lubricated by the central lubrication system of the machine.

### Lubricating System - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  Check that all [Oil hose](#OilHoseoilHoses-0FB0A0A0) are filled with oil, and not are damaged.
    
2.  Check all hose connections.
    
3.  Check for oil leaks and excessive lubrication.
    
4.  Risk of fire.
    
    Make sure that no packaging materials or hoses touch these hot surfaces. Take the movement of the mechanism into consideration.
    
    There are several hot surfaces on the LFU that can cause fires.
    
    Check the hoses and make sure that they do not touch any of the hot surfaces. Make sure that all the hoses are installed and routed in a similar way to how they were when the LFU was delivered. Take the movement of the mechanism into consideration.
    
5.  Remove any packaging material in and around the LFU.

### Pipe Work Hydraulic - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step

**Description**

This check is made to prevent hydraulic oil leakage and risk for product contamination.

**Check**

Risk of personal injuries

Make sure that the oil pressure is zero before checking the hoses for oil leakages.

Pin hole leakages may penetrate your skin.

Keep the area clean from oil for easier detection of leakages.

Leaking hoses shall be changed. Even a small leakage is enough for corrective action.

1.  Check the [Pipe](#Pipepipe-0FB163F4) for leakages.
    
2.  Check that the [Bracket](#Bracketbrackets-0FB163F4) are firmly fastened.

*   Pipe
*   Bracket

3.  Check the [Hydraulic hose](#HydraulicHosehydraulicHoses-0FB163F4) for wear or other signs of fatigue.
    
    **Note:** Pay extra attention where the hoses may touch each other or other parts of the machine.
    
    **Note:** Pay extra attention to hoses with large movements.
    
4.  Hot surfaces
    
    The hot channel and the extruder can be hot.
    
    Risk of burns.
    
    Risk of fire.
    
    Make sure that no packaging materials or hoses touch these hot surfaces.
    
    There are several hot surfaces on the LFU that can cause fires.
    
    Make sure that all the hoses are installed and routed in a similar way to how they were when the LFU was delivered. Take the movement of the mechanism into consideration.
    
    **Note:** Pay extra attention to hoses with large movements.
    
5.  Check the [Hydraulic hose](#HydraulicHosehydraulicHoses-0FB163F4) for pin-hole leakage by:
    
    *   checking the surroundings for oil residues.
        
    *   checking the [Hydraulic hose](#HydraulicHosehydraulicHoses-0FB163F4) close to the [Clamp](#Clampclamps-7998B517).
        
    *   checking all the hydraulic hoses close to the [Crimp shell](#CrimpShellcrimpShells-7998C290).
        
    *   checking all the hydraulic hoses where they change direction.
        
    
    **Note:** pay extra attention to hoses with large movements
    
6.  Check all the hydraulic hose connections for signs of leakages
    

7.  Remove any packaging material in and around the LFU.

### Accumulator Unit - Check Pressure

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  Make sure that the **LFU** is free from loose or blocking objects.
    
2.  Check and if necessary set the hydraulic pressure and the air pressure for the accumulator, see Procedures [Hydraulic Accumulator Pressure - Set](#section901)and [Pneumatic Pressures LFU - Set](#section917).
    
    Make sure that the non return valve is working properly, see Procedure [Pneumatic Pressures LFU - Set](#section917).

4.  Check, and if necessary, set the belt tension for the drive tool, see Procedure [Drive Tool - Set Belt Tension](#section843).
    
5.  Check, and if necessary, set the belt tension for the motor unit, see Procedure [Motor Unit - Set Belt Tension](#section850).
    
6.  Check the accumulator for leakage from the leakage detection hole, see Procedure [Valve Ramp Unit - Check](#section893). Any air or oil leakage indicates that the sealings are worn out. If necessary, replace the accumulator according to Procedure [Accumulator Unit - Change](#section906).
    
7.  Change the directional valve, see Procedure [Directional Valve - Change](#section908).
    
8.  Bleed the system, see Procedure [Hydraulic System LFU - Bleed](#section911).
    
9.  Check the cylinder, see Procedure [Vertical Cylinder - Check](#section896).

8.  Assemble the new check-valve. Do not use the O-ring. Tighten to a torque of 3Nm.
    
9.  Assemble in the reverse order.
    
10.  Set the air pressure. See Procedure [Pneumatic Pressures LFU - Set](#section917) on page [Pneumatic Pressures LFU - Set](#section917).
    
11.  Check the recharge pressure. See Procedure [Hydraulic Accumulator Pressure - Set](#section901) on page [Hydraulic Accumulator Pressure - Set](#section901).

Equipment Status

Program Step

Special Equipment

**Handle Remote Control**

Instruction regarding handle of the remote control and recharging accumulator, see Procedure [LFU Remote Control - Handle](#section748).

Risk of crushing and cutting.

Enclose the area around the **LFU** and make sure that no unauthorized personnel can come in contact with the **LFU**.

The movement in the **LFU** can cause injuries.

Hot surfaces

The hot channel and the extruder can be hot.

Risk of burn.

Oil under pressure

Use protective goggles when working near and around the **LFU** unit. Also check the condition of the hydraulic hoses and connections before setting the machine into service mode. If necessary, change the hoses. See Procedure [Hydraulic System LFU - Change Hydraulic Hoses](#section907) on page [Hydraulic System LFU - Change Hydraulic Hoses](#section907).

Risk of eye injury.

1.  Connect a [Pressure gauge](#PressureGaugepressureGauge-EC070BF7) which can take 0 to 2.5 MPa (0 to 25 Bar) to the [Test connection](#TestConnectiontestConnection-EC072704).
    
2.  Activate step 1 (Hydraulic high Pressure) with the remote control.
    
3.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    Make sure that the mandrels are in a position where they cannot collide with the raising external tools.
    
    If the mandrels are positioned in the wrong direction when the recharging accumulator valve (2) is activated, the mandrels and the external tools can collide.
    
    Activate step 2 (Locking scissors) and close tools with the [](#ValveRechargingAccumulatorS1A30K122-F7620E97)[Valve, recharging accumulator (S1/A30K1223, S2/A30K2223)](#ValveRechargingAccumulatorS1A30K122-EC071A58) and check the pressure on the pressure gauge.
    
4.  If necessary, adjust hydraulic pressure with [Reduction valve](#ReductionValvereductionValve-EC072E6D) to **1.3 ±0.02 MPa (13 ±0.2 bar)**
    
    **Note:** During adjusting, hold the [](#ValveRechargingAccumulatorS1A30K122-F7620E97)[Valve, recharging accumulator (S1/A30K1223, S2/A30K2223)](#ValveRechargingAccumulatorS1A30K122-EC071A58) pressed.
    
    **Note:** The pressure should be maintained during every cycle. If the pressure is not received, the accumulator check-valve can be broken. See procedure on page .

### Hydraulic System LFU - Bleed

Equipment Status

Program Step HEATING

Special Equipment

Heat-resistant protective gloves TP No. 90303-0012  
Protective goggle TP No. 90303-0011  
A transparent bottle with cap and hose

Risk of crushing and cutting.

Be careful when working near the moving parts. It is recommended to use trained personnel when working with the **LFU** unit in service position.

The machine contains moving parts that can crush.

Hot surfaces

The hot channel and the extruder can be hot.

Risk of burn.

Oil under pressure

Use protective goggles when working near and around the **LFU** unit. Also check the condition of the hydraulic hoses and connections before setting the machine into service mode. If necessary, change the hoses. See Procedure on page [Hydraulic System LFU - Change Hydraulic Hoses](#section907).

Risk of eye injury.

#### Reference Cylinders

1.  Open the doors for the **LFU**.
    
2.  Start up the hydraulic unit with **low pressure**. See Procedure [LFU Remote Control - Handle](#section748).
    
3.  Apply a suitable [Hose](#Hosehose-C73F7AF9) through the [Cap](#Capcap-C73F7AF9) on a [Transparent Bottle](#TransparentBottletransparentBottle-C73F7AFB).
    
    **Note:** The hose must fit the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB).
    
4.  Fit the [Hose](#Hosehose-C73F7AF9) on the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB) and open the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB).
    
5.  Make sure to completely empty the [Reference Cylinder](#ReferenceCylinderreferenceCylinder-C73F7AFB) from air, by activating and deactivating the [Reference Cylinder Valve](#ReferenceCylinderValvereferenceCyli-C73F7AFB) manually on the hydraulic block, a couple of times.
    
6.  Check the evacuating oil and make sure that it is free from air.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0003129502.png)

*   Hose
*   Cap

*   Transparent Bottle
*   Ventilating Nipples

*   Reference Cylinder
*   Reference Cylinder Valve

*   Bleed button
*   Window “Service Functions”

7.  When the oil is free from air, tighten the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB).
    
8.  Push the [Bleed button](#BleedButtonBleedButton-C73F7AFB) on the **LFU** [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window, and open the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB) to check for air in the oil.
    
    **Note:** When bleed is pushed the machine will apply low hydraulic pressure on the following parts: [Horizontal Cylinders](#HorizontalCylindershorizontalCylind-C533CF64), the [Reference Cylinder](#ReferenceCylinderreferenceCylinder-C73F7AFB), and the [Injection Cylinders](#InjectionCylindersinjectionCylinder-C53404F8).
    
9.  Check the evacuating oil and make sure that it is free from air
    
10.  When the oil is free from air, tighten the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C73F7AFB).
    
11.  Deactivate the bleeding function by pushing the [Bleed button](#BleedButtonBleedButton-C73F7AFB) on the [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window.
    
12.  Leave the [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window by deactivating the service key.
    
    **Note:** Repeat steps to with some runtime in between (6-20h), until the oil is completely free from air. This due to that the [Reference Cylinder](#ReferenceCylinderreferenceCylinder-C73F7AFB) is the highest point in the hydraulic system.
    
    **Note:** If bleedings are required frequently, the reason can be air leakage through an invisible hole in the cylinder hydraulic hose. Check or change the affected hydraulic hose and perform a new bleeding.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0003129502.png)

*   Hose
*   Cap

*   Transparent Bottle
*   Ventilating Nipples

*   Reference Cylinder
*   Reference Cylinder Valve

*   Bleed button
*   Window “Service Functions”

#### Injection and Horizontal Cylinders

1.  Open the doors for the **LFU**.
    
2.  Start up the hydraulic unit with **low pressure**. See Procedure [LFU Remote Control - Handle](#section748).
    
3.  Push the [Bleed button](#BleedButtonBleedButton-C73F7AFB) on the **LFU** [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window.
    
    The machine will now apply low hydraulic pressure on the following parts:
    
    *   [Horizontal Cylinders](#HorizontalCylindershorizontalCylind-C533CF64). See illustration on next page.
        
    *   [Reference Cylinder](#ReferenceCylinderreferenceCylinder-C73F7AFB). See Illustration on previous page.
        
        **Note:** On previous versions of the [Reference Cylinder](#ReferenceCylinderreferenceCylinder-C73F7AFB), there are no ventilating nipples.
        
    *   [Injection Cylinders](#InjectionCylindersinjectionCylinder-C53404F8). See illustration on next page.
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0003129500.png)

*   Bleed button
*   Window “Service Functions”

4.  Apply a suitable [Hose](#Hosehose-C73F7AF9) through the [Cap](#Capcap-C73F7AF9) on a [Transparent Bottle](#TransparentBottletransparentBottle-C73F7AFB).
    
    **Note:** The hose must fit the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533C644) and the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533F2D2).
    
5.  Fit the [Hose](#Hosehose-C73F7AF9) on the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533C644) on the [Horizontal Cylinders](#HorizontalCylindershorizontalCylind-C533CF64), or the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533F2D2) on the [Injection Cylinders](#InjectionCylindersinjectionCylinder-C53404F8), depending on which cylinder that needs to be bled.
    
6.  Check the evacuating oil and make sure that it is free from air.
    
7.  When the oil is free from air, tighten the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533C644), or the [Ventilating Nipples](#VentilatingNipplesventilatingNipple-C533F2D2).
    
8.  Deactivate the bleeding function by pushing the [Bleed button](#BleedButtonBleedButton-C73F7AFB) on the [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window.
    
9.  Leave the [Window “Service Functions”](#WindowServiceFunctionsServiceFuncti-C73F7AFB) window by deactivating the service key.
    
    **Note:** If bleedings are required frequently, the reason can be air leakage through an invisible hole in the cylinder hydraulic hose. Check or change the affected hydraulic hose and perform a new bleeding.

4.  Remove the [O-ring](#O-ringo-ring-5E419AE5) and the [Support ring](#SupportRingsupportRing-5E41A6C4).
    
5.  Lubricate the threads, the [O-ring](#O-ringo-ring-5E419AE5) and the [Support ring](#SupportRingsupportRing-5E41A6C4) with hydraulic oil.
    
6.  Fit the new [O-ring](#O-ringo-ring-5E419AE5) and the new [Support ring](#SupportRingsupportRing-5E41A6C4) for [Check Valve](#Valvevalve-5E416B35) according to illustration A.
    
7.  Fit the new [O-ring](#O-ringo-ring-5E419AE5) and the new [Support ring](#SupportRingsupportRing-5E41A6C4) for the [Reducer 90459-2733](#Valvevalve-6039A2D8), and the [Reducer 90459-2740](#Valvevalve-6039A304) according to illustration B.

Functional Description
----------------------

### Hygiene Risk

Hygiene risk.

Do not touch the screw caps.

The screw caps can become contaminated.

Make sure that you do not contaminate the caps, the CAU or the CSU at any time. Always wash and disinfect your hands and gloves before touching parts that must be hygienic.

### Integration in the TT/3

The [CAU -Screw Cap Application Unit](#CAU-ScrewCapApplicationUnitscrewCap-EC915E65) is integrated between the [LFU - Lid Forming Unit](#LFU-LidFormingUnitlidFormingUnit-EC916662), and the [Package Section](#PackageSectionpackageSection-EC916AE0).

### Package Changes

The lid of the package has no [Membrane](#Membranemembrane-EC91963A). The [Screw cap](#ScrewCapscrewCap-EC91A460) is the sealing on the top of the package.

The [Screw cap](#ScrewCapscrewCap-EC91A460) is equipped with a [Tamper ring](#TamperRingtamperRing-EC91A9AA), for tamper evidence.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205600.png)

### Overview CAU

The [Screw Cap Application Unit (CAU)](#ScrewCapApplicationUnitCAUscrewCapA-EC91F0DF) contains a [Machine Body](#MachineBodymachineBody-EC91FAF4), a [Pneumatic Panel](#PneumaticPanelpneumaticPanel-EC91FFEA), [Transfer Unit](#TransferUnittransferUnits-EC920463), [Screw Cap Handling](#ScrewCapHandlingscrewCapHandling-EC920AC6), [Screw Cap Applicator unit](#ScrewCapApplicatorUnitscrewCapAppli-EC921068), [Doors and Covers](#DoorsAndCoversdoorsAndCovers-EC921606), and [Duct](#Ductducts-EC921A8C).

It also includes a [Screw Cap Supply Unit (CSU)](#ScrewCapSupplyUnitCSUscrewCapSupply-EC92207D) and a [Vision Unit](#VisionUnitvisionUnit-EC92262B), that is located external from the main machine.

### Duct and Sprue Box

When the lid is manufactured with inlet moulding, there is a leftover called [Sprue](#Spruesprue-EC927CEB). The [Sprue](#Spruesprue-EC927CEB) is separated from the lid with the [Knife](#Knifeknife-EC929524).

The [Sprue](#Spruesprue-EC927CEB) falls through the [Duct](#Ductduct-EC92993B), down to the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501). The [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501) can be reached by opening the [Hatch](#Hatchhatch-EC929D72).

The [Hatch](#Hatchhatch-EC929D72) can be opened during PRODUCTION in order to empty the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501). The [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501) needs to be emptied every third production hour.

When 11 000 packages have been produced according to the count on the **TPOP**, a blue alarm occurs. Empty the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501) and reset the blue alarm. If this is not done a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** when the photocell for the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-EC928501) is activated. When the blue alarm has been active for 3 seconds the machine will step down to tankfilling on the affected machine side.

*   Sprue

*   Sprue box

### Transfer Unit

The packages are transferred into the [Magazine](#Magazinemagazine-EC9362B7), by the **LFU** -stripper. The packages will then be rotated one revolution in the [Magazine](#Magazinemagazine-EC9362B7). This is done to cool down the lid before fitting the screw cap.

After one revolution the [CAU stripper](#CAUStripperCAUStripper-EC9371A2) will move the packages into the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9378FB). The [CAU stripper](#CAUStripperCAUStripper-EC9371A2) is driven by the [Drive unit](#DriveUnitdriveUnit-EC936C38).

If there are packages in the capping station in this moment, they will be moved to the [Cassette](#Cassettecassettes-EC937DB9) in the package section by the **CAU** stripper in the same stroke.

**Note:** It is possible to open the upper forming pipes in the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9378FB), to remove packages. See further instruction in the Operator Manual.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205598.png)

*   Magazine
*   Drive unit
*   CAU stripper

*   Cassette
*   Capping station

### Screw Cap Applicator Unit

The screw cap is assembled when the package is positioned in the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9829C3). It is the [Screw Cap applicator unit](#ScrewCapApplicatorUnitsScrewCapAppl-EC98340B) that applies the screw cap to the package.

While the [CAU stripper](#CAUStripperCAUStripper-EC9820AC) moves packages and places new packages in the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9829C3), the [Screw Cap applicator unit](#ScrewCapApplicatorUnitsScrewCapAppl-EC98340B) moves down and away (forward) from the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9829C3) to pick up new screw caps from the screw cap handling unit (the screw cap handling unit will be described later).

Then the [Screw Cap applicator unit](#ScrewCapApplicatorUnitsScrewCapAppl-EC98340B) moves up and toward (backward) the capping station, to position the screw caps in front of the packages in the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9829C3). Finally the [Screw Cap applicator unit](#ScrewCapApplicatorUnitsScrewCapAppl-EC98340B) starts to rotate the screw caps and the **CAU** stripper moves the packages toward the screw cap to assemble them. When the screw caps have been assembled, the cycle start over again.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000374899.png)

*   CAU stripper
*   Capping station
*   Screw Cap applicator unit

### Screw Cap Handling

The screw caps are blown up from the **CSU** to the [Cyclone](#Cyclonecyclone-EC986A33). From the [Cyclone](#Cyclonecyclone-EC986A33), the screw caps fall down into the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-EC9872A8). The [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-EC9872A8) turns all screw caps with the same side down to align them, then the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-EC9872A8) distributes the screw caps down the [Chute](#Chutechute-EC987B73).

The screw caps are transported down the [Chute](#Chutechute-EC987B73). Further down the chute they are divided between two chutes to supply both sides of the [Screw cap transfer](#ScrewCapTransferscrewCapTransfer-EC9880DF).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205596.png)

*   Cyclone
*   Screw cap sorter

*   Chute
*   Screw cap transfer

The [Loading piston](#LoadingPistonloadingPiston-1D7DB3C6) transfers the screw cap through the [Tube](#Tubetube-2CB744FF) into the [Screw Cap Holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolder-2CB748D3) in the screw cap applicator unit. The [Screw Cap Holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolder-2CB748D3) rotates the [Screw cap](#ScrewCapscrewCap-1D7DBFC5) to match the heels in the screw cap with the heels on the loading piston and registers the screw cap position. The loading piston moves back and the screw cap applicator unit lifts the screw cap and assembles it to the package as described earlier.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001362846.png)

*   Tube
*   Screw Cap Holder

*   Loading piston
*   Screw cap

### CSU

The [CSU](#CSUCSU-EC9AF1B0) feeds one TT/3 with screw caps. There are two sides in the **CSU**, **S1** and **S2** (see illustration). Each side contains a [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9AF677), and a [Fan](#FeedUnitfeedUnit-EC9AFCD5). One side of the **CSU** serves one production side on the **CAU** with screw caps.

The [Electrical cabinet](#ElectricalCabinetelectricalCabinet-EC9B07AB) serves both sides of the [CSU](#CSUCSU-EC9AF1B0).

One [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9AF677) has the capacity to hold 15 000 screw caps. A full [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9AF677) can be emptied in two minutes, using the emptying function.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205594.png)

*   CSU
*   Container

*   Fan
*   Electrical cabinet

The screw caps are stored in the [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9B1900). From the [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9B1900) they fall down on the [Conveyer](#Conveyerconveyer-EC9B2660). The [Vibrator](#Vibratorvibrator-EC9B2C56) shakes the container to keep the screw caps from becoming jammed at the bottom of the [Container](#Containercontainer-EC9B1900).

The [Conveyer](#Conveyerconveyer-EC9B2660) transports the screw caps until they fall down into the **HEPA** -filtered air stream that is driven by the [Fan](#Fanfan-EC9B345C). Then the screw caps are blown through the [Outlet](#Outletoutlet-EC9B2FE8), and through the pipe that leads to the screw cap sorter on top of the screw cap applicator unit in the TT/3.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205593.png)

*   Container
*   Conveyer
*   Vibrator

*   Fan
*   Outlet

To perform certain maintenance procedures or to change screw cap colour, it is necessary to empty the **CSU** from screw caps. An emptying function is built in for this purpose. The [Hatch](#Hatchhatch-EC9B4761) must be folded out according to the illustration. When the [Push button](#PushButtonpushButton-EC9B4A81) is pushed, the [Conveyer](#Conveyerconveyer-EC9B2660) will reverse. Then the screw caps will be transported out through the [Hatch](#Hatchhatch-EC9B4761). For further instructions about the emptying procedure, see the Operation Manual (**OM**).

When the level of screw caps is low in the **CSU**, a blue alarm occurs. When the **CAU** is emptied, the blue alarm will remain.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205612.png)

*   Conveyer
*   Hatch
*   Push button

### Vision Unit

The vision unit ejects packages when the screw cap is not properly attached. It is a pneumatic cylinder that ejects packages.

There is also a cylinder for volume change with two different positions depending on package height. The camera takes care of the fine adjustment automatically. For example, BASE 750 and BASE 1000 uses the same position of the volume change cylinder which the camera can handle, while for example BASE 500 and BASE 1000 use different positions for the volume change cylinder.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205611.png)

### 110307771/110307772, Magazine S1/S2, Sleeve Stuck

**Description**

The [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-EC9E304D) controls if there are any [Sleeve](#Packagepackages-C0A98CD9) in the [Magazine](#MagazineMagazine-C0A96F05). The [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-EC9E304D) reads across the upper pair of [Sleeve forming device](#SleeveFormingDevicesleeveFormingDev-EC9E3B8A), towards the [Reflector](#Reflectorreflector-EC9E432E), see illustration.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

The alarm will be set if there are sleeves present when there are not supposed to be any sleeves and vice versa. This is detected by the [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-EC9E304D) (G31B1227 for side1 and G31B2227 for side2).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205609.png)

*   Photocell
*   Sleeve
*   Magazine

*   Sleeve forming device
*   Reflector

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check the sleeve size according to specification in:
    
    [Sleeve Forming Unit (Sleeve Maker)](#section399)
    
*   Make sure that the prefolding is in correct position. If necessary, adjust according to:
    
    [Pre-Folder - Set](#section363)
    
*   Check the position of the guide stripper in:
    
    [Guide Stripper - Set Position](#section858)
    
*   Inspect the stripper fingers to make sure that they are straight and not damaged. If the **CAU**\-stripper is not set correctly, set according to:
    
    [CAU Stripper - Set](#section1044)
    
*   Check the photocell according to:
    
    [Frame - Set Sleeve Edge Photocell](#section1016)
    
    [Frame - Change Photocell](#section1017)
    
*   To achieve a correct home position for the linear unit, perform in sequence the following actions:
    
    [Drive Unit - Set Linear Unit](#section1034)
    
    [Drive Unit - Set Home Position](#section1035)
    

### 110307811/110307812, Magazine S1/S2, Servo Fault

**Description**

The [Motor](#MotorMotor-C0A8833D) rotates the [Magazine](#Magazinemagazine-C0A88B7D). If this alarm is set, it indicates that something is wrong with the position or movement of the [Magazine](#Magazinemagazine-C0A88B7D).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205608.png)

*   Motor
*   Magazine

**Conditions to set the alarm**

This alarm is a summary alarm and can be caused by a numerous of reasons, mechanically and electronically. The electronically reasons are the same for every servo axis in the machine. The alarms that are likely to be mechanically connected are the following.

*   `Position error fault`
    
*   `Motor overtemp fault`
    

`Position error fault` is set due to that something suddenly is disturbing the motion of the mechanics. This could be some kind of obstacle (a loose bolt etc), lack of lubrication, a stuck ball bearing.

`Motor overtemp fault` is similar to the above fault but here the disturbance is not that sudden. If the motor for some reason is forced to work harder it will become hot and the `Motor overtemp fault` will occur. The cause could be slowly degrading lubrication, wear of bearings and guides, or basically that the environment (i.e. cooling capacity) around the motor has changed.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Look for any obvious obstacles in the magazines movement. Try to rotate the mechanics manually to check that it moves smoothly.
    
*   Check that the motor, the gearbox and the rest of the mechanics are properly fixed (loose bolts etc).
    
*   Check that the electrical connections are properly connected, both to the motor and to the servo drive in the electrical cabinet. Also inspect the cables to make sure that they are not damaged.
    
*   If the magazines home position is out of place, set according to:
    
    [Magazine - Set Home Position](#section1029).
    

### 110307791/110307792, Capping Station S1/S2, Sleeve Stuck

**Description**

The [Fibre optics](#Photocellphotocell-EC9FB50C) checks if there are any [Sleeve](#Sleevesleeves-EC9FBBBF) in the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9FBF00). The [Fibre optics](#Photocellphotocell-EC9FB50C) reads across the [Capping station](#CappingStationcappingStation-EC9FBF00).

**Conditions to set the alarm**

The alarm will be set if there are sleeves present when there are not supposed to be any sleeves and vice versa. This is detected by the [Fibre optics](#Photocellphotocell-EC9FB50C) (G31B1228 for side 1 and G31B2228 for side 2).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000291772.png)

*   Fibre optics
*   Sleeve
*   Capping station

**Troubleshooting**

*   If the friction between the sleeves and the forming tube are to high, it will effect the function. Clean the forming tubes carefully with alcohol or similar.
    
*   Inspect the stripper fingers to make sure that they are straight and not damaged. If the CAU-stripper is not set correctly, set according to:
    
    [CAU Stripper - Set](#section1044)
    
*   Check the position of the stop plate according to:
    
    [Capping Station - Set Stop Plate](#section1048)
    
*   Check the function of the fibre optic according to:
    
    [Capping Station - Check Fibre Optic](#section1047)
    
    [Connection Box - Set Fibre Optic Amplifier](#section1022)
    
    [Capping Station - Change Fibre Optic](#section1051)
    
*   Make sure the upper halves of the capping station is properly fixed (loose bolts etc).
    
*   Check the sleeve size according to specification in:
    
    [Sleeve Forming Unit (Sleeve Maker)](#section399)
    

### 110307821/110307822, CAU Stripper, Servo Fault

**Description**

The [Motor](#Motormotor-EC9FD047) runs the [Linear unit](#LinearUnitlinearUnit-EC9FD2E2). If the alarm is set, it indicates that something is wrong with the movement of the [CAU stripper](#CAUStripperCAUStripper-EC9FD813).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205606.png)

*   Motor
*   Linear unit
*   CAU stripper

**Conditions to set the alarm**

This alarm is a summary alarm and can be caused by a numerous of reasons, mechanically and electronically. The electronically reasons are the same for every servo axis in the machine. The alarms that are likely to be mechanically connected are the following.

*   `Position error fault`
    
*   `Motor overtemp fault`
    

`Position error fault` is set due to that something suddenly is disturbing the motion of the mechanics. This could be some kind of obstacle (a loose bolt etc), lack of lubrication, a stuck ball bearing.

`Motor overtemp fault` is similar to the above fault but here the disturbance is not that sudden. If the motor for some reason is forced to work harder it will become hot and the `Motor overtemp fault` will occur. The cause could be wear of bearings and guides, or basically that the environment (i.e. cooling capacity) around the motor has changed.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Look for any obvious obstacles in the **CAU** stripper. Try to move the mechanics manually to check that it moves smoothly.
    
*   Check that the motor, the gearbox and the rest of the mechanics are properly fixed (loose bolts etc).
    
*   Set the parallelism of the **CAU** stripper according to:
    
    [CAU Stripper - Set](#section1044).
    
*   Check the setting of the drive unit according to:
    
    [Drive Unit - Set Linear Unit](#section1034).
    
*   Set the home position for the linear unit according to:
    
    [Drive Unit - Set Home Position](#section1035).
    
*   Check that the electrical connections are properly connected, both to the motor and to the servo drive in the electrical cabinet. Also inspect the cables to make sure that they are not damaged.

### 110307741/110707631/110307742/110707632, CSU S1/S1/S2/S2, Lid or Door Open

**Description**

*   `110307741 = Yellow alarm S1`
    
*   `110707631 = Blue alarm S1`
    
*   `110307742 = Yellow alarm S2`
    
*   `110707632 = Blue alarm S2`
    

**Conditions to set the alarm**

When a lid or a door is open a blue alarm will occur on the **TPOP**. If the lid or door remains open for more then 10 minutes a yellow alarm will occur and the machine will step down to HEATING.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure that both lids and both doors are properly closed
    
*   Set the inductive switches according to:
    
    [Frame - Set Inductive Switch](#section1134)
    
*   Change broken inductive switches according to:
    
    [Frame - Change Inductive Switch](#section1140)
    

### 110307751/110307752, CSU S1/S2, Fan Malfunction

**Description**

The [Motor](#Motormotor-ECA217DF) runs the [Fan](#Fanfan-ECA21A49).

**Conditions to set the alarm**

The alarm, which is a summary alarm, indicates that there is something wrong with the motor or the frequency converter.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205604.png)

*   Motor
*   Fan

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure that the fan can rotate freely.
    
*   Reset the overload protection for the motor.
    
*   Check electrical terminals for bad connections.
    

### 110307710, Overload protection tripped CSU

**Description**

In the **CSU** electrical cabinet there is a overload protection.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If this alarm occurs on the **TPOP** it indicates that something is wrong with the overload protection in the **CSU** electrical cabinet.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Reset the overload protection for the motor.
    
*   Make sure that there is power to the connections for the overload protection.
    
*   Check electrical terminals for bad connections.
    

### 110630050, CAU Emergency Stop

**Description**

The [CSU](#CSUCSU-ECA2BB88) unit is equipped with an [Emergency stop push-button](#EmergencyStopPush-buttonemergencySt-ECA2C408) that can be used to short stop the unit in case of emergency.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the [Emergency stop push-button](#EmergencyStopPush-buttonemergencySt-ECA2C408) is pushed, the alarm will occur on the **TPOP**.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Deactivate the [Emergency stop push-button](#EmergencyStopPush-buttonemergencySt-ECA2C408) and step up the machine again.
    
*   Check the safety circuit for bad connections.
    
*   Change the safety relay.

### 110307831/110307841/110307832/110307842, Capper Unit S1:1/S1:2/S2:1/S2:2, Servo Fault

**Description**

The [Servomotor](#ServoMotorservoMotors-ECA3E58C) runs the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolders-ECA3F379). An alarm on the **TPOP** regarding the [Servomotor](#ServoMotorservoMotors-ECA3E58C), indicates that something is wrong with the [Servomotor](#ServoMotorservoMotors-ECA3E58C).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205641.png)

*   Servomotor
*   Screw cap holder

**Conditions to set the alarm**

This alarm is a summary alarm and can be caused by a numerous of reasons, mechanically and electronically. The electronically reasons are the same for every servo axis in the machine.

If the motor for some reason is forced to work harder it will become hot and the motor overtemp fault will occur. The cause could be changes in tension of a transmission belt, slowly degrading lubrication, wear of bearings and guides, or basically that the environment (i.e. cooling capacity) around the motor has changed.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Try to rotate the mechanics manually to check that it moves smoothly. Check that the motor and the rest of the mechanics are properly fixed (loose bolts etc).
    
*   Check that the electrical connections are properly connected, both to the motor and to the servodrive in the electrical cabinet. Also inspect the cables to make sure that they are not damaged.
    
*   If the servomotor is broken, change according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Change Servomotor](#section1098).
    
*   Check the tension of the timing belt according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Set Timing Belt](#section1095).
    

### 110307721/110307722, Capper Unit S1/S2, Horizontal Cylinder Wrong Pos

**Description**

Before the screw cap is fitted in the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolder-ECA48838), the [Capper unit](#CapperUnitcapperUnit-ECA491FC) must be moved against the [Tube](#Tubetube-ECA48D3F).

When the screw cap has been attached to the package, the [Capper unit](#CapperUnitcapperUnit-ECA491FC) must be moved away from the package, before it is lowered.

The movement of the [Capper unit](#CapperUnitcapperUnit-ECA491FC), in horizontal direction, is performed by the [Cylinder](#Cylindercylinder-ECA4E198), and it is monitored by the [Proximity sensor](#ProximitySensorproximitySensor-ECA49C10) and [Proximity sensor](#ProximitySensorproximitySensor-ECA4A138).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205640.png)

*   Tube
*   Screw cap holder
*   Capper unit

*   Proximity sensor
*   Proximity sensor
*   Cylinder

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If it takes more then 350ms for the cylinder to reach fully retracted position, or more than 200ms to reach fully extended position, the alarm will occur on the TPOP. This is detected by sensor G31B1221 and G31B1222 (side 1) and G31B2221 and G31B2222 (side 2) respectively.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure there are no obstacles of any kind in the way of the capping cylinders movement. Manually move the capping cylinder back and forward to check that it moves smoothly.
    
*   If there is a play in the capping cylinder, it might indicate that the cylinder needs to be changed according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Change Cylinder](#section1100)
    
*   Set the movement of the capping cylinder by setting the pneumatic valves according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Lift - Set Pneumatic Valve](#section1111)
    
*   Make sure that the capper unit is correctly lined up according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Basic Set](#section1094)
    
*   Set the sensors on the capping cylinder, according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Set Sensor](#section1096)
    
*   If one or more of the sensors on the capping cylinder is broken, change according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Change Sensor](#section1101)
    

### 110307610, Output Module, Fuse Blown

**Description**

This is a summary alarm for all electronic fuses in the **CAU** DeviceNet nodes.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If a DeviceNet output module on the **CAU** is overloaded, this alarm will be set.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Switch OFF and ON the DeviceNet node.
    
*   Change DeviceNet module.
    
*   Tighten all unused connections.

**Description**

This is a alarm that indicates a failure in the **CAU** DeviceNet.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the DeviceNet communication fails or if two nodes has the same address or if the DeviceNet nodes are in incorrect order, this alarm will be set.

**Troubleshooting**

*   [DeviceNet](#section1837)
    

### 110307861/110307862 Sprue Stuck in Chute

**Description**

If sprues for some reason are getting stuck in the chute (that is, the bottom part of the chute is incorrectly mounted), the photocell (G31B1307/G31B2307) will detect if the chute is blocked.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the photocell is activated, a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** and the machine will be brought to a direct stop. This to avoid sprues from falling out of the chute.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Look for any obvious obstacles in the chute.
    
*   Check the photocell according to:
    
    [Duct - Set Photocell](#section1129)
    
    [Duct - Change Photocell](#section1130)
    
*   Check that the bottom part of the chute is correctly mounted according to the illustration.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205639.png)

### 110307681/110307682, Sprue Box S1/S2, High Level

**Description**

The excess plastic from the moulding of the package lid is called sprue. The sprue is cut off from the lid and collected in the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-ECA76A60). The [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-ECA774E7) (G31B1223 side 1 or G31B2223 side 2) detects if the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-ECA76A60) is full.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

When 11000 packages (default value, can differ according to **TPOP** setting) has been produced according to the count on the **TPOP**, a blue alarm will occur and an attention signal will sound. Empty the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-ECA76A60) and reset the blue alarm on the **TPOP**. Zero the count by pressing [Zero](#ZeroZero-ECA78239) on the **TPOP**. If this is not done a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** when the [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-ECA774E7) for the [Sprue box](#SprueBoxsprueBox-ECA76A60) is activated. When the yellow alarm has been active for 3 seconds the machine will step down to tankfilling on the affected machine side.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0003962676.png)

*   Sprue box
*   Photocell
*   Zero

*   Check the photocell according to:
    
    [Frame - Set Sprue Level Photocell](#section1015)
    
    [Frame - Change Photocell](#section1017)
    
*   Check electrical connections on I/O node.
    

### 110307851/110307852, Capper Unit S1/S2, Screw Cap Not Correctly Loaded

**Description**

The screw cap [Transfer cylinder](#TransferCylindertransferCylinder-ECA7BCCB) pushes new screw caps in to the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolders-ECA7C26F) for each capping cycle.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the [Transfer cylinder](#TransferCylindertransferCylinder-ECA7BCCB) has not reached fully extended position within a certain time, the alarm will occur on the **TPOP**. This is detected by [Sensor](#Sensorsensor-ECA7B983) (G31B1226 on side 1 or G31B2226 on side 2).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001392933.png)

*   Sensor
*   Transfer cylinder

*   Loading piston
*   Screw cap holder

**Troubleshooting**

*   A probable cause of this alarm is that two screw caps has been delivered to the capping position at the same time (double screw cap).
    
*   Make sure there are no obstacles of any kind in the way of the screw cap transfer unit. Manually move the transfer cylinder back and forward to check that it moves smoothly.
    

### 110307731/110307732, Capper Unit S1/S2, Screw Capping Failed

**Description**

The control system (**PLC**) monitors and evaluates different parameters (torque and rotational angel) during the capping process in order to determine that the screw cap has been successfully applied.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the machine fails to fulfil the above demands for four machine cycles in a row, a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** and the machine will step down the affected machine side.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check if a screw cap is stuck somewhere in the chute.
    
*   Set the capping position for the **CAU** -Stripper according to:
    
    [Drive Unit - Set Capping Position](#section1037).
    
*   Adjust the capping torque according to OM.
    
*   Check the function of the screw cap holder servomotors.
    
*   Check the belt tension according to:
    
    [Capper Unit - Set Timing Belt](#section1095)
    

### 110307801/110307802, Screw Cap Lift S1/S2, Servo Fault

**Description**

The [Motor](#Motormotor-ED096498) runs the [Compact module](#CompactModulecompactModule-ED0967D4), that the [Capper unit](#CapperUnitcapperUnit-ED096A81) is attached to. The alarm indicates that something is wrong regarding the vertical movement.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205636.png)

*   Motor
*   Compact module
*   Capper unit

**Conditions to set the alarm**

*   `Position error fault`
    
*   `Motor overtemp fault`
    

`Position error fault` is set due to that something suddenly is disturbing the motion of the mechanics. This could be some kind of obstacle (a loose bolt etc), lack of lubrication, a stuck ball bearing.

`Motor overtemp fault` is similar to the above fault but here the disturbance is not that sudden. If the motor for some reason is forced to work harder it will become hot and the `Motor overtemp fault` will occur. The cause could be changes in tension of a transmission belt, slowly degrading lubrication, wear of bearings and guides, or basically that the environment (i.e. cooling capacity) around the motor has changed.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Look for any obvious obstacles in the capper units movement.
    
*   Try to move the mechanics up and down manually to check if the compact module has a bad function.
    
*   Check that the motor, the gearbox and the rest of the mechanics are properly fixed (loose bolts etc).
    
*   Check that the electrical connections are properly connected, both to the motor and to the servo drive in the electrical cabinet. Also inspect the cables to make sure that they are not damaged.
    
*   Check that the guides are well lubricated. If necessary lubricate according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Lift - Lubricate Compact Module](#section1113)
    
*   Check the position of the loading pistons in the transfer unit and make sure they are moving without interfering with the screw cap holders.
    
*   Set the sensors according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Transfer - Set Sensor](#section1057)
    

### 110307661/110307662, Screw Cap Chute S1/S2, Low Level

**Description**

The [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-ED09C75E) on the [Chute](#Chutechute-ED09CB21) controls the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-ED09CE66).

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If no screw caps are delivered from the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-ED09CE66) within a specific time a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP**.

If the cause of the alarm disappear or are removed within 90 seconds, the machine will be automatically restarted. If not, the machine will step down to machine step Tank Filling

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205635.png)

*   Photocell
*   Chute
*   Screw cap sorter

**Troubleshooting**

*   Look for any obvious obstacles in the screw cap sorter and the chute.
    
*   Set the airflow through the return pipe according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Sorter - Set Valve](#section1068)
    
*   Set the photocell for the chute according to:
    
    [Chute - Set Photocell](#section1075)
    
    [Chute - Change Photocell](#section1078)
    

### 110307641/110307642, Screw Cap Sorter S1/S2, Warm Motor Overload

**Description**

The [Motor](#Motormotor-ED09FA91) runs the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-ED09FEF1).

**Conditions to set the alarm**

The alarm, which is a summary alarm, indicates that there is something wrong with the motor or the frequency converter.

The specific fault is displayed in the window of the frequency converter (G31T1022, side 1 or G31T2022, side 2) as an error number.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205634.png)

*   Motor
*   Screw cap sorter

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure the mechanism inside the screw cap sorter can rotate freely.
    
*   Reset the overload protection for the motor.
    
*   Check the fuse number 82 in the main electrical cabinet.
    
*   Check electrical terminals for bad connections.
    

### 110707711/110707712, Screw Cap Sorter S1/S2, Low Level

**Description**

The [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-ED0A3E74) controls the level in the [Screw cap sorter](#ScrewCapSorterscrewCapSorter-ED0A3B87).

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the [Photocell](#Photocellphotocell-ED0A3E74) detects a low level of screw caps for 25 seconds, a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP**. The machine will then step down the affected machine side.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205633.png)

*   Screw cap sorter
*   Photocell
*   Reflector

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure there are no obstacles in the pipes between the **CSU** and the screw cap sorter.
    
*   Check the function of the photocell according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Sorter - Check Photocell](#section1066)
    
    [Screw Cap Sorter - Set Photocell](#section1067)
    
    [Screw Cap Sorter - Change Photocell](#section1070).
    
*   Check the function of the conveyer in the **CSU**.
    

### 110307691/110307692, Screw Cap integrity fault from Vision system S1/S2

**Description**

When a package passes the camera on the conveyer, the height difference between the [Screw cap](#ScrewCapscrewCap-ED0A9307) and the [Package edge](#PackageEdgepackageEdge-ED0A9BAA) is measured. If this distance is outside a certain interval, the package will be wasted. The interval is the average height of the last 200 produced packages plus **TPOP** setting.

When a package passes the camera on the conveyer, the angular difference between the [Screw cap](#ScrewCapscrewCap-ED0A9307) and the [Package edge](#PackageEdgepackageEdge-ED0A9BAA) is measured. If this angle is above the value set on **TPOP**, the package will be wasted.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If three out of the latest 30 packages are rejected, a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** and the machine will be stepped down to tank filling.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205662.png)

*   Screw cap
*   Package edge

**Troubleshooting**

*   make sure that the screw cap holders are in good condition.
    
*   perform the basic set for the capper unit:
    
    [Capper Unit - Basic Set](#section1094)
    
*   Set the end positions for the screw cap lift according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Lift - Set End Positions](#section1112)
    
*   Set the screw cap transfer cylinder according to:
    
    [Screw Cap Transfer- Set Parallelism](#section1055)
    
    [Screw Cap Transfer - Set Overloading](#section1056)
    
*   Check the settings for the **LFU**:
    
    [LFU - Basic Set](#section741)
    

*   If the yellow light on the camera lights, restart it by cycling power:
    
    [Vision Unit - Cycle Power](#section1972)
    
*   Perform the fine adjustment for the vision unit according to:
    
    [Vision Unit- Set fine adjustment with PC](#section1158)
    
*   Make sure that the conveyer speed is correct. It must be 15m/min.
    
*   If the location where the camera measures is exposed to direct sunlight, the function of the camera might be disturbed. Take measures to cover the sunlight.
    
*   Check the photocell. Set or change, if necessary:
    
    [Photocell - Check](#section1168)
    
    [Photocell - Set](#section1169)
    
    [Photocell - Change](#section1171)
    
*   Clean the camera lens according to:
    
    Chapter 8 Care and Cleaning in the Operation Manual.
    
*   Perform the mechanical settings for the camera unit according to:
    
    [Vision Unit - Set Position](#section1157)
    
*   Check that the camera is properly fixed.
    
*   Check that the camera volume change cylinder is properly fixed.

    [Photocell - Set](#section1169)
    
    [Photocell - Change](#section1171)
    
*   If the location where the camera measures is exposed to direct sunlight the function of the camera might be disturbed. Take measures to cover the sunlight.
    
*   Clean the camera lens according to:
    
*   Perform the mechanical settings for the camera unit according to:
    
    [Vision Unit - Set Position](#section1157)
    
*   Make sure that the conveyer speed is correct, it must be 15m/min.
    

### 110307671/110307672 Communication Error Vision System

**Description**

`Communication fault`.

Yellow function light indicates reading in progress.

Red function light indicates tilted screw cap or internal program fault, for example communication fault. Red function light can also indicate that the photocell is activated but there is no package in reading position.

Green function light indicates everything OK.

Green blinking function light indicates that the camera is waiting for a signal from the **PLC**. The signal is sent when the machine is in step production.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the communication between the camera and the TT/3 machine fails.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure that the communication cable for the camera is properly attached.

### 110307911 / 110307912 / 110307921 / 110307922, S1:1 / S1:2 / S2:1 / S2:2, Cap Orientation Failed

**Description**

When the loading piston inserts the screw cap into the screw cap holder, the control system (**PLC**) orients the screw cap by rotating it. The heels in the screw cap then grip together with the notches on the loading piston. The PLC monitors how many degrees the screw cap is rotated and how long it takes to find the heels in the screw cap.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the machine fails to orient three screw caps within 30 seconds, a yellow alarm will occur on the **TPOP** and the machine will step down the affected machine side.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that a cap is present in the cap holder to be applied to the neck. Missing cap can not be detected by the machine so the alarm will be Cap Orientation failed. see [Troubleshoot - Cap Torque Error and Tilted Caps](#section992).
    
*   Check that the screw caps have heels.
    
*   Check the function of the loading pistons.
    
*   Set the cap transfer position for the screw cap lift. See Procedure [Screw Cap Lift - Set End Positions](#section1112).
    
*   Check the function of the screw cap holder servomotors.
    

### 110307931 / 110307932 / 110307941 / 110307942, S1:1 / S1:2 / S2:1 / S2:2, Unsafe Start Angle for Controlled Capping

**Description**

The control system (**PLC**) monitors how many degrees the screw caps are rotated when assembled on to the neck of the packages. The standard deviation of degrees that the screw caps are rotated is small if the machine is running correctly. The illustrations below show examples of when Controlled Capping is running correctly and when it is running poorly.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001436764.png)

Running correctly.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001436763.png)

Running poorly.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the PLC senses that the machine has been running in an unsafe area for more than 60 seconds, a yellow alarm will occur on the TPOP and the machine will step down on the affected machine side.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Perform a start angle screening. See Procedure [Controlled Capping - Set Start-Angle](#section1121).
    
*   Set the capping reference for the stripper. See Procedure [CAU Stripper - Set Capping Reference](#section1045).
    
*   Set the capping position for the screw cap lift. See Procedure [Screw Cap Lift - Set End Positions](#section1112).
    
*   Check the loading piston template setting. See Procedure [Screw Cap Transfer - Set Overloading](#section1056) and [Screw Cap Transfer - Set Parallelism](#section1055).
    
*   Check the function of the Screw cap holder servomotors.
    

### 110307011/110307012 SleeveStop S1/S2, Wrong position

**Description**

The [Proximity Switch](#ProximitySwitchproximitySwitch-3DB01C44) controls if [Sleeve Stop](#SleeveStopsleeveStop-3DB02A0C) movement is in correct position during the [Magazine plate](#Magazinemagazine-3DB088D5) movement.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004014443.png)

*   Proximity Switch
*   Sleeve Stop
*   Magazine plate

**Condition for alarm**

The proximity switch G31B1338/G31B2338 detects if the [Sleeve Stop](#SleeveStopsleeveStop-3DB02A0C) is in wrong position between sector value range 1500-0200 and 0550-1200, during step MOTOR RUNNING, PRODUCTION or PRODUCTION END when **CAU** Magazine is in movement.

If the Sleeve Stop is not in lower position during step HEATING.

When the alarm is triggered:

*   The production stops on the affected machine sides.
    
*   The affected machine side stops cutting new blanks, but fills and finishes all the packages that are currently in the package section.
    
*   The unaffected machine side continues to run.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Package jammed between cylinder and Sleeve stop, remove package.
    
*   Incorrectly set proximity switch, see Chapter [Sleeve Stop - Check Cylinder Sensor](#section939).
    
*   Incorrectly set flow regulators, see Chapter [Sleeve Stop - Set Flow Regulators](#section942).
    
*   Incorrectly set air connection, see Pneumatic Diagram for Carton Section.
    

Troubleshooting CAU

### Troubleshoot - Cap Torque Error and Tilted Caps

2000

Equipment Status

Program Step production

#### Introduction

In the case of sporadic machine issues spread out over time, package waste figures for cap torque and tilted cap can be high even though the machine is not stopped for a specific alarm.

The reason being that the software is configured to only stop the machine if the same failure mode happens several times in a row or during a short period of time.

This trouble shooting guide is for that reason using the waste as origin instead of an alarm from TPOP.

### Troubleshoot - Quick Guide

### Troubleshoot - Cap Torque Error Waste

**Cap Torque Error, High Waste**

To guarantee that the cap is properly attached to the neck, the capping sequence has a quality control.

The cap is applied with a set torque and how many degrees the cap turns is measured.

If the cap turns more than allowed it indicates an incorrect capping, the package will then not be filled and wasted in front of the machine.

The torque error can come from that a cap is not in place to be capped, so analysing the waste is the first step in finding the root cause of the problem.

Troubleshooting C38 Caps
------------------------

### CSU Air Speed - Check

According to the Maintenance Manual, the airspeed must not exceed 10 m/s. However, the best solution is for the airspeed to be as slow as possible. See Procedure [Feed Unit - Set Fan Speed](#section1144) .

1.  If you do not have an airspeed measuring device, slow down the fan 1 Hz at a time. Run the machine for 10 to 15 minutes.
    
2.  Repeat this step until the **CSU** fails to supply the machine with caps. Then empty the system of caps, increase the speed by 2 Hz, and then restart production. This is the best **CSU** airspeed for this equipment.
    

### Cap Trap Lid, Guide, Air, Nozzle - Check

Equipment Status

Air must be turn OFF.  
Program Step

#### Ensure Parts Installed

1.  Check and make sure that the following parts are installed correctly:
    
    *   The [Air nozzle](#AirNozzleAirNozzle-098F11D5) is connected in the [Air return pipe](#AirReturnPipeairReturnPipe-098F10D6).
        
    *   The [Cap return air regulator](#CapReturnAirRegulatorCapReturnAirRe-098F1401) has been opened seven turns.
        
    *   The [Cap trap air regulator](#CapTrapAirRegulatorCapTrapAirRegula-098F149F) has been opened four turns.
        
    *   The [Direction guide](#DirectionGuideDirectionGuide-098F163D) is mounted with two [Screw](#Screwscrews-098F16EC) on the cap trap lid.
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0005252823.png)

#### Secure the Correct Position of the Blow Nozzle

1.  Disassemble the cap trap.
    
2.  Mark the centre of the trap on the lid with a marker when the lid is in the position as shown in the image.

4.  Hold the pipe in the correct position. Put the blow nozzle behind the centre, otherwise the caps get stuck in the cap trap.

### Cap Chute Lids - Check

Equipment Status

Air must be turn OFF.

### How to Understand Cap-Related Waste

There are two types of cap-related waste:

*   camera waste
    
*   **FM** waste
    

For camera waste, it is important to differentiate ghost waste from tilted caps:

*   Ghost waste occurs due to a faulty camera setting.
    
*   Tilted caps occur due to heat problems in the top, or misalignment in the **CAU**.
    

For **FM** waste, see Section [How to Understand Cap Waste in FM](#section1011).

### How to Understand Cap Waste in FM

Broken caps on the sprue box cause wasted packages without caps. Broken caps are caps that have been smashed in the cap loading area. The caps are smashed because they have been in the wrong position (not all the way down or fallen) during the cap loading sequence.

Reasons for broken caps:

*   The 69-mm setting of the cap loading position is not set correctly. See Procedure [Cap Loading Piston, Template, Setting - Check](#section1002).
    

*   The ends of the cap chutes are bent. See Procedure [Cap Chute Quality - Check](#section1005).
    

*   The cap hatches or cap chutes are not set correctly causing lack of cue pressure, which makes the caps fall in the cap loading position. See Procedure [Cap Chute Hatch Setting - Check](#section1004).
    

*   The Y-setting is wrong causing lack of caps and cue pressure. See Procedure [Direction Guide, Air Nozzle - Check](#section1000).
    

*   Wrong type of cap chute lids. See Procedure [Cap Chute Lids - Check](#section999).
    

*   The springs are broken.
    

*   Wrong type of bushings. See Procedure [Bushing - Check](#section1001).
    

### FAQ

*   Why are there many plastic particles everywhere?
    
    1.  The **CSU** speed is set too high. See Procedure [CSU Air Speed - Check](#section997).
        
    2.  Make sure you have the correct air flow. See Procedure [CSU Air Speed - Check](#section997).
        

*   Why do the caps get stuck in the cap trap in the sorter?
    
    1.  The wrong part is used or the settings are wrong. See Procedure [Cap Trap Lid, Guide, Air, Nozzle - Check](#section998).
        

*   Why do the caps get stuck in the chutes?
    
    1.  The tamper rings are damaged in the pipes from the **CSU**. See Procedure [CSU Air Speed - Check](#section997).
        
    2.  The wrong lids are being used. See Procedure [Cap Chute Lids - Check](#section999).
        
    3.  The lids are not mounted correctly. See Procedure [Cap Chute Lids - Check](#section999).
        

*   Why do the caps get stuck in the ”Y”?
    
    1.  Check ”Y” settings according to Procedure [Direction Guide, Air Nozzle - Check](#section1000).
        
    2.  Make sure that the chutes and hatches are okay. See Procedure [Cap Chute Lids - Check](#section999), Procedure [Cap Chute Hatch Setting - Check](#section1004), and Procedure [Cap Chute Quality - Check](#section1005).
        

*   Why are there problems with damaged caps in the cap loading area (smashed caps, broken tamper rings, and so on)?
    
    1.  Make sure that the cap loading is correct. See Procedure [Cap Loading Piston, Template, Setting - Check](#section1002).
        

*   Why do the caps get stuck in the cap loading area?
    
    1.  The settings are wrong or the wrong parts are used. See Procedure [Bushing - Check](#section1001), Procedure [Cap Loading Piston, Template, Setting - Check](#section1002), and Procedure [Cap Chute Quality - Check](#section1005).
        

*   Why is the cap sorter too slow?
    
    1.  The cap sorter could be too slow because the wrong settings can have been chosen on the **TPOP**.
        

*   Why are the lids too warm?
    
    1.  The **HC** temperature sensor could be out of position. See Procedure [HC Output and Temperature Sensors - Check](#section1007).
        

*   Why do caps get stuck in the cap trap right after the sorter?
    
    1.  The edges in the cap trap are sharp.

### Drive Unit - Set Capping Position

Equipment Status

Program Step HEATING

**Note:** This procedure is only valid when Controlled Capping is deactivated.

**Note:** It is important that both production sides of the machine are stepped down to HEATING or lower for this setting to take effect.

3.  Connect a keyboard to the **TPOP**.
    
4.  Step the machine up to Program step production.
    
5.  Produce two packages.
    
6.  Wait until the packages have passed through the machine.
    
    *   If the packages were transferred out of the machine the normal way through the outfeed conveyer, see Section [Set Capping Position](#SetCappingPosition-14C2D375).
        
    *   If the packages have no screw caps and were thrown out of the machine after the package section, see Section [Set Cassette Position](#SetCassettePosition-14C2D617).
        
        **Note:** Packages can be thrown out of the machine for other reasons, but if they have no screw caps, it is likely that the capping position for the drive unit is set wrong.
        

#### Set Capping Position

1.  Push the F4 button to open `Technical menu`.
    
2.  Press [CAU technical window](#CAUTechnicalWindowCAUTechnicalWindo-F2B31DF5).
    
3.  Press [Capping position S1](#CappingPositionS1CappingPosition-F2B334E5) or [Capping position S2](#CappingPositionS2CappingPosition-F2B34548), depending on production side to activate it.
    
4.  Press [Enable Increase/Decrease](#EnableIncreaseDecreaseEnableIncreas-F2B352AB).
    
5.  Use [Decrease](#DecreaseDecrease-F2B36286) to reduce the value for [Capping position S1](#CappingPositionS1CappingPosition-F2B334E5) or [Capping position S2](#CappingPositionS2CappingPosition-F2B34548) by **0.5** and displace the capping position backward.
    
6.  Press [Exit](#ExitExit-F2B3838A) and press save.
    
7.  Repeat items [Reference](StepUpTheMachineToProduction.-14B784C9) to [Reference](PressAndPressSave.-14B78781) and continue to reduce the value for [Capping position S1](#CappingPositionS1CappingPosition-F2B334E5) or [Capping position S2](#CappingPositionS2CappingPosition-F2B34548) in steps of **0.5**, until the packages get thrown out of the machine after the package section. Then add **1.0** to the value for [Capping position S1](#CappingPositionS1CappingPosition-F2B334E5) or [Capping position S2](#CappingPositionS2CappingPosition-F2B34548) and the setting is finished.
    
    **Note:** When the packages are thrown out of the machine after the package section, it indicates that the screw cap is not correctly attached.

#### Set Cassette Position

3.  Press [Cassette position S1](#CassettePositionS1CassettePosition-F2B3902B) or [Cassette position S2](#CassettePositionS2CassettePosition-F2B399E6), depending on production side, to activate it.

6.  Press [Exit](#ExitExit-F2B3838A) and press `save`.

Repeat items [Reference](StepUpTheMachineToProduction.-14B784C9) to [Reference](PressAndPressSave.-14B79FA7) and continue to add to the value for [Cassette position S1](#CassettePositionS1CassettePosition-F2B3902B) or [Cassette position S2](#CassettePositionS2CassettePosition-F2B399E6) in steps of **0.5** until the packages are transferred out of the machine through the outfeed conveyer. Then the setting is finished.
    
    **Note:** When the packages are transferred out of the machine through the outfeed conveyer, it indicates that the setting is correct.

    If the distance A<1 ±0.1mm for any of the positions, repeat items [Reference](PullTheBackAgainstThe.-4FE5F23E) to [Reference](RemoveTheFeelerGauge.-4FE5F7F8) for the position with the smallest distance **A**.

### Screw Cap Transfer - Set Overloading

Equipment Status

Program Step AIR ON

Special Equipment

Valve Guide TP No. 3520946-0000. Valid for Mecman.  
Setting Template TP No. 2901501-0000

Risk of crushing.

Be careful when activating the cylinder.

The air cylinder moves if it is activated by compressed air.

This operation is done to ensure a correct overloading of the loading pistons. Too little overloading makes the screw caps fall out of the screw cap holders, too much overloading breaks the capping cylinder.

3.  Before performing this setting, make sure that the cap lift is in cap transfer position. See Procedure [Screw Cap Lift - Set End Positions](#section1112).
    
4.  Activate the capping cylinder valves to push the screw cap holders in loading position. To activate the valves, see Procedure [Pneumatic Valves - Manual Override](#section2114).
    
    *   G31K1220 for S1
        
    *   G31K2220 for S2
        
5.  Load a screw cap in the screw cap holder manually.
    
6.  Push the screw cap transfer unit forward and load screw caps into the screw cap holders.
    
7.  Activate the transfer cylinder valves to put the loading pistons in their loading position. To activate the valves, see Procedure [Pneumatic Valves - Manual Override](#section2114).
    
    *   G31K1217 for S1
        
    *   G31K2217 for S2
        

6.  Rotate the screw cap holders to the left, gently by hand, until the heels in the screw caps are aligned with the notches on the [Loading piston](#LoadingPistonloadingPistons-219D12E2).
    
    **Note:** This step is performed to ensure that the over travel distance will be correct. If the notches on the loading piston and the heels in the screw caps are interfering in the wrong way, the over travel distance will be incorrect.
    
7.  Use a feelergauge to check the distance **A** between the [Loading piston](#LoadingPistonloadingPistons-219D12E2) and the [Bracket](#Bracketbracket-219CA935).
    
8.  To set the distance **A**, loosen the [Lock nut](#Locknutlocknut-219D54EE) and adjust the position of the [Bracket](#Bracketbracket-219CA935) with the [Adjustment screw](#AdjustmentScrewadjustmentScrew-219D5FAC) and tighten the [Lock nut](#Locknutlocknut-219D54EE).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004760625.png)

A = 2 ±0.5 mm

*   Loading piston
*   Bracket

*   Adjustment screw
*   Lock nut

9.  The sensor is activated when the cap transfer unit is in loading position. If the sensor is not activated, adjust the sensor.
    
    **Note:** The sensor is only activated when the yellow LED is lit.
    
10.  Loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrew-219DD171) on the [Sensor](#Sensorsensor-219DD888).
    
11.  Slide the [Sensor](#Sensorsensor-219DD888) to find the interval where only the yellow **LED** light on the sensor is lit. Yellow and red **LED** light at the same time indicates that the sensor is outside the sensitivity interval.
    
12.  Set the [Sensor](#Sensorsensor-219DD888) in the middle of this interval and tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrew-219DD171).
    
13.  Deactivate the pneumatic valves. See Procedure [Pneumatic Valves - Manual Override](#section2114).
    
    *   G31K1220 for S1
        
    *   G31K1217 for S1
        
    *   G31K2220 for S2
        
    *   G31K2217 for S2
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004760624.png)

*   Screw
*   Sensor

#### Set Capper Unit Parallelism

1.  Use a [Wrench](#Wrenchwrench-F3C050FE) to lift and hold the [Capper unit](#CapperUnitcapperUnit-F3C054DE).
    
2.  Put the [Setting template](#SettingTemplatesettingTemplate-F3C0590B) in position.
    
3.  Position the [Forming tube template](#FormingTubeTemplateformingTubeTempl-F3C05FDB).
    
4.  Put the [Rod](#Rodrod-F3C065AD) in position.
    
5.  Adjust the height with the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C06BBB) until the [Forming tube template](#FormingTubeTemplateformingTubeTempl-F3C05FDB) and the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolders-F3C075F8) are centred.
    
6.  Slide the [Forming tube template](#FormingTubeTemplateformingTubeTempl-F3C05FDB) forward until they enter the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolders-F3C075F8).
    
    **Note:** If it is impossible to fit the forming tube templates in the screw cap holders, loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrews-F3C0836E) keeping the screw cap holder in lowest possible position. Fit the [Forming tube template](#FormingTubeTemplateformingTubeTempl-F3C05FDB) in the [Screw cap holder](#ScrewCapHolderscrewCapHolders-F3C075F8). If necessary, adjust the height with the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C06BBB). Then tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrews-F3C0836E).

#### Set Bridge and Cylinder End Positions

Risk of crushing.

Be careful when activating the cylinder.

The air cylinder will move if it is activated by compressed air.

Risk of damage to equipment

Never set the gap **A**, illustrated under [Preparations](#Preparations-13292C54), to less than 3 mm. If the gap is smaller, there is a risk of damage to the equipment.

### Capper Unit - Set Sensor

Equipment Status

Program Step

The yellow LED light on the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5) and the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875) must light up to indicate that the capping cylinder is in an end position. The LED light on the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5) for fully retracted cylinder and the LED light on the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875) for fully extended cylinder. A yellow and red LED light at the same time from a sensor indicates that the sensor is outside of the sensitivity interval.
