3.  Hold the [Capping cylinder](#CappingCylinderCappingCylinder-F3C3D663) in fully retracted position.
    
4.  Loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C3EC2F) on the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5).
    
5.  Slide the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5) to find the interval where the yellow **LED** light on the sensor lights up. A yellow and red LED light at the same time indicates that the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5) is outside of the sensitivity interval.
    
6.  Set the [Sensor (retracted position)](#SensorretractedPositionsensor-F3C3A1E5) in the middle of this interval and tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C3EC2F).
    
7.  Release the [Capping cylinder](#CappingCylinderCappingCylinder-F3C3D663) from fully retracted position.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000205856.png)

*   Capping cylinder
*   Sensor (retracted position)
*   Screw

*   Sensor (extended position)
*   Screw

8.  Hold the [Capping cylinder](#CappingCylinderCappingCylinder-F3C3D663) in fully extended position.
    
9.  Loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C3FD80) on the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875).
    
10.  Slide the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875) to find the interval where the yellow **LED** light on the sensor lights up. A yellow and red LED light at the same time indicates that the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875) is outside of the sensitivity interval.
    
11.  Set the [Sensor (extended position)](#SensorextendedPositionsensor-F3C3A875) in the middle of this interval and tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F3C3FD80).
    
12.  Release the [Capping cylinder](#CappingCylinderCappingCylinder-F3C3D663) from fully extended position.
    
13.  Assemble the servomotor and the box.

### Controlled Capping - Set Start-Angle

Equipment Status

Program Step PRODUCTION

**Note:** The start-angle must be set on all recipe and volume combinations:

1.  The first time that they are introduced in the equipment.
    
2.  The first time that they are used after a mechanical change in the **CAU**.
    
3.  When a recipe colour for the cap has been changed.
    

The procedure searches for the optimal start-angle for `controlled capping` by testing different start-angles.

3.  Make sure that the stripper home position is set. See Procedure [CAU Stripper - Set Capping Reference](#section1045).
    
4.  Step the machine up to Production.
    
5.  Connect a keyboard to the **TPOP**.
    
6.  Push F4 on the keyboard to open the `Technical Menu`.
    
7.  Press [CAU technical window](#CAUTechnicalWindowCAUTechnicalWindo-1EE530EA).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0005016290.png)

*   `None`

6.  Set the current side (S1 or S2) for the angle search:
    
    *   Set S1 by activating the [Capper Motor 1:1](#CapperMotorCapperMotor-1EE6143A).
        
    *   Set S2 by activating the [Capper Motor 2:1](#CapperMotor11CapperMotor11-1EE88871).
        
    
    **Note:** Activating the search on Capper Motor X:1 also activates the search for Capper Motor X:2.

    Status
    
    Description
    
    666
    
    No search has been performed.
    
    999
    
    The search failed.
    
    0-115
    
    Showing the recommended start-angle.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0005036611.png)

    *   When the search is completed, the status of the search is shown in the field [Recommended Start-Angle](#RecommendedStartAnglerecommendedSta-1EE919C5).
        
9.  If the search failed:
    
    *   The status number 999 is displayed in the field [Recommended Start-Angle](#RecommendedStartAnglerecommendedSta-1EE919C5).
        
    *   Do a new search. See item [Reference](DoTheSearchPressAndThenPress.AGreen-15D3990F).

### Controlled Capping - Waste Failed Orientations

Equipment Status

Program Step PRODUCTION

If the machine produces a large number of packages with failed cap orientation, Waste Failed Orientations can be activated to separate the failed orientations from the rest. Waste Failed Orientations can be activated during production or Motor Running.

1.  Connect a keyboard to the **TPOP**.
    
2.  Push F4 on the keyboard to open the `Technical Menu`.
    
3.  Press [CAU technical window](#CAUTechnicalWindowCAUTechnicalWindo-1EE530EA).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001396429.png)

*   CAU technical window

4.  Press [Capper Motor 1:1](#CapperMotorCapperMotor-1EE6143A) or [Capper Motor 2:1](#CapperMotor11CapperMotor11-1EE88871), depending on production side.
    
    **Note:** Activating Waste Failed Orientations for Capper Motor X:1 starts Waste Failed Orientations for Capper Motor X:2.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001396538.png)

*   `Capper Motor 1:1`
*   `Capper Motor 2:1`

5.  Press [Waste Failed Orientations](#WasteFailedOrientationsWasteFailedO-428D1D8E) and press [ON](#ONON-428D21FE) to activate Waste Failed Orientations.
    
    **Note:** The [Indicator](#IndicatorgreenLight-428D3277) on the [Waste Failed Orientations](#WasteFailedOrientationsWasteFailedO-428D1D8E) button indicates that Waste Failed Orientations is running.
    
    **Note:** Waste Failed Orientations is automatically deactivated after one hour, or when the machine is stepped down below Motor Running.

### Feed Unit - Conveyer Belt

Equipment Status

Program Step

#### Check Belt Wear

1.  Check the belt for wear. Pay special attention to the edges of the belt.
    
2.  If the belt shows any sign of wear, replace it according to [Change Conveyer Belt](#ChangeConveyerBelt-591F4981).
    

#### Check Belt Alignment

1.  Check belt alignment. If it is not centred, continue with items [b)](ReleaseTheToReleaseTheTensionOfTheB-33E2A96C) and [c)](UseAScrewdriverOrASimilarObjectAtTh-33E2AF53).
    
2.  Release the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-3DD49BE1) to release the tension of the belt.
    
3.  Use a screwdriver or a similar object at the [Adjustment points](#AdjustmentPointsadjustmentPoints-3DD4A118) to adjust the [Roller brackets](#RollerBracketsrollerBrackets-3DEB2345).

#### Change Conveyer Belt

1.  Empty the **CSU** from screw caps according to the OM.

6.  Remove the [Cover](#Covercover-6EE53CE0).
    
7.  Remove the [Springs](#Springssprings-3EE1EE97).
    
8.  Loosen the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-3EE1F5F5).
    
9.  Move the [Geared motor unit](#GearedMotorUnitgearedMotorUnit-3EE1FE1D) to release the tension on the [Timing belt](#TimingBelttimingBelt-3EE20821).
    
10.  Remove the [Conveyor roller](#ConveyorRollerscomveyorRollers-3EE210BD).
    
11.  Remove the [Spacer](#Spacersspacers-3EE219A9).

14.  Install the new conveyor belt.
    
15.  Assemble in the reverse order.

### Feed Unit - Timing Belt

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

#### Check Timing Belt

1.  Remove the cover.
    
2.  Check the teeth on the timing belt for wear. If the teeth are worn, change the timing belt according to [Change Timing Belt](#ChangeTimingBelt-3DE9B47F).
    
3.  Assemble the cover.
    

#### Change Timing Belt

1.  Remove the [Cover](#Covercover-58A0C42E).
    
2.  Remove the [Springs](#Springssprings-58A0C42E).
    
3.  Loosen the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-58A0C42E).
    
4.  Move the [Geared motor unit](#GearedMotorUnitgearedMotorUnit-58A0C42E) to reduce the tension on the [Timing belt](#TimingBelttimingBelt-58A0C42F).
    
5.  Remove the old [Timing belt](#TimingBelttimingBelt-58A0C42F).
    
6.  Install in the reverse order.
    
7.  Move the [Geared motor unit](#GearedMotorUnitgearedMotorUnit-58A0C42E) to increase the tension on the [Timing belt](#TimingBelttimingBelt-58A0C42F).
    
8.  Tighten the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-58A0C42E).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001504278.png)

*   Cover
*   Springs

*   Timing belt

16.  Make sure that the [Fourth sealing strip](#FourthSealingStripfourthSealingStri-41429E1E) is installed 21±1 mm from the edge of the lid.
    
    **Note:** all measurements are to be measured from the inside edge of the lid

17.  Assemble the lid in the reverse order. See items [Reference](RemoveTheFromTheMachine.-4142EFA8) to [Reference](OpenThe.-414317E5).
    
18.  Make sure that the new sealing strips are tight against the container and are sealing properly.
    
    **Note:** if the sealing strips are not seated properly against the container, the necessary overpressure inside the CSU is not obtained.

#### Adjust Camera Position

1.  Loosen the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-5790B4E0) (8pcs) to free the [Clamps](#CameraUnitcameraUnit-5790BA4A) .
    
2.  Check the position of the [Cylinder](#Cylindercylinder-808AC54D), the distance **A** has the following dependency:
    
    **Dependency**
    
    **Distance**
    
    [Cylinder](#Cylindercylinder-808AC54D) is in upper position
    
    **A**\= 388 -1.0/+0 mm
    
    [Cylinder](#Cylindercylinder-808AC54D) is in lower position
    
    **A**\= 338-1.0/+0 mm
    
3.  Adjust the [Articulated foot](#BarTemplatebarTemplates-5790AB9F) (3pcs) to achieve the distance **A** between the [Camera Unit](#ConveyerBeltconveyerBelt-5790DC28) and the surface of the [Articulated foot](#ArticulatedFootarticulatedFeet-F763276C).
    
    **Note:** Turn the [Articulated foot](#BarTemplatebarTemplates-5790AB9F) half a turn at the time to set the distance A.
    
4.  Use a spirit level to make sure that the [Articulated foot](#ArticulatedFootarticulatedFeet-F763276C) and the [Camera Unit](#ConveyerBeltconveyerBelt-5790DC28) are levelled relative to each other.
    
    **Note:** Use the spirit level on the [Cylinder](#Cylindercylinder-808AC54D), to get a precise value of the [Camera Unit](#ConveyerBeltconveyerBelt-5790DC28).
    
5.  Lock the [Articulated foot](#BarTemplatebarTemplates-5790AB9F) when the distance A is set.
    
6.  Fasten the [Clamps](#CameraUnitcameraUnit-5790BA4A) with the [Screws](#Screwsscrews-5790B4E0).

### Vision Unit - Check Incorrect Read via TPOP

The information about Incorrect read from the vision camera can be used when evaluating the performance of the vision camera, and for troubleshooting function.

2.  Connect a keyboard to the **TPOP**.
    
3.  Push F4 on the keyboard to open the Technical Menu.
    
4.  Push the [Button](#Buttonbutton-7021F8DA) to open the `CAU technical` window.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000514281.png)

*   Button

4.  Press the [Go to sub menu button](#GoToSubMenuGoToSubMenu-6EC2040F) to go to the second page of the `CAU technical` window.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002988944.png)

*   `Go to sub menu` button

5.  Compare the information about [Incorrect read vision on S1 and S2](#IncorrectReadVisionOnS1AndS2Incorre-6EC2AA87) and [Injection completed on S1 and S2](#InjectionCompletedOnS1AndS2Injectio-6EC29B97) on S1 and S2.
    
6.  If the amount of [Incorrect read vision on S1 and S2](#IncorrectReadVisionOnS1AndS2Incorre-6EC2AA87) is high compared to the amount of [Injection completed on S1 and S2](#InjectionCompletedOnS1AndS2Injectio-6EC29B97), adjust the vision camera. See Procedure [Vision Unit - Set Position](#section1157) and 4.10-5 Vision Unit - Set Camera Angle. For MiniV Nallo, see [Vision Unit - Set Fine Adjustment for MiniV Nallo](#section1162).
    
    **Note:** Fallen packages are included in incorrect read. However, the proposed adjustments will not necessarily stop packages from falling and will therefore not automatically lower the amount of Incorrect read.
    
    *   Fallen package below the vision camera
        
    *   Wrong conveyor speed (15m/min recommended)
        
    *   No space between packages when they pass the camera
        
    *   Rotated packages on the conveyor
        
    *   Packages too close to the camera
        
    *   Packages too far from the camera
        
    *   Packages not centred in the camera view
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002988943.png)

*   Injection completed on S1 and S2
*   Incorrect read vision on S1 and S2

#### Reset of Incorrect Read Vision

1.  Press the [Manoeuvre window](#ManoeuvreWindowButtonManoeuvreWindo-70335F65), and then press the [CAU S1](#CAUButton-7033C28C) for S1 or S2 to open the [Setting and information CAU](#SettingAndInformationCAUWindowSetti-7033DDFE).
    
2.  Press the [Enable Increase/Decrease button](#EnableIncreaseDecreaseEnableIncreas-7034117D) to choose reset for [Reset for S1](#S1S1-70349771) or [Reset for S2](#S2S2-70349B3D).
    
3.  Press `Reset` for the machine side that needs reset of the Incorrect read vision.
    
    **Note:** Pressing Reset resets all information, including Incorrect read vision.

### Functional Description

**Introduction**

The unfinished packages enter the package section from the mandrel wheels and are placed in cassettes. These cassettes transport the package through the filling and bottom sealing mechanisms. The packages are then placed on an outfeed unit and exit the machine.

**Note:** Read the description in the specific sections for more information.

**Conveyor and Conveyor Drive Unit**

The conveyor is made up by a number off cassettes, the unit that drives them and various equipment that guides the cassettes.

The cassette conveyor is driven by two servo motors attached to two planetary gearboxes. The front and back wheels are driven by separate servomotors. The front wheel is automatically adjusted by a homing procedure. The mechanical play is by default set to 70% between the upper cassettes and 30% between the lower cassettes. The mechanical play of the front wheel can be adjusted on the TPOP. The start position of the rear wheel (the infeed wheel) is adjusted on the TPOP. The drive unit is also synchronized with the other movements in the machine through the PLC system.

**Bottom Sealing**

The Bottom sealer has two servo driven units. The first of these is the lifting unit that lifts the cassette with the filled package, the cassette stabilizer and the volume displacement cylinders. The second unit is the sealing unit with a knee mechanism that moves the sonotrodes and the dolly and assures the sealing by a pneumatic spring force.

**Final Folder**

The function of the final folder unit is to fold the transversal seal, form it to flaps and seal them to the bottom of the package to make the package stand steadily.

**Outfeed Unit**

The function of the discharger unit is to pull the packages from the cassettes and place them on the conveyor chain. Packages with unsealed flaps are detected by a photocell (in the machine body) and ejected.

**Hygiene Chamber**

The hygiene chamber prevents contamination from the surrounding environment. This is done in three steps:

*   Spray of H2O2 peroxide solution.
    
*   High energy UV-radiation.
    
*   Removing peroxide residue using hot HEPA-filtrated air.

### 110304011 / 110304021 / 110304012 / 110304022, Cassette Stabiliser, Wrong Position

Alarms and Troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The machine is equipped with cassette stabilisers. The stabilisers centres the cassettes when the sleeves are moving from the capping station in the **CAU** or the stripper in the carton section.

**Condition for Alarm**

The cassette centring movement takes more than 250ms.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the holder is not bent and that there are no loose screws.
    
*   Check that the centring moves easily and is correctly set. See Procedure [5.6.4.1-1 Cassette Centring - Check](#section1403).
    
*   Check the lugs for wear and that the cylinder is not leaking air. Change if necessary. See Procedure [5.6.4.1-4 Cassette Centring – Overhaul](#section1406).
    
*   Check that the sensor has contact at the outer position.
    
*   Check the pneumatic supply to the cylinder.
    

### 110304411 / 110304412, HEPAAir Diffuser Plates, Wrong Position

**Description**

When running with a **TTCU** cleaning, the **HEPA** air diffuser opens and gets a small angle.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   The HEPA air diffuser plate should be closed (Production), but there is a signal.
    
*   The HEPA air diffuser plate should be open (running with TTCU), but there is no signal.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the sensor is working properly by checking the input signal to the **PLC**.
    
*   Check that the cylinder is working properly. Change if necessary.
    

### 110304041 / 110304281 / 110304042 / 110304282, Bottom Seal, Converter Fault

Alarms and Troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

When the bottom seal is made, the generator sends an electrical signal to the converter. The electrical signal is sent the frequency 20 kHz and is converted to oscillations energy by piezo elements.

**Condition for Alarm**

The generator detects a signal error to or from the converters.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make a seal evaluation according to the **OM** Package Checks. Check for overpressure on the package to make sure that it is not a mechanical problem.
    
*   Check that there is no gap between the sonotrode and the anvil when the servo motor is in its lowest position. If a gap is present, check the flat air cylinders in the bottom sealing housing that are compressing the package material, and perform a basic set.
    
*   Check that there is no water in the connection.
    
*   Check the cables between the converter and the generator, especially the quick-couplings.
    
*   Swap the converters between the machine sides and see if the problem is transferred to the other side. If it is transferred, change the converter.
    
*   Swap generators between the machine sides.
    

### 110304252, Bottom Sealing Jaws, Movement Error

alarms and troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The bottom sealing jaws move back and forth in the bottom sealer and are driven by a servomotor. The jaws press the packaging material together just before the sealing process begins.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   There is too much resistance when moving.
    
*   Something is obstructing the movement when performing a homing, which results in an incorrect home position for the servomotor.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Push the alarm icon a second time for a more detailed alarm description.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the movement.
    
*   Activate manual lubrication.
    
*   Try to manually move the jaws forward and check that they move smoothly.
    
*   Check the drive for alarm codes. If there are any alarm codes on the drive, the fault codes can be found in the MM. See Procedure [7.5.6-1 Servo System - General Troubleshoot](#section1863).
    
*   If something is obstructing the way when performing a homing, the home position could be set wrong. Step down the machine to Pre-heating and disconnect and connect the feedback cable to the servomotor.
    
    **Note:** Before doing this, check for alarm codes on the drive.
    

### 110304431, Main Return Valve, Wrong Position

**Description**

The main return valve transfers the product or cleaning liquid back out from the machine to process. The main return valve is used during **CIP**, Quick Rinse, Product Drain, and Tank Drain.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   The valve should be opened, but the sensor on the lid gets no signal.
    
*   The valve should be closed, but the sensor gets no signal.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the valve lid is correctly assembled.
    
*   Check that the sensor detects the position of the valve.
    
*   Check that the sensor is not positioned too far in or too far out.
    
*   If the lid “jumps” up repeatedly, try changing the air filter that is attached on the side of the valve. If that does not help, put two straps on the lid to hold it down as a temporary solution. Order a new part and replace the defected.
    
    **Note:** First make sure the sensor is not positioned too far in.
    
*   Check the input signal to the **PLC** via **EM**.
    

### 110304231 / 110304232, Outfeed Conveyor, Overload

**Description**

The outfeed conveyor belt transports the packages from the machine to the outer conveyor.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   The frequency converter does not send a ready signal.
    
*   The frequency converter does not send an active signal.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that nothing is obstructing the conveyor.
    
*   Check that the conveyor is not too tight or loose.
    
*   Check for an error code on the frequency converter.
    
*   Check the fuse.
    

### 110304401 / 110304402, Aborter Door, Wrong Position

**Description**

The aborter door should be closed when the **TTCU** re-uses the cleaning liquid during the External Cleaning.

**Condition for Alarm**

The doors are closed, but the sensor does not get a signal.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the doors are closed.
    
*   Check that the sensor is getting a signal that the doors are closed.
    
*   Check that the alarm disappears when placing a metal piece in front of the sensor.
    
*   Change the sensor.
    

### 110304580 / 110304581 / 110304582, Side Pusher Outfeed, Wrong Position

Valid for Dev. Step 1900 / 2000

**Description**

The side pusher is the final step in the machine. It pushes the packages on to the inner conveyor. The side pusher is driven by a servomotor.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   Something is obstructing the movement of the pusher.
    
*   Something is obstructing the movement when performing a homing, which results in an incorrect home position for the servomotor.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check the belt on the linear unit.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the side pusher.
    
*   Check the drive for alarm codes. If there are any alarm codes on the drive, the fault codes can be found in the MM. See Procedure [7.5.6-1 Servo System - General Troubleshoot](#section1863).
    
*   At homing, the position can change if the shafts for the cam roller are damaged.
    
*   If something is obstructing the way when performing a homing, the home position could be set wrong. Step down the machine to Pre-heating, then disconnect and connect the feedback cable to the servomotor.
    
    **Note:** Before doing this, check for alarm codes on the drive.
    
*   Check that no cassettes are damaged.
    

### 110304071 / 110304081 / 110304072 / 110304082, Flap Seal, Wrong Temperature

Alarms and Troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

To seal the flaps against the bottom of the package, the machine heats up part of the flaps to melt the outer layer of plastic. The flaps are then pressed against the package and cooled down.

When stepping up to motor running there is a 25s timer. The temperature for the flap sealing oven must be greater than the set minimum value before stepping up to production.

**Condition for Alarm**

The temperature deviates more than 20°C from the set value for more than 5s during production.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check the fuse.
    
*   If there is an open circuit or if the temperature sensor is broken, it shows 1372°C on the **TPOP**.
    
*   Make sure that the air temperature is 400-410°C.
    
*   Check that the flap sealing nozzle is not clogged. See Procedure [5.4.4-1 Flap Heater - Check](#section1308).
    
*   Check the thermocouple and the distance. See Procedure [5.4.4-4 Flap Heater - Fit Thermocouple](#section1311).
    
*   Check the air pressure:
    
    2.5±0.5bar for Base.
    
    2.0±0.5bar for Midi/Mini/Micro.
    
*   Check the heating element. If the air is lost, the heating element can be burnt.
    
*   Check for short circuit windings.
    

### 110304091 / 110304092, Outfeed, Ten Packages with Unsealed Flaps, S1

Alarms and Troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

To seal the flaps against the bottom of the package, the machine heats up part of the flaps to melt the outer layer of plastic. The flaps are then pressed against the package and cooled down.

**Condition for Alarm**

If 5x2packages get wasted because of bad flap sealing, the machine steps down. Note that there is a count down function for this alarm. For example, if the machine produces 4x2packages and then begins to produce packages with good flap sealing, the counter counts down until it reaches zero.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure that the air temperature is 400-410°C.
    
*   Make a sealing evaluation according to the **OM** Package Checks concerning the flap sealing.
    
*   Check that there are no product splashes on the packages.
    
*   Check the volume displacement.
    
*   Check the centring of the bottom sealing.
    
*   Check the creasing according to the **OM** Package Checks.
    
*   Check that the flap sealing nozzle is not clogged. See Procedure [5.4.4-1 Flap Heater - Check](#section1308).
    
*   Check the sensor and sensor lens. See Procedure [5.6.5-1 Photocell Unit - Check](#section1409).
    
*   Set the steering. See Procedure [5.4.3-1 Steering - Set](#section1306).
    
*   Check the flap heater and set if necessary. See Procedure:
    
    1.  [5.4.4-1 Flap Heater - Check](#section1308)
        
    2.  [5.4.4-2 Flap Heater - Set](#section1309)
        
    3.  [5.4.4-3 Flap Heater - Set Nozzle](#section1310)
        
*   Check and set the final folder. See Procedure:
    
    1.  [5.4.2-1 Flap Guide – Set](#section1304)
        
    2.  [5.4.3-1 Steering – Set](#section1306)
        
    3.  [5.4.4-1 Flap Heater - Check](#section1308)
        
    4.  [5.4.4-2 Flap Heater - Set](#section1309)
        
    5.  [5.4.6.1-1 Drive Unit – Check](#section1318)
        
*   Make sure that the outer support for the bottom sealing is levelled. See Procedure [5.3.7-3 Folding Support Anvil and Lift – Set](#section1272).
    
*   Check the flap folder and that the flap folder lugs are not worn out. Check and set the flap folder. See Procedure [5.4.2-1 Flap Guide – Set](#section1304).
    
*   Check if there is air in the product from the process.
    

### 110304270, Discharger Error

alarms and troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The discharger transfers the packages from the cassettes and puts them down in front of the pusher. The discharger is driven by a servomotor and connected to a linear unit to move it up and down. The gripper fingers are moved by pneumatic force.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   There is too much resistance when the discharger is moving.
    
*   Something is obstructing the movement when performing a homing, which results in an incorrect home position for the servomotor. The home position it set mechanically.
    
*   There is a problem with the linear unit or belt.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Push the alarm icon a second time for a more detailed alarm description.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the movement.
    
*   Check that mechanical parts are correctly aligned.
    
*   Check that the lubrication is sufficient and not absent.
    
*   Check the bushings.
    
*   Check the belt on the linear unit.
    
*   Check the drive for alarm codes. If there are any alarm codes on the drive, the fault codes can be found in the MM. See Procedure [7.5.6-1 Servo System - General Troubleshoot](#section1863).
    

### 110304101 / 110304102, Outfeed, Package Left in Cassette

**Description**

Two gripper fingers transfer packages from the cassette. The gripper fingers pull the packages out from the cassette and put them in front of the pusher.

A photocell unit, active during sector value800-1100, detects if the gripper fingers fail to pull the packages out from the cassette.

**Condition for Alarm**

The gripper fingers cannot pull the packages from the cassette.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that no package is stuck in the cassette.
    
*   If the package is empty, look for the cause.
    
*   Make a package and integrity check according to the **OM** Package Checks. Check bottom and package shape.
    
*   Check that no package is stuck in front of the photocell unit. See Procedure [5.6.5-1 Photocell Unit - Check](#section1409).
    
*   Check that the lenses on the photocell unit are not dirty, both inner and outer side.
    
*   Check the photocell unit. See Procedure [5.6.5-1 Photocell Unit - Check](#section1409).
    
*   Check the gripper finger according to:
    
    1.  [5.5.2-1 Gripping Device - Check Linear Bearing](#section1327)
        
    2.  [5.5.2-2 Gripping Device, Level of Gripper fingers- Check](#section1328)
        
    3.  [5.5.2-3 Gripper Fingers, Height – Check](#section1329)
        
    4.  [5.5.2-4 Grippers Fingers – Set](#section1330)
        
    5.  [5.5.2-5 Gripping Shafts – Set](#section1331)
        
*   Check that the belt is not broken or damaged in the discharger servo lifter. See Procedure [5.9.2-1 Servo Lift Discharger - Check Belt and Bearings](#section1472).
    
*   Check that the package section is in the correct machine sector value. If not, make a new homing. See Procedure [5.7.7-1 Drive Unit - Homing](#section1458).
    
*   If the alarm is triggered when there is no package in the package section, it could be the cassettes triggering the alarm. If this happens, the package section must be inched for the alarm to disappear. If this happens frequently, check the homing. See Procedure [5.7.7-1 Drive Unit - Homing](#section1458).
    
*   Check that the water lubrication is enough.
    
*   Check the upper volume displacement cylinders. Check that the buttons are not bent or have cracks.
    

### 110304241 / 110304242, Cassette Lift, Bottom Sealing Error

Alarms and Troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The cassette lift lifts the packages up during the transversal sealing.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   There is too much resistance when the cassette lift is moving up and down.
    
*   Something is obstructing the movement when performing a homing, which results in an incorrect home position for the servomotor.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Push the alarm icon a second time for a more detailed alarm description.
    
*   Check the belt on the linear unit.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the movement.
    
*   Check the drive for alarm codes. If there are any alarm codes on the drive, the fault codes can be found in the MM. See Procedure [7.5.6-1 Servo System - General Troubleshoot](#section1863).
    
*   If something is obstructing the way when performing a homing, the home position could be set wrong. Step down the machine to Pre-heating and disconnect and connect the feedback cable to the servomotor.
    
    **Note:** Before doing this, check for alarm codes on the drive.
    

### 110304211 / 110304212, Outfeed, Pusher Overload

**Description**

The outfeed pusher pushes the packages to the inner conveyor or, if there is a side pusher, to the plate above the inner conveyor.

**Condition for Alarm**

The outfeed pusher fails to move from the inner to the outer position in less than 600ms, three times in a row.

**Note:** After an external cleaning this alarm can occur up to three times.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that there is no fallen package obstructing the outfeed pusher.
    
*   Check the gripper fingers setting according to:
    
    1.  [5.5.2-1 Gripping Device - Check Linear Bearing](#section1327)
        
    2.  [5.5.2-2 Gripping Device, Level of Gripper fingers- Check](#section1328)
        
    3.  [5.5.2-3 Gripper Fingers, Height – Check](#section1329)
        
    4.  [5.5.2-4 Grippers Fingers – Set](#section1330)
        
    5.  [5.5.2-5 Gripping Shafts – Set](#section1331)
        
*   Do a package check. Check that the package bottom shape is correct.
    
*   Check that the inner conveyor is moving smoothly and that there is no height difference between the inner and outer conveyor. Check and set the conveyor chain. See Procedure [5.5.5-1 Conveyor Chain – Check](#section1362) and [5.5.5-2 Conveyor Chain - Set](#section1363).
    
*   If the machine is equipped with a **CAU** and the package is empty, check the waste level of torque error on the **TPOP**.
    
*   Check the discharger unit. Check if the fingers are gripping the package in correctly.
    
*   Check the pneumatic cylinders for leakage. See Procedure [5.5.4-1 Pusher – Check](#section1351).
    
*   Make sure that the pusher blade is at the correct distance and angle from the bottom plate. See Procedure [5.5.4-4 Pusher - Set](#section1354).
    
*   Check and set the ejecting device. See Procedure [5.5.3-3 Ejecting Device -Set](#section1344).
    
*   Check that the outfeed pusher is moving smoothly. See Procedure [5.5.3-2 Ejecting Device - Basic Set Cylinder Movement](#section1343).
    
*   Swap the proportional valves between the machine sides. Make sure that the valves are working properly. If needed, change valve. See Procedure [5.5.4-2 Pusher - Change Prop. Valve](#section1352).
    
*   Check that the sensor for the outfeed pusher is working and set the sensor. See Procedure [5.5.4-7 Proximity Switch Pusher - Set](#section1357).
    

### 110304171 / 110304172, Cassette Lift, Filling Error

alarms and troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The cassette lift lifts up the cassette during the filling of the package.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   There is too much resistance when the cassette lift is moving.
    
*   Something is obstructing the movement when performing a homing, which results in an incorrect home position for the servomotor. The home position it set mechanically.
    
*   There is a problem with the linear unit or belt.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Push the alarm icon a second time for a more detailed alarm description.
    
*   Check the belt on the linear unit.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the movement.
    
*   Check that mechanical parts that are correctly aligned.
    
*   Check that the lubrication is sufficient and not absent.
    
*   Check the drive for alarm codes. If there are any alarm codes on the drive, the fault codes can be found in the MM. See Procedure [7.5.6-1 Servo System - General Troubleshoot](#section1863).
    
*   If something is obstructing the way when performing a homing, the home position could be set wrong. Step down the machine to Pre-heating, then disconnect and connect the feedback cable to the servomotor.
    
    **Note:** Before doing this, check for alarm codes on the drive.
    

### 110304030, Cassette Conveyor Error

alarms and troubleshoot Package Section.

**Description**

The conveyor contains cassettes, which holds and transports the packages during several functions.

**Condition for Alarm**

*   The conveyor is moving with a high force.
    
*   The space between the cassette and conveyor rail is too small.
    
*   To much friction between the cassettes and conveyor rail. During an external cleaning the material gets hot and expands.
    
*   A package is stuck in the package section.
    

**Troubleshooting**

*   Push the alarm icon a second time for a more detailed alarm description.
    
*   Check the distance between the cassette and the conveyor guide rail. If necessary, set the guide rails. See Procedure [5.2.4.1-1 Guide Rails - Set](#section1244).
    
*   Check the distance between the cassettes
    
*   Check that the cassette lubrication is sufficient. Try increasing it a little.
    
*   Check that no parts are stuck between the cassette and star wheel.
    
*   Check that the volume displacement cylinder, both upper and lower, is working correctly and is not stuck in a cassette during production.
    
*   If this happens during a volume change, check that the volume change cylinder is not stuck in a position where it obstructs the conveyor movement.
    
*   Check if the cassette centring cylinder is slow and then check the setting of the cassette lift. See Procedure [5.3.10-1 Cassette Lifter, Centring - Set Height and Centring](#section1290) in the MM.
    
*   Check that the centring of the cassette stabilisers works smoothly and is correctly set. See Procedure [Cassette Centring - Check](#section1403) in the MM.
    

### 110304380, UV Water Clean, Low Intensity Lamp Fault

**Description**

The UV lamp sterilizes the cassette lubrication water for both machine sides.

**Condition for Alarm**

The sensor, attached to the UV lamp housing, is getting a weak light from the lamp.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the sensor lens is not dirty. See Procedure [5.13.3-2 Cassette Lubrication - Clean UV lamp and Sensor](#section1526).
    
*   Change the lamp. See Procedure [5.13.3-3 Cassette Lubrication - Change UV-lamp and O-ring](#section1527).
    
*   Check the fuse.
    

### 110304361 / 110304362, Output Module, Fuse Blown

**Description**

This is a summary alarm for all electronic fuses for the output modules in the Package DeviceNet nodes.

**Condition for Alarm**

A DeviceNet output module in the package section is overloaded.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the electrical connections are properly connected.
    
*   Switch the DeviceNet node OFF and ON. +24V turn off to ADN module and all the EP24 modules.
    
*   Change the **ADN** DeviceNet scanner module.
    
*   Tighten all unused connections.
    

### 110304151 / 110304152, Volume Change, Vertical Actuator in Wrong Position

**Description**

The volume washer position is adjusted, up or down, depending on package volume.

**Condition for Alarm**

The volume washer is not in position within 10seconds.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that nothing is obstructing the way.
    
*   Check that the sensor is working.
    
*   Check and set the volume change. See Procedure:
    
    1.  [5.11.1-3 Volume Change Mechanism – Set](#section1493)
        
    2.  [5.11.2-2 Motor Drive Control – Set](#section1497)
        
    3.  [5.11.2-1 Volume Change DC-motors - Set Current Limit](#section1496)
        
*   Step the machine to Step Zero (Air off) to make the actuator perform a new homing. This does not work if the machine is already in a volume change sequence.
    

### 110304131 / 110304141 / 110304132, Volume Change, Horizontal Cylinder in Wrong Position

**Description**

On volume change, the volume change cylinder moves the volume washer in or out from the cassette. There are two sensors that detect the end positions, one for inner and one for the outer position.

**Condition for Alarm**

It takes longer than 2.5seconds to change from inner to outer position and vice versa.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the air cylinder is not leaking air. See Procedure [5.11.1-2 Volume Change Mechanism - Check Cylinder](#section1492).
    
*   Check that the volume washer is not broken.
    
*   Check that nothing is obstructing the way.
    
*   Check and set the volume change. See Procedure [5.11.1-3 Volume Change Mechanism – Set](#section1493).
    
*   Check that the cassettes are mounted in the correct direction and that no cassettes are broken.
    

### 110304351 / 110304352, Packages Infeed into Cassette Failed

**Description**

When the sleeve enters the cassette, the cassette centring secures the cassette in a position aligned with the sleeve. This ensures that the sleeve moves all the way into cassette.

There is a fibre optic sensor, mounted on the infeed hatches, which has one sender and one receiver. This sensor detects if the package fail to go all the way into the cassette.

**Condition for Alarm**

The package is not properly placed in the cassette.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check that the centering of the cassette stabilisers works smoothly and is correctly set. See Section [5.6.4.1-1 Cassette Centring](#section1402).
    
*   Check the lugs for wear and that the cylinder is not leaking air. Change if necessary. See Procedure [5.6.4.1-4 Cassette Centring – Overhaul](#section1406).
    
*   If the machine is equipped with a **CAU**, check the alignment between the capping station and the cassette. See Procedure [4.4.5-3 Capping Station - Set to Package Section](#section1049).
    
*   Check that the stripper fingers are straight and not damaged. Check the **CAU** stripper and set if necessary. See Procedure [4.4.4-1 CAU Stripper – Set](#section1044).
    
*   Check for tilted caps that could obstruct the package movement.
    
*   Check the fibre optic on the cleaning hatches. Set according to relevant volume. See Procedure [Doors - Set Fibre Optic Sensor](#section1444).
    
*   Check the sleeve size according to specification. See Section [2.4.3-1 Sleeve Forming Unit - Check Size for Sleeve](#section400).
    
*   Check that the **LFU** stripper is moving the package out from the mandrel straight.
    
*   Check the top of the package. If the top of the package has collapsed, check and set the lid blowing. See Procedure [3.14.4-2 Pneumatic Pressures LFU - Set](#section917).
    
*   If the machine is equipped with the Micro Bridge Twist, check the guide unit. See Procedure [5.6.11-1 Steering - Check Guide Unit in Pre-folder](#section1440).
    
*   Check the home position of the cassette conveyor. If necessary, set homing. See Procedure [5.7.6-1 Drive Unit - Homing](#section1458).
    

### 110312481 / 110312482, Gas Dosing, Wrong Pressure

**Description**

Some products will be affected by oxygen in the head-space of the package. Vitamins, colour and taste can be affected. If the oxygen level is reduced, from the normal 21% to about 8-10%, the shelf life of the product can be increased considerably. The gas dosing system does that by replacing the oxygen in the head-space with substitute gas.

Gas at 4-6bar passes from the supply unit, through a connection at the filling platform, to a valve block in the front of the machine. The valves switch between gas dosing and compressed air. A proportional valve reduces the gas pressure to the value that is set in the **PLC**. This is about 2.5bar during production.

The valves will be switching on and off during production.

**Condition for Alarm**

The gas dosing pressure is outside the **PLC** limits.

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check the manometers in the front of the machine.
    
*   Check that the valves switch fast enough between on and off.
    
*   Check that the gas dosing valves work properly.
    

### 110304050, Air Supply and Pressure to the Safety Valve

**Troubleshooting**

*   Make sure that the air pressure is set correctly on the main ramp. See Procedure 6.6.1-1 Pneumatic Supply - Set Pressure (Festo, Mecman), in the MM.
    
*   Make sure that the manual valve before the safety valve is open. See Procedure Safety Air Valve - Description.
    
*   Make sure that the manometer on the safety air valve shows at least 6bar. If it shows < 3bar, there is an air leakage problem, and the safety air valve will not fully pressurise the system. Check for air leakage.
    
*   If the safety air valve shows 6 bar, there should be a signal from the pressure guard. Check the electrical connection to the pressure guard and the Point I/O input. The pressure guard is factory set and should normally not be adjusted.
    

### Safety Air Valve - Description

#### General

The following table describes the functions performed by the [Safety air valve](#SafetyAirValvesafetyAirValve-CFFE0D9D).

Machine status

Phase

Function performed by the [Safety air valve](#SafetyAirValvesafetyAirValve-CFFE0D9D)

Comment

Air on

1

The pneumatic system is exhausted of all air.

2

The pneumatic system is pressurised to 50% of the incoming pressure

If the air pressure is impeded by leakage in the system, the [Safety air valve](#SafetyAirValvesafetyAirValve-CFFE0D9D) will not continue to phase 3

3

The pneumatic system is pressurised to 100% of the incoming pressure

air off

Exhaust

The pneumatic system is quickly exhausted of all air

This function is also performed if an emergency stop is actuated, or if a door is opened

The [Manual open/close valve](#ManualOpencloseValvemanualOpenclose-CFFDF400) is normally in the open position.

Bottom Sealing
--------------

### Functional Description

1.  [Lifting unit](#LiftingUnitLiftingUnit-CF466384) that lifts the cassette, the filled package, the cassette stabilizer and the volume displacement cylinders. This unit is driven by a [Servomotor](#Servomotorservomotor-CF467580) and a [Belt drive](#BeltDrivebeltDrive-CF468690).
    
2.  [Sealing unit](#SealingUnitSealingUnit-CF466E18) with a knee mechanism that moves the [US-horn](#US-hornUS-horn-CF468FC7) and the [Anvil](#Anvilanvil-CF46979D) and assures the sealing by a pneumatic spring force. This unit is driven by a [Servomotor](#Servomotorservomotor-CF469ECA) and a [Ball screw](#BallScrewballScrew-CF46A514).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000326785.png)

*   Lifting unit
*   Servomotor
*   Belt drive

*   Sealing unit
*   **US**\-horn
*   Anvil

*   Servomotor
*   Ball screw

### Knee Mechanism of the Sealing Unit

The [Ball screw](#BallScrewballScrew-CF487A0A) is driving a linear guided [Yoke](#Yokeyoke-CF4991B7) in vertical direction. To make the linear jaw movement between the anvil and the US-horns, the yoke is linked with [Link arm](#LinkArmlinkArms-CF499CE5) to:

*   a horizontal linear unit to drive the [Anvil](#Anvilanvil-CF49CBAD)
    
*   one linear unit with [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CF49DF00) and [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CF49E4C6),
    
*   one [Overtravel carriage](#OvertravelCarriageovertravelCarriag-CF49F6B3) to drive the **US**\-horns.
    

The knee mechanism unit is fixed to the frame with [Linear bearing](#LinearBearinglinearBearings-CF4A087D) and [Linear bearing](#LinearBearinglinearBearings-CF4A10D3).

The movements are shown in the illustration below.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000250820.png)

*   Link arm
*   Anvil

*   Pneumatic spring carriage

### Folding

During the dwell time of the cassette conveyer, the folding and sealing take place. A synchronized movement of the lifter and knee mechanism makes the folding. This combined movement follows a predicted [Folding curve](#FoldingCurvefoldingCurve-CF4A69A5).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000155803.png)

*   Folding curve

The diagram below shows the whole sequence of the cassette conveyer index, cassette lifter and knee mechanism.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000377910.png)

*   Seal

*   Conveyor index

### Sealing Functionality

The [US-horn](#US-hornUS-horns-CFAC0BBB) are clamped with a [Mechanical joint](#MechanicalJointmechanicalJoint-CFAC4369) to [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CFAC1707) and [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CFAC1AC9) which can move independently from each other. On these pneumatic spring carriages there are four [Pneumatic membrane](#PneumaticMembranepneumaticMembranes-CFAC2065) that are always pressurized with the setting from a [Regulator](#Regulatorregulator-CFAC738D). The membranes are pressing against the [Overtravel carriage](#OvertravelCarriageovertravelCarriag-CFAC24A1).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000155831.png)

*   US-horn
*   Mechanical joint

*   Pneumatic spring carriage
*   Pneumatic spring carriage

*   Pneumatic membrane
*   Regulator

*   Overtravel carriage

The three carriages move together as a group. When the knee mechanism is moving down, the force is almost infinite when the [Link](#Linklink-CFAC7C93) reaches its nearly straight position. At this point the mechanism reaches an end point due to that the distance between the anvil and **US**\-horns is zero. This is basic setting for the end point of the servomotor.

When the folded package is squeezed between the [Anvil](#Anvilanvil-CFAC823B) and the [US-horn](#US-hornUS-horns-CFAC0BBB) there will be a distance D of 0.4 mm compressed paperboard. The [Overtravel carriage](#OvertravelCarriageovertravelCarriag-CFAC24A1) moves then into the [Pneumatic membrane](#PneumaticMembranepneumaticMembranes-CFAC2065) leaving a distance E of 0.35 mm in-between the [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CFAC1707) and [Pneumatic spring carriage](#PneumaticSpringCarriagepneumaticSpr-CFAC1AC9) and the [Overtravel carriage](#OvertravelCarriageovertravelCarriag-CFAC24A1). The force in the system is now set to the pneumatic pressure in the membranes and the sealing pulse can be performed.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000155830.png)

D = 0.4 mm

E = 0.35 mm

*   US-horn
*   Pneumatic spring carriage

*   Pneumatic spring carriage
*   Pneumatic membrane

*   Overtravel carriage
*   Link

*   Anvil

### Seals - Change

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  If mounted, remove the [Anvil](#Anvilanvil-D030DAD5).
    
2.  Lubricate the inner surface of the seals. The inner surface is lubricated to avoid noise from the rods during production.
    
3.  Fit [Seal](#Sealseals-D030F478) and [Seal](#Sealseals-D030FE7B).
    
4.  Turn the outer [Shaft](#Shaftshafts-8DA56959) by 10°.
    
5.  The function of the two outer [Seal](#Sealseals-D030F478) is to tighten inwards (to prevent oil to leak out from the bottom sealing house into the hygienic chamber).
    
6.  The function of the three [Seal](#Sealseals-D030FE7B) in the middle is to tighten outwards (to prevent cleaning solution to leak into the bottom sealing house).
    
7.  Hence, the seals are to be fit differently, in accordance with the illustration.
    
8.  Fit the [Sonotrode holder](#SonotrodeHoldersonotrodeHolders-D0310829).
    
9.  Put the [Anvil](#Anvilanvil-D030DAD5) back, and thereafter, tighten the seals by their covers.
    
10.  Fit the sonotrodes and set according to [Sonotrode and Anvil - Set (Align)](#section1263).

### Sonotrode - Turn

Equipment Status

Program Step Step Zero

Special Equipment

Tool TP No. 3601927-0000  
Torque wrench, 1/2" (>220Nm)

Consumables

Penetrating Lubricant

1.  Make sure to know which version is installed in your machine. See [Converter - Description](#section1260)
    

2.  Remove the converter from the machine and put the converter in a vice.
    
3.  Remove the [Bolt](#Boltbolt-6334990D) and the [Folding plate](#FoldingPlatefoldingPlate-804142B5).

*   Folding plate

Risk of damage to the equipment.

Do not use a hammer on the [Ring](#Ringring-63B5EB1E). The impacts can damage the ceramic discs inside the converter.

5.  Check the holes on the [Ring](#Ringring-63B5EB1E). If the holes are worn, perform item [Reference](UseADrillingMachineWithADrillTheSam-6350C891). If the holes are in good condition, perform item [Reference](UsePenetratingLubricantBetweenTheAn-AA6563A1).

Risk of damage to the equipment.

Always use penetrating lubricant on the threads.

Both the [Ring](#Ringring-63B5EB1E) and the [Converter](#Converterconverter-A6B4FE84) are made of stainless steel and can easily seize.

7.  Use penetrating lubricant between the [Converter](#Converterconverter-A6B4FE84) and the [Ring](#Ringring-63B5EB1E).

### Filters - Check

Equipment Status

Power must be turn ON.  
Air must be turn ON.  
Steam must be turn ON.  
Water must be turn ON.  

1.  Check the [Particle filter](#ParticleFilterparticleFilter-5F32C69F). If the [Particle filter](#ParticleFilterparticleFilter-5F32C69F) is clogged, it must be replaced.

3.  Make sure that the arrows on the filters point in the direction of the air flow.

Program Step

### Lower Cassette Lift - Overhaul

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  Remove the [O-ring](#O-ringO-rings-D1BB65C1) and [Seal](#Sealseals-D1BB56D3), [Ball bushing](#BallBushingballBushings-D1BB708A), [Rubber ring](#RubberRingrubberRing-D1BB7B5A), and the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D1BB83D7), see illustration next page.
    
    **Note:** Be careful not to damage the cylinder housing when removing the [Ball bushing](#BallBushingballBushings-D1BB708A), see illustration next page.

    Sharp tools can damage the [Seal](#Sealseals-D1BB56D3) and cause leaks.
    
    Fit the [Seal](#Sealseals-D1BB56D3) in the [Ring](#Ringring-D1BB9765) according to the illustration. Squeeze the seals by hand to make them enter the grooves in the lid. Then push the seals to the correct position by the aid of a suitable pen or similar.
    
5.  At reassembling, check that the [Oil channel](#OilChanneloilChannel-D1BB8F76) in the column matches the [Oil channel](#OilChanneloilChannel-D1BBA49D) in the flange.

Cassette Lifter, Centring
-------------------------

### Cassette Lifter, Centring - Set Height and Centring

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  Inch the machine to a sector value between 300 and 800
    
2.  On Mecman machines, force the valves G50K1220 (S1), and G50K2220 (S2). On Festo machines, use the air service tool. See [Air Service Tool Description](#section2113).
    
3.  Adjust the **height** of the centred cassette by loosening the [Lock nut](#LockNutlockNut-D1D1CF86) and turning the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-D1D1D85A). Adjust so that the cassette is just touching the [Rail](#Railrails-D1D1DEBF), then turn the piston half a revolution more (to increase the contact pressure). Tighten the [Lock nut](#LockNutlockNut-D1D1CF86).
    
4.  Run some packages through the machine, and check if the transversal seal lines up.
    
5.  If the transversal seal is unaligned in the way that illustration **A** shows, adjust the seal by loosening the [Screw](#Screwscrew-D1D1E597) and moving the [Centring](#Centringcentring-D1D1ECF6) in the direction of arrow **A**.
    
6.  If the transversal seal is unaligned in the way that illustration **B** shows, adjust the seal by loosening the [Screw](#Screwscrew-D1D1E597) and moving the [Centring](#Centringcentring-D1D1ECF6) in the direction of arrow **B**.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001647630.png)

*   Lock nut
*   Piston

*   Rail
*   Screw

*   Centring

After the centring procedure:

8.  On Mecman machines, force the valves G50K1220 (S1), and G50K2220 (S2). On Festo machines, use the air service tool. See [Air Service Tool Description](#section2113).
    
9.  Check that there is a gap **X**, in the conveyor, on both sides of the entered cassette. If there is no gap, adjust using shims (see items[Reference](LoosenTheAndAdjustItWith1MmShimsTPN-D6389DAE) to [Reference](TightenTheRearYoke.-D638A661)).
    
10.  Loosen the [Rear yoke](#RearYokerearYoke-D1D20510), and adjust it with 1 mm shims (TP No 2673458) between the [Tie rods](#TieRodstieRods-D1D20C9F) and the [Rear yoke](#RearYokerearYoke-D1D20510).
    
11.  Tighten the rear yoke.
    
12.  Set the anvil and sonotrodes according to Procedure [Sonotrode and Anvil - Set (Align)](#section1263).

Basic settings
--------------

### Basic Settings Bottom Seal

Cells containing hyphen (**\-**) refers to a setting when the configuration exists, but no value is set.

Cells with grey background refer to a setting in which the configuration does not exist.

Italic text refers to a setting that has not been verified, but are based on verified settings from similar configurations.

Designations /ml, /ml-H, /ml-H+, /pbl, /jl, /jl MF, /aqk and /lk indicate different packaging material specifications.

The letters **T** and **P** indicate settings for pulse time (ms) respectively for the pressure (bar).

**Valid for:** CLC/C Duplex board

Bottom format

Board stiffness (mN)

### Sealing Pressure Regulators - Set

Equipment Status

Air must be turn ON.  

1.  To decrease sealing pressure, turn the hand wheel counter-clockwise.
    
    **Note:** When decreasing pressure, it is necessary to turn approximately 0.4 bar below the estimated value, and then up again to the value.
    
2.  To increase sealing pressure, turn the hand wheel clockwise.
    
3.  Basic setting: choose the same pressure reading for both [Pressure regulators](#PressureRegulatorspressureRegulator-99E671AF) one pressure regulator for each subside of the machine).
    
4.  At production, fine tune each side after checking the sealing quality.
    
    **Note:** During manufacturing and assembling of converters and sonotrodes, there is always a difference in the amplitude movement of the unit. This means that the air pressure regulators for the sealing pressure may have to be set individually between the subunit to create the same energy so that a good sealing can be produced. The energy values can be shown on the TPOP monitoring window.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0003575493.png)

*   Pressure regulators

    **Note:** The energy values can be shown on the TPOP monitoring window.

### Protective Air Pressure Regulator and Pressure Sensor - Set

1.  Set the air [Pressure sensor](#PressureSensorpressureSensor-62B37D00).
    
    **Note:** Pressure guard display has to be in Run mode. When pushing the [Arrow up](#ArrowUpArrowUp-62B3722B) button you can see the settings for SP Switching pressure and HY Hysteresis.

Changes will be saved when pushing [Edit button](#EditButtoneditButton-62B39511) for a new setting window. The display will go back to `Run` mode after the last setting window. The following table describes the [Pressure sensor](#PressureSensorpressureSensor-62B37D00) menu.

Final Folder

### Functional Description

The function of the final folder unit is to fold the transversal seal, form it to flaps and seal them to the bottom of the package to make the package stand steadily.

Program Step

Burn hazard.

Allow the nozzles to cool down before starting any work on them.

The flap sealing nozzles are very hot when in operation and can cause severe burns.

Outfeed Unit
------------

### Functional Description

The function of the discharger unit is to pull the packages from the cassettes and place them on the conveyor chain. Packages with unsealed flaps are detected by a photocell (in the machine body), and ejected away.

### UV-lamp

Safety hazard.

Read and follow the safety precautions carefully before starting any work on the UV-lamp.

There are several safety hazards involved when working with the UV-lamp.

### Functional Description

The **UV**\-lamp system consists of two **UV**\-lamp units and their cooling system (one on each side of machine side).

The combination of peroxide and **UV**\-radiation effectively disinfects the surface of the packaging material.

In order to reduce heat, the **UV**\-lamp is cooled by a [Venting fan](#VentingFanventingFan-D34A58C5), which sucks air through the [Lamp housing](#LampHousinglampHousing-D34A5D84).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002747703.png)

*   Venting fan

*   Temperature sensor

*   Lamp housing

The cooling capacity (speed of venting fan) is controlled by the [Temperature sensor](#TemperatureSensortemperatureSensor-D34A24B3) and a frequency converter. The optimal cooling air temperature is 55 °C. (The cooling temperature is permanently preset. It is not necessary to check or adjust it.)

**Illumination of the hygiene chamber by UV light:**

The **UV** light has an additional function [Illumination by UV light](#IlluminationByUVLightilluminationBy-D34C8C83), which can be used to illuminate the hygiene chamber for approximately 10 minutes. The **UV** lamp will be extinguished (goes immediately out) under alarm conditions or upon opening of a door.

To prevent overheating of the package cassettes, the lamp will only work during the program steps MOTOR RUNNING, PRODUCTION, END PRODUCTION, and when the machine is performing a VOLUME CHANGE.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156013.png)

*   **UV** lightIllumination by

### UV Meter - Set Offset

To get a correct measurement of the UV-lamp intensity it is important that the offset of the sensor is correctly set. The offset needs to be set when a new sensor is used or if the intensity not is 0.00 mW/cm2.

Equipment Status

Power must be turn ON.  

Special Equipment

UV-meter TP No. 90459-3591

If the value **E** on the **UV**\-meter is anything other than 0.00, follow items [Reference](PressTheUntilTheIsInFrontOfAdjustOf-281E4204) to [Reference](PressThe.-281E5AE0).

If the value is 0.00, go to Procedure [UV-lamp - Check Intensity](#section1371)

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001849252.png)

#### Prepare UV-meter

The following equipment is required:

[UV-meter](#UV-meterUV-meter-29A43F4B), [Lid for UV-sensor holder](#LidForUV-sensorHolderlid-29A44A04), [UV-sensor](#UV-sensorUV-sensor-29A45173), and [Sensor holder](#SensorHoldersensorHolder-29A45E3A).

1.  Make sure the **UV**\-meter has fresh batteries; otherwise, the measurements will be incorrect. The **UV**\-meter is to be calibrated once a year by the agency of the manufacturer.
    
2.  Make sure that the serial number of the **UV**\-sensor is the same as the one on the **UV**\-meter. The **UV**\-sensor and **UV**\-meter are calibrated together and must be used together.
    
3.  Clean the [UV-sensor](#UV-sensorUV-sensor-29A45173) using a soft lint-free cloth and alcoholic solution (Isopropanol 70%). See [Chemicals for Cleaning and Disinfection](#section2117).

### UV-Lamp - Check Power

Equipment Status

Program Step HEATING

Special Equipment

Digital Multimeter with True RMS (TRMS)  
Digital Current Clamp Meter with True RMS (TRMS)

1.  Make sure that the **UV**\-lamp is on and that the shutter is open. See [UV-lamp - Check Intensity](#section1371). Check items d to j.
    
2.  In the **UV**\-side of the electrical cabinet, measure the voltage of the **UV**\-lamp on the [Terminal Plinth](#TerminalPlinthV51X0232terminalPlint-C7CC989C) V51X0232, between terminal 1 and 2 for side1 and 11 and 12 for side2. See Chapter 3 Circuit Diagram in the Electrical Manual. Note the voltage.
    
    There is a natural variation in voltage between different **UV**\-lamps.
    
3.  Attach the clamp around the cable from terminal 1,or 11 depending on which side you are working on, and measure the current to the UV-lamp. Note the current.
    
    There is a natural variation in current between different **UV**\-lamps due to voltage variation.

    Lower power results in lower **UV** intensity.
    
    Normal range in 4 kW mode
    
    Normal range in 5 kW mode
    
    Voltage
    
    270 to 300 V
    
    280 to 310 V
    
    Current
    
    15 to 17 A
    
    19 to 20 A
    
    Power
    
    4 400 to 4 800 VA
    
    5 500 to 6 000 VA

    **Note:** The current to the UV-lamp must not be over 20A at 5kW (the fuse for the UV-lamp is 20A).

### UV-lamp House - Remove Internal Armature

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

Burn hazard.

Allow the **UV**\-lamp and the surrounding parts to cool down before starting any work on them.

The **UV**\-lamp and the surrounding parts can be hot.

Hazardous voltage.

The circuits of the **UV**\-lamp can contain residual voltage even after the power is turned off. Make sure that the electrical supply disconnecting device is turned off and secured with a lock and that you do the correct short circuit procedure, before starting any work on the **UV**\-lamp.

Will shock, burn, or cause death.

1.  Set the electrical supply disconnecting device in positionO. Wait at least five minutes before you continue to work with the **UV**\-lamp.
    
2.  Remove the [Hepa box](#HepaBoxhepaBox-F1D54D97) by loosening the [Screw](#Screwscrew-F1D55673).
    
3.  Put the [Hepa box](#HepaBoxhepaBox-F1D54D97) on a suitable working area.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004490003.png)

*   Hepa box
*   Screw
*   UV-lamp housing

4.  Remove the two pneumatic [Hose](#Hosehoses-D3661B56) connected to the [UV-lamp housing](#UV-lampHousingUV-lampHousing-FE2D48CF).
    
5.  Move the [Cable hose](#CableHosecableHoses-D3662D5B) from the machine body over the hygiene chamber, and place them so they easily can be pulled through the cable gland.
    
6.  Loosen the counter nuts on the cable gland in the wall.
    
7.  Pull the [Cable hose](#CableHosecableHoses-D3662D5B) through the cable gland in the wall, from the carton section into the hygiene chamber.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004500413.png)

*   UV-lamp housing
*   Hose
*   Cable hose

8.  Loosen the eight end plate [Screw](#Screwscrews-D3663855) and washers that secure the [Lamp insert](#LampInsertlampInsert-D3663DF6) to the [UV-lamp housing](#UV-lampHousingUV-lampHousing-FE2D48CF).
    
9.  Pull out the [Lamp insert](#LampInsertlampInsert-D3663DF6) about 50 mm from the [UV-lamp housing](#UV-lampHousingUV-lampHousing-FE2D48CF).
    
10.  Disconnect the [Earth connection](#EarthConnectionearthConnection-D36654E3) between the [End plate](#EndPlateendPlate-D3665AEE) and [UV-lamp housing](#UV-lampHousingUV-lampHousing-FE2D48CF).
    
11.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    Handle the internal armature with care.
    
    Collisions will cause premature failure of the UV-lamp.
    
    Carefully place the internal armature on a suitable working area.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004500412.png)

*   UV-lamp housing
*   Screw
*   Lamp insert
*   Earth connection
*   End plate

12.  Set a voltage tester (or multimeter) to AC voltage and a range above 400 V.
    
13.  Hold the [Test probes](#VoltageMetervoltageMeter-089B58D9) against the [Phase terminal](#PhaseTerminalphaseTerminal-089C7772) and the [Phase terminal](#PhaseTerminalphaseTerminal-13213-089C7772) to drain the capacitor.

### UV-lamp House - Change Hose

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

Consumables

Alcoholic Solution (Ethanol 70% or similar)

Burn hazard.

Allow the UV-lamp and the surrounding parts to cool down before starting any work on them.

The UV-lamp and the surrounding parts can be hot.

Hazardous voltage.

The circuits of the UV-lamp can contain residual voltage even after the power is turned off. Make sure that the electrical supply disconnecting device is turned off and secured with a lock and that you do the correct short circuit procedure, before starting any work on the UV-lamp.

Will shock, burn, or cause death.

1.  Remove the internal armature of the UV-lamp house by following Procedure [UV-lamp House - Remove Internal Armature](#section1388).
    
    **Note:** Remove the markings on the hoses and save them for later.
    

2.  Disconnect the [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5), the [Electrical cables](#ElectricalCableselectricalCables-0600E1D8) and the [Cable gland](#CableGlandcableGland-060120CB) from the [UV-lamp house](#UV-lampHouseUV-lampHouse-0600F2D0).
    
3.  Pull out the straight pipe insert from the [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004521123.png)

*   Hose
*   Electrical cables
*   Cable gland
*   UV-lamp house

4.  Disconnect the [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5) from the [Cable gland splice](#CableGlandSplicecableGlandSplice-06017673).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004521122.png)

*   Hose
*   Cable gland splice

5.  Pull off the hose. Make sure that no markings on the [Electrical cables](#ElectricalCableselectricalCables-0600E1D8) fall off.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004521121.png)

*   Electrical cables

6.  Cut the new hose to the same length as the old.
    
7.  Pull the new [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5) on the electrical cables and connect it to the [Cable gland splice](#CableGlandSplicecableGlandSplice-06017673).
    
    **Note:** If needed, spray alcoholic solution (Ethanol 70% or similar) inside the hose to reduce friction.
    
8.  Tighten the [Cable gland splice](#CableGlandSplicecableGlandSplice-06017673) in both ends.
    
9.  Repeat items b) to h) for the second hose.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004521122.png)

*   Hose
*   Cable gland splice

10.  Assemble the straight pipe insert into the end of the hose. Pull the electrical cables through the insert.
    
    **Note:** If needed, spray alcoholic solution (Ethanol 70% or similar) inside the hose to reduce friction.
    
11.  Pull the [Electrical cables](#ElectricalCableselectricalCables-0600E1D8) and the [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5) through the [Cable gland](#CableGlandcableGland-060120CB) into the [UV-lamp house](#UV-lampHouseUV-lampHouse-0600F2D0).
    
12.  Make sure that the insert is flush with the hose end (see arrow in illustration).
    
13.  Connect the [Electrical cables](#ElectricalCableselectricalCables-0600E1D8).
    
14.  Assemble the markings on the [Hose](#Hosehose-0600D6A5).
    
15.  Repeat items j) to n) for the second hose.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004521120.png)

*   Hose
*   Electrical cables
*   Cable gland
*   UV-lamp house

16.  Assemble the UV-lamp house by following Procedure [UV-lamp House - Remove Internal Armature](#section1388) in reverse order.

Replace Switch V51B1247/ V51B2247.

Cables to UV lamp V51E1224/V51E2224 not connected correctly

Connect cables according to the **EM**.

Adjust current relay V51R0002/V51R0003. See Procedure [Current Control Relay - Set](#section1784).

Current relay V51R0002/V51R0003 malfunctions

Replace relay V51R0002/V51R0003.

Photocell Unit
--------------

### Functional Description

The unit is correctly adjusted when the **LED**s on the photocells light up

When the green lamp lights up there is contact between the transmitter and the receiver.

When the red lamp lights up an object is being indicated between the transmitter and the receiver.

### Photocell Unit - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  To check the [Upper photocell](#UpperPhotocellupperPhotocell-D3D48C98), use tape to fasten a piece of packaging material in front of the upper photocell, and then run the machine.
    
2.  This should trigger a stop alarm from the out-feed unit.
    
3.  To check the [Lower photocell](#LowerPhotocelllowerPhotocell-D3D49314), use tape to fasten a piece of packaging material in front of the lower photocell, run two packages through the machine, and make sure they are thrown out.
    
4.  Remove the tape and clean the cover windows with alcoholic liquid.

*   Lower photocell

### Diaphragm Valve - Change Diaphragm

Equipment Status

Program Step

#### Remove Actuator

1.  If the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) is in the closed position, move it to the open position.
    
2.  Remove the [Bolt](#Boltbolts-DE8D3995) and the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553).
    
3.  Move the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) to the closed position.
    

#### Remove Diaphragm

1.  Unscrew the old [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-DE94C68F) and remove it.
    
2.  Clean the parts of the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553).
    
3.  Make sure that no parts of the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) are damaged.
    
4.  Replace any damaged parts.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000710387.png)

*   Actuator
*   Bolt
*   Diaphragm

#### Install Diaphragm

1.  Place the [Compressor](#Compressorcompressor-DE9EFDB2) loosely on the actuator [spindle](#Spindlespindle-DE9F01D2) and fit the [Groove](#Groovegrooves-DE9F053C) onto the [Guide](#Guideguides-DE9F07F2).
    
2.  Make sure that the [Compressor](#Compressorcompressor-DE9EFDB2) fits closely in the [Guide](#Guideguides-DE9F07F2).
    
3.  Tightly screw the new [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-DE94C68F) into the [Compressor](#Compressorcompressor-DE9EFDB2).
    
4.  Make sure that the [Diaphragm boss](#DiaphragmBossdiaphragmBoss-DE9F84DB) fits closely in the recesses of the [Compressor](#Compressorcompressor-DE9EFDB2).
    
5.  When you feel a clear resistance, turn the [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-DE94C68F) counter-clockwise until the bolt holes of the [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-DE94C68F) is in alignment with the bolt holes of the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553).
    

#### Install Actuator

1.  Move the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) to the open position.
    
2.  Put the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) back on the valve body.
    
3.  Install the [Bolt](#Boltbolts-DE8D3995) and tighten them by hand.
    
4.  Move the [Actuator](#Actuatoractuator-DE8D1553) to the closed position.
    
5.  Fully and evenly tighten the [Bolt](#Boltbolts-DE8D3995) until the rubber has been compressed by 10-15%.

### Pump Unit - Set the Impeller in the Return Pump

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

1.  Remove the [Impeller](#Impellerimpeller-D3D67913), the [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-D3D68A90) with the [Adaptor](#Adaptoradaptor-D3D69222) without moving the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3D69FF4) on the [Motor shaft](#MotorShaftmotorShaft-D3D6ABFC).
    
2.  Torque tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrews-D3D6B48A) carefully to **15 Nm**, counter hold the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3D69FF4).
    
3.  Fit the [Thrower](#Throwerthrower-D3D6BBC4) on the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3D69FF4). Fit the [Adaptor](#Adaptoradaptor-D3D69222) together with the [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-D3D68A90) on the motor.
    
4.  Fit [Washer](#Washerwashers-D3D6C2E5) and [Screw](#Screwscrews-D3D6C944).

### Pump Unit - Clean the Screen Gasket

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

Special Equipment

Tool TP No. 90458-0248

Consumables

Alkali solution (Manual Cleaning)

Hot parts.

Before service, make sure that the pump and pipes are cool before performing this procedure.

The pump and the pipelines can cause burn damages.

Remaining hazardous media.

Use protective safety equipment: safety glasses, protective gloves and an apron.

The pump and the pipes between the pump and the **TTCU** can contain hazardous media under pressure.

3.  Carefully open the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-D3D6F78A) and let the media to flow out slowly.
    
4.  Remove the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-D3D6F78A).
    
5.  Move the [Pipe](#Pipepipe-D3D70012) to the side and remove the [Strainer gasket](#StrainerGasketstrainerGasket-14BE9EBF).
    
6.  Clean the [Strainer gasket](#StrainerGasketstrainerGasket-14BE9EBF) carefully with cleaning solution and a brush. A damaged [Strainer gasket](#StrainerGasketstrainerGasket-14BE9EBF) must be replaced. Rinse the [Strainer gasket](#StrainerGasketstrainerGasket-14BE9EBF) thoroughly with water.
    
7.  Install in the reverse order.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156109.png)

*   Clamp
*   Pipe
*   Strainer gasket

### Pump Unit - Dismantle the Return Pump

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

Special Equipment

Tool TP No. 90458-0248

Remaining hazardous media.

Before service, make sure that the pump and the pipes are drained and pressureless. Use protective safety equipment: safety glasses, protective gloves, apron, and respirator with gas vapour filters.

The system could contain hazardous media under pressure.

Hot parts.

Before service, make sure that the pump and pipes are cool before performing this procedure.

The pump and the pipelines can cause burn damages.

3.  Disconnect the pump from the piping in the connection points.

7.  Turn the [Stationary seal ring](#StationarySealRingstationarySealRin-D3D99E74) clockwise using the [Tool](#Tooltool-D3D9C606) to remove it from the [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-D3D94557).

### Pump Unit - Overhaul Valve

Equipment Status

Air must be turn OFF.  
Program Step STEP ZERO

Consumables

Silicone grease: TP No. 344477-0000

1.  Remove the four [Bolt](#Boltbolts-D3E2D3CB) and the [Cover plate](#CoverPlatecoverPlate-D3E2EB3B).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156103.png)

*   Bolt
*   Cover plate

2.  Disconnect the [Proximity switch](#ProximitySwitchproximitySwitch-D3E308FB) and the [Air connection](#AirConnectionairConnection-D3E31149) from the [Valve](#Valvevalve-D3E33894).
    
3.  Disconnect the [Valve](#Valvevalve-D3E33894) at the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-D3E3597B).
    
4.  Open the [Clamp](#Clampclamps-D3E370D8) and remove the [Valve](#Valvevalve-D3E33894) from the machine.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156142.png)

*   Proximity switch
*   Air connection
*   Valve
*   Connection
*   Clamp

5.  Risk of crushing.
    
    Be careful when working on the valve so that you will not crush your fingers if the air pressure in the valve releases.
    
    The [Valve](#Valvevalve-D3E33894) contains a spring that will close the valve if it is not being held open by compressed air.
    
    Remove the lower [Clamp](#Clampclamp-D3E38D0C) and the [Lower valve body](#LowerValveBodylowerValveBody-D3E39E2A).
    
6.  Supply compressed air through the [Air connection](#AirConnectionairConnection-D3E31149) until the [Valve plug](#ValvePlugvalvePlug-D3E3B39D) releases from the [Seat](#Seatseat-D3E3C6BB). Do not release the compressed air until told to do so.
    
7.  Loosen and remove the [Valve plug](#ValvePlugvalvePlug-D3E3B39D) and the [Seat](#Seatseat-D3E3C6BB).
    
8.  Release the compressed air.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156141.png)

*   Air connection
*   Clamp

*   Lower valve body
*   Valve plug

*   Seat

9.  Remove the [Upper clamp](#UpperClampuUpperClamp-D3E3DC34) and the [Upper valve body](#UpperValveBodyupperValveBody-D3E3EDD2).
    
10.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    Be careful when removing the bushing (14).
    
    The bushing (14) will be reused and it can be damaged when it is removed.
    
    Remove the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E4226C), the [Lip seal](#LipSeallipSeal-D3E42F59), and the [Bushing](#Bushingbushing-D3E3FFB3) from the [Bonnet](#Bonnetbonnet-D3E43ADF). Use a bushing tool and a rubber mallet to remove the [Bushing](#Bushingbushing-D3E3FFB3).
    
11.  Install a new [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E4226C) and a new [Lip seal](#LipSeallipSeal-D3E42F59).
    
12.  Install the [Bushing](#Bushingbushing-D3E3FFB3).
    
13.  Carefully remove the [Plug seal](#PlugSealplugSeals-D3E44612) from the [Valve plug](#ValvePlugvalvePlug-D3E3B39D).
    
14.  Carefully install the new [Plug seal](#PlugSealplugSeals-D3E44612) in the grooves by applying pressure on opposite points on the [Plug seal](#PlugSealplugSeals-D3E44612).
    
15.  Make sure that any air trapped behind the [Plug seal](#PlugSealplugSeals-D3E44612) is released.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156140.png)

*   Upper clamp
*   Upper valve body

*   Bushing
