*   Lip seal
*   Bonnet

*   Plug seal

16.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    Do not overtighten the bushings (19).
    
    If you overtighten the bushings (19) you will damage the O-rings.
    
    Loosen and remove the two [Bushing](#Bushingbushings-D3E454C2).
    
17.  Replace the [O-ring](#O-ringO-rings-D3E45F55), the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E46A56), and the two [Bushing](#Bushingbushings-D3E454C2). Lubricate the O-rings before replacing them.
    
18.  Replace the [O-ring](#O-ringO-rings-D3E4726A) on the [Seat](#Seatseat-D3E3C6BB) with new ones.
    
19.  Install the [Upper valve body](#UpperValveBodyupperValveBody-D3E3EDD2) with the [Upper clamp](#UpperClampuUpperClamp-D3E3DC34).
    
20.  Supply compressed air through the [Air connection](#AirConnectionairConnection-D3E31149) until the [Valve plug](#ValvePlugvalvePlug-D3E3B39D) can be fully screwed on and then screw it on.
    
21.  Release the compressed air.
    
22.  Install the [Lower valve body](#LowerValveBodylowerValveBody-D3E39E2A) with the lower [Clamp](#Clampclamp-D3E38D0C).

24.  Connect the [Valve](#Valvevalve-D3E33894) at the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-D3E3597B).

26.  Install the [Cover plate](#CoverPlatecoverPlate-D3E2EB3B) with the [Bolt](#Boltbolts-D3E2D3CB).

### Pump Unit - Assemble the Return Pump

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.  

Special Equipment

Tool: TP No. 90458-0248

Consumables

Silicone grease: TP No. 344477-0000

1.  Lubricate the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E552BC) and push it on the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3E55F02) and position it correctly. Place the [Spring](#Springspring-D3E6766F) on the rotating seal ring (4).
    
2.  Push the [Rotating seal ring](#RotatingSealRingrotatingSealRing-D3E68176) over the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E552BC) as far as possible against the shoulder.
    
3.  Fit [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E69BAA) on the [Stationary seal ring](#StationarySealRingstationarySealRin-D3E6A2C7).
    
4.  Fit the [Stationary seal ring](#StationarySealRingstationarySealRin-D3E6A2C7) in [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-43A36618) turn it counter clockwise and tighten using the [Tool](#Tooltool-D3E6F9BC).
    
5.  Place the [Key](#Keykey-D3E6AD04) in the groove of the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3E55F02).
    

6.  Fit the [Impeller](#Impellerimpeller-D3E6E7EE) on the [Stub shaft](#StubShaftstubShaft-D3E55F02). Fit the [Impeller nut](#ImpellerNutimpellerNut-D3E6F118) on the shaft and tighten carefully.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000746727.png)

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156136.png)

*   O-ring
*   Stub shaft
*   Spring

*   Rotating seal ring
*   O-ring
*   Stationary seal ring

*   Key

7.  Ensure that the clearance between [Impeller](#Impellerimpeller-D3E709E8) and [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-D3E71AE7) is **0.15 to 0.20 mm** (tap gently with a plastic hammer). If necessary adjust it according to procedure [Pump Unit - Set the Impeller in the Return Pump](#section1423), on page [Pump Unit - Set the Impeller in the Return Pump](#section1423).
    
8.  Fit the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-D3E724FB) in the [Pump casing](#PumpCasingpumpCasing-D3E71AE7).
    
9.  Fit the [Casing cover](#CasingCovercasingCover-D3E72C9A). Fit the [Washer](#Washerwashers-D3E73311) and the [Cap nut](#CapNutcapNuts-D3E73A4D). Tighten the [Cap nut](#CapNutcapNuts-D3E73A4D) firmly.
    
10.  Risk of damaging equipment.
    
    Never test the direction of rotation with liquid in the pump. Never run the pump with both the suction side and the pressure side blocked.
    
    Ensure that the [Impeller](#Impellerimpeller-D3E709E8) rotates smoothly.
    
11.  Connect the pump to the piping.

Equipment Status

Program Step

Risk of crushing.

Be careful when working near the moving parts.

The machine contains moving parts that can crush.

Use the air service tool to perform the instructions in this procedure. See Section [Air Service Tool Description](#section2113).

3.  Use compressed air (by the arrows) to check the function of the [Pneumatic cylinder](#PneumaticCylinderpneumaticCylinder-D3E909A2).
    
    *   Make sure that the pneumatic cylinder moves smoothly. If necessary, change the pneumatic cylinder according to Procedure 5.6.8-3 Hatch - Change Cylinder (Valid for the non USA/Canada variants).

Drive Unit
----------

### Functional Description

The Cassette Conveyor is driven by a [Servomotor](#Servomotorservomotor-D55A9E8B), through a [Planetary gear](#PlanetaryGearplanetaryGear-D55AA85E) (gear ratio 80:1) and two bevel gear boxes ([Bevel gearbox VV1](#BevelGearboxVV1bevelGearboxVV1-D55ACEC1) and [Bevel gearbox VV2](#BevelGearboxVV2bevelGearboxVV2-D55AD4DD) (gear ratio 2:1)). It is synchronised with the other movements in the machine through the **PLC** system.

The system cannot be cranked by hand. It must be driven using the inch button on the panel.

Oil level sensors are built in to the bevel gearboxes VV1 and VV2. If an oil level is low, an alarm on the panel signals. The alarm only signals if the machine has been out of operation for more than one hour. During operation, the oil is tossed around in the gears, which could result in false alarms. The planetary gear (2) is filled with grease.

All four drive shafts are equipped with a [Safety clutch](#SafetyClutchsafetyClutch-D55ADB7F) that releases at 250Nm. A [Proximity switch](#ProximitySwitchproximitySwitch-D55AE04D) senses when the clutch releases and stops the machine.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0002244726.png)

### Servo Motor Coupling - Change

Equipment Status

Program Step

1.  Remove the four [Screw](#Screwscrews-2528F73E) and measure the distance between the [Servo motor](#ServoMotorservoMotor-25293767) and the [Coupling house](#CouplingHousecouplingHouse-252B287B). If it is smaller than 0.8 or larger than 1.2 mm the coupling was incorrectly installed.

    Be careful when fixing the shaft in the vice.
    
    The [Shaft of the first step of the planet gear](#ShaftOfTheHouseCouplingshaftOfTheHo-2D6C9791) can easily be damaged by a steel vice.
    
    Very carefully fix the [Shaft of the first step of the planet gear](#ShaftOfTheHouseCouplingshaftOfTheHo-2D6C9791) in a vice.

Conveyor, Cassette Lubrication
------------------------------

### Functional Description

The Cassette Lubrication is intended both for rinsing after a crash and for lubrication during production. During rinsing after a crash, minor product residues on the cassettes are flushed off. During production, the cassette links are lubricated with water.

Drinking water, with no chemicals added is used, and a [UV-lamp](#UV-lampForSterilizingLubricationWat-D6DE1112) is sterilizing the water beforehand, for both machine sides. The system is automatically rinsed with Oxonia through the [Valve](#Valvevalve-D6DE2351) during each disinfection phase.

*   Flushing to remove product residue after a stop is done by the [Spraying nozzle](#SprayingNozzlesprayingNozzles-D6DE431D). This function must be started on the **TPOP**. The [Pressure reducing valve](#PressureReducingValvepressureReduci-D6DE4AE0) must be set according to [Lubrication Water - Check](#section1525).
    
    **Note:** The cassettes must be empty before flushing is possible.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000260874.png)

*   UV-lamp
*   Valve

*   Spraying nozzle
*   Pressure reducing valve

*   Dripping water from the [Pipes](#Pipespipes-D6DE54A5) lubricates the cassette links during production.
    
*   The [Flow control valve](#FlowControlValveflowControlValve-D6DE6466) and [Flow control valve](#FlowControlValveflowControlValve-D6DE69A3) must be set according to [Lubrication Water - Check](#section1525).
    

If the alarm `73331 UV water cleaning lamp low intensity` occurs, the UV-lamp and sensor must be checked and, if necessary, cleaned according to [Cassette Lubrication - Clean UV-lamp and Sensor](#section1526). If the problem is not resolved, check the UV-lamp assembly. Make sure that no water has reached the electrical connection.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000260873.png)

*   Pipes
*   Flow control valve
*   Flow control valve

### Lubrication Water - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step HEATING

1.  Set the lubrication water pressure to 2 bar, by turning the [Pressure reducing valve](#PressureReducingValvepressureReduci-D6DEEEFC) until the correct setting is shown.
    
2.  During maintenance work, close the [Shut-off valve (drinking water)](#Shut-offValvecityWatershut-offValve-D6DEFE3B) for incoming drinking water.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001849897.png)

*   Pressure reducing valve
*   Shut-off valve (drinking water)

3.  Set the water flow from the [Spraying nozzle](#SprayingNozzlesprayingNozzles-D6DF60E8), the [Pipes](#Pipespipes-D6DF673B), the [Side feeder nozzle](#SideFeederNozzlesideFeederNozzle-B6E74277), and the [Chain lubrication nozzle](#ChainLubricationNozzlechainLubricat-B6E74A57). The water must reach the cassettes above.
    
    Set the water flow with the flow regulators on the corresponding pipe work and the main [Flow control valve](#FlowControlValveflowControlValve-D6DF6F5F).
    
    **Note:** If the water flow is not set to reach the cassettes, there will be damage on the conveyor. Damage on the conveyor might restrict the cassette movement.
    
    **Note:** The drinking water consumption should be set to approximately 140l/h.
    
4.  Activate the cassette flushing at the **TPOP**, one machine side at a time.
    
    **Note:** It is only possible to activate this function when there are no packages in the cassettes.

Equipment Status

Power must be turn OFF.

Gas Dosing System (Optional Equipment)
--------------------------------------

### Functional Description

**Valid for Festo and Mecman**

Not all machines have the gas dosing system.

Some products are affected by oxygen in the head-space of the package. Vitamins, colour, and taste can be affected. If the oxygen level is reduced, from the normal 21% to about 8 to 10%, the shelf life of the product can be increased considerably. The gas dosing system does that by replacing the oxygen with a substitute gas.

*   Gas at 4 to 6bar passes from the supply unit through a connection at the filling platform to a [Valve block](#ValveBlockvalveBlock-18662D8D) in the front of the machine. The valves switch between substitute gas and compressed air.
    
*   A [Proportional valve](#ProportionalValveproportionalValve-18664815) reduces the gas dosing pressure to the value that is set in the **PLC**\-program. This is about 2.5bar during production.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001630908.png)

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0001630907.png)

*   Valve block
*   Proportional valve

*   The gas enters a filter unit that consists of a [5 micron filter](#MicronFilter5MicronFilter-4FE44E06) and a [0.01 micron filter](#MicronFilter0.01MicronFilter-4FE44E06).
    
*   The gas is then distributed to the two stations through [Fixed restriction](#FixedRestrictionfixedRestrictions-4FE44E04) and 0.2micron [Absolute filter](#AbsoluteFilterabsoluteFilters-4FE44E04) that filter the gas once again.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000156320.png)

*   5 micron filter
*   0.01 micron filter
*   Fixed restriction
*   Absolute filter

Two stations are fitted over the packages as follows:

[Station 1](#Station1Station1-4FE3FE75)

Located before the product filling.

[Station 2](#Station2Station2-4FE3FE75)

Located between the filling pipes and the bottom sealing.

*   When the gas dosing system is functioning but not in production there is a constant flow of compressed air through it. The airflow stops bacteria from entering the gas dosing system when the gas is turned off. This also reduces the gas consumption.
    
*   As soon as a sleeve is fed from the cutting device into the conveyor (at production start), the valves switch from air to gas with a pulsed flow through the [Pulse valve](#PulseValvepulseValves-4FE3FE75).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000299492.png)

*   Station 1
*   Station 2
*   Pulse valve

When the **TTCU** starts to clean the hygiene chamber the [Valve](#Valvevalve-12213-4FE40436), [Valve](#Valvevalve-12214-4FE40436) and [Drain Valve](#DrainValvedrainValve-4FE40436) close and the [Cleaning Solution Valve](#CleaningSolutionValvecleaningSoluti-4FE40436) and the [Valve](#Valvevalve-4FE40436) opens. The [Valve](#Valvevalve-12213-4FE40436) and [Valve](#Valvevalve-12214-4FE40436) create a buffer that ensures that no build up of liquid reaches the [Absolute filter](#AbsoluteFilterabsoluteFilters-4FE44E04). The valves stay in this configuration for all the **TTCU** cycles until the disinfection starts. In the disinfection cycle, the [Valve](#Valvevalve-12213-4FE40436) opens and the area between the [Valve](#Valvevalve-12213-4FE40436) and [Valve](#Valvevalve-12214-4FE40436) is disinfected. After the hygiene chamber clean is complete the [Cleaning Solution Valve](#CleaningSolutionValvecleaningSoluti-4FE40436) closes and the [Drain Valve](#DrainValvedrainValve-4FE40436) opens to drain the remaining liquid and remains open during production. At this time the [Valve](#Valvevalve-12213-4FE40436) and [Valve](#Valvevalve-12214-4FE40436) opens and the [Pulse valve](#PulseValvepulseValves-4FE3FE75) starts to pulsate. Compressed air is then pushed through the system to push out any remaining fluids.

### Functional Description

**Introduction**

The filling section has two main tasks:

*   to provide the right amount of filling product to the packages in the hygiene chamber.
    
*   to perform and support hygiene functions of the filling machine (with the exception of external cleaning in the hygiene chamber cleaning and package disinfection).
    

The filling section is also the main supply distributor for granulate, drinking water, ice water, air, and gas (gas is only valid if the machine is equipped with the gas dosing system).

For a functional description of the filling system, see page [Filling System](#section1547).

For a functional description of the hygiene functions, see page [Hygiene Functions](#section1548).

### Filling System

**Note:** Distance filling is used on a ADY variant machine. Bottom up filling is used on a standard variant machine.

**Note:** It is only possible to produce sweetened condensed milk on both production sides at the same time.

The two production sides of the machine can produce two different products at the same time. Two separate 50 litre tanks for the filling product(s) enable the machine to fill two different products simultaneously and independently.

The product enters the tank via a [Valve](#ValveValve-F771ED2C). The valve keeps the product level in the tank relatively constant. Information about the current level is communicated from the [Level probe](#LevelProbeLevelProbe-F7720145) via a signal from the [PLC](#PLCPLC-F771F9CC) to the control unit in the [Valve](#ValveValve-F771ED2C).

Two filling pipes lead the product from the tank to the packages. A servo-assisted piston pump measure and portion the filling product from the package's open bottom end. For a functional description of the piston pump see [Pump Units](#section1635).

### Hygiene Functions

The following list is a brief overview of the **TT/3** filling machine hygiene functions:

*   Cleaning of the filling system, **CIP**. See page [Cleaning of the Filling System (Cleaning In Place, CIP)](#section1549).
    
*   Sterilisation of the filling system, **SIP**. See page [Sterilisation of the Filling System (Sterilisation In Place, SIP)](#section1550).
    
*   Quick Rinse, **QR** (Optional for **XH**). See page [Quick Rinse of the Filling System (QR Optional)](#section1551).
    
*   Cleaning and disinfection of the hygiene chamber. See page [Cleaning and Disinfection of the Hygiene Chamber](#section1552).
    

The machine program is configurated to perform cleaning in place, sterilisation in place, quick rinse, cleaning, and disinfection when started by the operator from the **TPOP**.

*   Clean air system, filtered HEPA. See page [Clean Air System](#section1553).
    

*   Pre-treatment of the packaging material web, H202 (valid for **AD**, **ADY**, **SD**, **ASCM**, and Water). See Section [Peroxide Unit](#section518) on page [Peroxide Unit](#section518).
    
*   Package disinfection, UV+H2O2. See Section [Peroxide Unit](#section518) on page [Peroxide Unit](#section518).
    

For machine variant **XH**, the operator must activate, from the **TPOP**, the hydrogen peroxide system to run the machine with hydrogen peroxide.

For machine variants **AD**, **ADY**, **SD**, **ASCM**, and Water, the machine is automatically run with hydrogen peroxide.

For machines variants **XH**, **3A** and **XHIC**, a short automatic purge is performed every four hours during production.

### Cleaning of the Filling System (Cleaning In Place, CIP)

The **CIP** cleans the filling system by using the diary cleaning supplies systems or by using a separate unit called **ALCIP**.

The purpose of the **CIP** is to ensure that there are no residual product in the filling system nor in their connections. The program is performed in many steps. See the flow charts and sequence diagram for more information on the **CIP** steps. The flow charts and the sequence diagram are laminated documents. The sequence diagrams can also be seen in Chapter [General](#section2093). For more information see also the **OM**.

### Sterilisation of the Filling System (Sterilisation In Place, SIP)

The purpose of the **SIP** is to reduce the number of bacteria in the filling system. This is done by the **SIP** and must be preceded by a complete **CIP**.

*   Heating
    
*   Steam sterilisation 122°C, 20 minutes
    
*   Cooling
    
*   Pressure balance. The purpose of the last step is to balance the pressure and cool the pipes in order to make production start possible.
    

See the flow charts and sequence diagram for more information on the **SIP** steps. The flow charts and the sequence diagram are laminated documents. The sequence diagrams can also be seen in Chapter [General](#section2093). For more information see also the **OM**.

### Quick Rinse of the Filling System (QR Optional)

The purpose of the **QR** is to rinse out product left in the filling system at the time for product change.

The **QR** option differ from product to product and must be evaluated and defined. The result of a **QR** is a product contact surfaces that are visually clean. The principle of the **QR** program is to open up paths of the product contact surfaces in the filling system. 2 to 3 paths are used and repeated a number of times.

It is site responsibility to evaluate an define how many times the water rinse sequences should be repeated. The total time needed for a **QR** is the time that the water (at specified quality) must be supplied to the **TT/3** .

### Cleaning and Disinfection of the Hygiene Chamber

The purpose of the cleaning and disinfection is to remove residual product and to reduce the number of bacteria in the area where the packages are filled and sealed.

This is performed by a separate unit, the Tetra Top Cleaning Unit **(TTCU)**. For more information on the **TTCU** see Chapter [Tetra Top Cleaning Unit](#section1988). See also the **OM**.

### Clean Air System

High Efficiency Particulate Air (**HEPA**) flows from cabinets and units to the:

•

Hygiene chamber. The **HEPA** cabinet for the Package Section (**PS**) provides the hygiene chamber with a defined flow of filtered **HEPA**. Here, the purpose of HEPA is to prevent contamination from the surrounding environment during the filling and sealing processes. The filtered **HEPA** enters the hygiene chamber where the packages enter chamber and above the bottom sealing.

•

Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) reducer. The H2O2 reducer has outlets above the cassettes in the hygiene chamber as hot filtered HEPA is used for removing the H2O2 residue in the packages before filling.

•

Tank breathing and cleaning boxes. The filtered **HEPA** from the **HEPA** cabinet for the Filling Section (**FS**) prevents the surrounding air from entering the product tanks during filling. The excess air from the tanks is directed to the cleaning boxes where it is distributed around the filling pipes.

•

**Valid for:** Hygiene level UHH

Lid Forming Unit (**LFU**). The **HEPA** cabinet for **LFU** provides a defined flow of filtered **HEPA** over the **LFU**. Here, the purpose of HEPA is to prevent contamination from the surrounding environment. The **HEPA** filter is in the filter housing above the **LFU**.

•

**Valid for:** Hygiene level UHH

**Valid for:** Equipment with CAU

Cap Application Unit (**CAU**). The **HEPA** cabinet for **CAU** provides a defined flow of filtered HEPA over the **CAU** to prevent contamination from the surrounding environment. The **HEPA** filter is in the filter housing above the **CAU**.

### Measures Particles in HEPA System

### HEPA Unit - Evaluation

1.  Measure the particles in the **HEPA** air according to the procedures below:
    
    *   [HEPA Unit LFU - Particle Measurements](#section1576)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Hygiene Chamber](#section1577)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Peroxide Reducer](#section1578)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Cleaning Box](#section1579)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit CAU - Particle Measurements](#section1580)
        
2.  Run eight measuring cycles to make sure that the values are stable. Use the values from the last three stable measurements.
    
3.  Make sure that none of the measured values are higher than 100, which means less than 100 particles/ft3 with the size 0.5 µm. Particles bigger than 0,5 µm is not allowed.
    
4.  If any of the values (from the stable measurements) are higher then the allowed value, check that part of the clean air system and make sure that:
    
    *   the HEPA-filter is intact.
        
    *   the HEPA-filter gasket is intact.
        
    *   the HEPA-filter is assembled correctly.
        
    *   all the clamps in the HEPA-system and if necessary tighten the clamps.
        
    *   there are no holes in any hose or hose connection.

### HEPA Fan

The HEPA fans in the HEPA units should always run to maintain a continuous air flow through the filters. To ensure this, keep the machine supplied with power, even when it is not in production.

### HEPA Fan - Procedure for Short Stops (<1 hour)

If a HEPA fan stops for less than **one hour**, there is no action.

### HEPA Fan - Procedure for Medium Stops (1-48 hours)

Equipment Status

Program Step

If a HEPA fan stops for a period of **more than one but less than 48 hours**

1.  make sure that there is power supply to the HEPA fans.
    
2.  step up the machine to tank filling.
    
3.  keep the machine in tank filling for 30 minutes. Then the machine is ready to use.
    

### HEPA Fan - Procedure for Long Stops (>48 hours)

Equipment Status

Program Step STEP ZERO

Special Equipment

Alkali solution  
Isopropanol 70%  
Soft cloth

If a HEPA fan stops for more than **48 hours**

1.  remove all HEPA filters.
    
2.  clean the HEPA cabinet and all the HEPA ducts. Use a soft cloth and alcoholic solution (Isopropanol 70%). See [Chemicals for Cleaning and Disinfection](#section2117).
    
3.  install new HEPA filters. Follow these procedures:
    
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Change HEPA Filter](#section1558)
        
    *   [Peroxide Reducer - Change HEPA Filter](#section1561)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, FS - Change HEPA Filter](#section1565)
        
    *   [Ventilation UV-lamp - Change Filter](#section1570)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit - Change HEPA Filter](#section1200)
        
4.  measure particles in the HEPA air. Follow these procedures:
    
    *   [HEPA Unit LFU - Particle Measurements](#section1576)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Hygiene Chamber](#section1577)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Peroxide Reducer](#section1578)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit, PS - Particle Measurements Cleaning Box](#section1579)
        
    *   [HEPA Unit CAU - Particle Measurements](#section1580)

Equipment Status

Program Step

Consumables

Cleaning Detergents  
Soft cloth

1.  Turn the locking ring right to the gap.
    
2.  Push the ring upwards, turn it to he left and remove the nozzle.

6.  Pull the nozzle gently to make sure that the nozzle is firmly secured onto the filling tube.

### Functional Description

**Angle seat valve**

The main parts of the angle seat valve are shown in the illustration below.

The following instructions cover both **NC** (Normally Closed) and **NO** (Normally Open) valves.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209397.png)

*   Actuator
*   Valve stem

*   Valve plug
*   Valve house

**No Product In Hepa (NPIH) system**

It is very important that product never reaches the **HEPA** filters in the machine for any reason. If this happens the hygiene in the machine will be lost. To prevent this from happening, a system consisting of an [Air sensor](#AirSensorairSensor-F969B7B7), [Pressure gauge](#PressureGaugepressureGauge-F969C372), Product Relief Valve ([PRV](#PRVPRV-F969C5BB)), [High pipe](#HighPipehighPipe-F969C7D2) and [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-F969C993) has been implemented on the machine.

The first part of the system works by detecting air and high pressure in the product and consists of the [Air sensor](#AirSensorairSensor-F969B7B7) and the [Pressure gauge](#PressureGaugepressureGauge-F969C372). The second part is the relief part and works by closing the [Product valve](#ProductValveproductValve-F969CBF8) and opening the [PRV](#PRVPRV-F969C5BB) when air or high pressure is detected. The system ensures that any product containing air or too high pressure is drained out without reaching the [Product tank](#ProductTankproductTank-F969CDD4).

During production, two scenarios can set a high product pressure yellow alarm.

1) The product pressure is higher than 200 kPa for more than 10 seconds.

2) The pressure peaks at above 200 kPa for more than 2 seconds 10 times.

If the alarm occurs the machine empties out all packages and steps down to program step Preheating.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209396.png)

*   Air sensor
*   Pressure gauge
*   **PRV**
*   High pipe

*   Non-return valve
*   Product valve
*   Product tank

During **CIP** a yellow alarm occurs if the pressure is above 4 kPa for more than 2 seconds.

If the [Air sensor](#AirSensorairSensor-F96A83CA) detects air during program step production, the [PRV](#PRVPRV-F96A88DA) immediately opens and a blue alarm occurs. If air is detected for more than 10 seconds, the [Product valve](#ProductValveproductValve-F96A8F8D) closes and the air in product yellow alarm occurs.

**Note:** The pressure release function is disabled for ADY.

During the program steps Tankfilling and Motor on the air in product yellow alarm is set immediately if the [Air sensor](#AirSensorairSensor-F96A83CA) detects air.

**Note:** The pressure release function is disabled for ADY.

The **PRV** can also be opened manually in certain program steps to purge unwanted product from the machine. See the **OM** for more information.

As an added backup the HEPA air pipe into the [Product tank](#ProductTankproductTank-F96A9213) also includes a [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-F96A8D37). This [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-F96A8D37) stops any splash in the product tank so that it does not reach the HEPA air system. Splashing can be caused by bubbles that enter the [Product tank](#ProductTankproductTank-F96A9213). The non-return valve also stops product from reaching the HEPA air system through overfilling of the [Product tank](#ProductTankproductTank-F96A9213) if the level probe fails for any reason.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209396.png)

*   Air sensor
*   Pressure gauge
*   **PRV**
*   High Pipe

*   Non-return valve
*   Product valve
*   Product tank

### Regulator Valve, Tank Level - Overhaul

Equipment Status

Program Step

**Note:** For Machines with machine number 20082 or higher, see section .

#### How to apply a current value

In order to apply a current of 4 mA or 20 mA do as follows:

1.  Step the machine up to Air on.
    
2.  Turn the service key on.
    
    **Note:** The current supplied to the valve is now 20 mA.
    
3.  Turn the service key off.
    
    **Note:** The current supplied to the valve is now 4 mA.
    

#### Overhaul

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

1.  Remover the cover, not shown on the picture.
    
2.  Step the machine up to AIR ON and turn the service key ON to open the valve.
    

3.  Remove the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-F98F469A)
    
4.  Step the machine down to step zero and turn the service key OFF to close the valve.
    
5.  Remove the valve and the [L-ring](#L-ringL-ring-F98F4862).
    
6.  Loosen and remove the [Holder](#Holderholder-F98F4AAB)

#### Initialization

During initialization the positioner adapts itself optimally to the friction conditions and the signal pressure required by the control valve.

Risk of injury due to the actuator stem extending or retracting.

Do not touch or block the actuator stem.

The process is disturbed by the movement of the actuator stem.

Do not initialize the positioner while the process is running and only after isolating the plant by closing the shut-off valves.

The type and extent of self-adaptation depends on the preset parameters. MAX applies as the default setting for the nominal range (Code **P4**). During the initialization process, the positioner determines the total travel range or rotational range of the valve (from the CLOSED position to the opposite end position).

Alternatively, a different travel can be selected in Code **P4** (see code list in [Setting other valid parameters](#SettingOtherValidParameters-01F0488A).

**Note:** The travel set in Code **P4** is only limited during initialization. However, it might be exceeded in closed-loop control when the control signal is higher than 20 mA.

Start initialization

**Initialized positioner**

The manual mode starts using the last set point used in closed-loop operation, ensuring a bumpless changeover.

The bar elements on the display indicate the system deviation between the manual set point and set point used for closed-loop control while manually moving the valve in Code P17.

The manual set point is adjusted in steps of 0.1%. You can move the valve controlled within its range.

**Positioner that has not been initialized**

Touch [DOWN button](#DOWNButtonDOWNButton-EB517505) or [UP button](#UPButtonUPButton-EB51785C) for a long time to move the valve manually.

The valve is only moved in one direction uncontrolled. The bar elements on the display indicate the change in direction.

Touch [CONFIRM button](#CONFIRMButtonCONFIRMButton-EB518517) to deactivate manual mode.

**Note:** The Manual mode function can only be exited as described or by interrupting the electrical supply (cold start). The positioner does not automatically exit this function and return to the display showing the status indication.

#### Fault

In case of a fault, the [Fault indication icon](#Fault-EC5BDA9F) is displayed. Switch past Code P0 or P20 to display the respective error code E0 to E15 together with ERR appear on the display. Refer to the [Error codes](#section1634) list on page [Error codes](#section1634) for the cause of the errors and the recommended action.

**Example:**

If, for instance, a travel has been entered in Code P4 (nominal range) which is larger than the maximum valve travel possible, the initialization process would be interrupted (E2 error code) because the rated travel would not have been reached (E6 error code). The valve moves to the [Fail-safe position active](#Fail-safePositionActive-ECDD631F).

E2 error code: Initialization canceled

E6 error code: Rated travel not achieved

The nominal range (Code P4) must be changed and the positioner re-initialized to remedy this problem.

(operational error)

Recommended action

(operational error)

(initialization error)

Recommended action

(initialization error)

The transit times of the actuator determined during initialization are so short (below 0.5 second) that optimal positioner tuning is not possible.

Recommended action

2

Recommended action

Check supply air, positioner mounting and setting. Re-initialize the positioner.

(initialization error)

No supply air, mounting blocked.

2

Recommended action

Check supply air, positioner mounting and mA input signal. Re-initialize the positioner.

1

Recommended action

Return positioner to SAMSON AG for repair.

Pump Units
----------

### Functional Description

The [Fill pump](#FillPumpfillPump-FA8734D8) is driven by a [Servo motor](#Servomotorservomotor-FA8734D8). The Universal Product Valves [Inlet UPV](#InletUPVinletUPV-FA8734D8) and [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6), and the [Resuction device](#ResuctionDeviceresuctionDevice-FA8734D6) are pneumatically activated, and the timing is coordinated from the servo to ensure correct speed and accurate filling.

The servo motor drives the fill pump. The servo motor contains a motor combined with a roller screw. This results in a reliable high-speed filling system. Each time that the machine steps up to program step Air on, a homing procedure is performed on the servo motors. The servo motor is oil cooled and lubricated in order to keep correct working temperature.

Before production, air is purged from the system and a column of product stands ready for filling. This is activated on the **TPOP**. Both the [Inlet UPV](#InletUPVinletUPV-FA8734D8) and the [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6) are closed at the start of production.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209450.png)

*   Fill pump
*   Servo motor
*   **UPV**Inlet

*   **UPV**Outlet
*   Resuction device

Fill stroke:

*   Resuction is deactivated just after the start of filling.
    
*   As the [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6) opens, the piston moves forward to push product out of the [Pump chamber](#PumpChamberpumpChamber-FA8734D6).
    
*   The outlet **UPV** closes at the end of the fill stroke, and the resuction device is activated just before the fill stroke ends.
    

Charge stroke:

*   The [Inlet UPV](#InletUPVinletUPV-FA8734D8) opens and the piston moves backward to charge the [Pump chamber](#PumpChamberpumpChamber-FA8734D6).
    
*   At the end of the charge stroke, the inlet **UPV** closes.
    

The process repeats itself throughout production.

The [Leakage detector](#LeakageDetectorLeakageDetectors-8222-FA8734D6) detects any leakage behind the diaphragm in the [Fill pump](#FillPumpfillPump-FA8734D8). The [Leakage detector](#LeakageDetectorLeakageDetectors-FA8734D6) detects leakages in the [Resuction device](#ResuctionDeviceresuctionDevice-FA8734D6). The detectors are connected to different alarms on the **TPOP**.

### Functional Description

TT/3\_SCM

The [Fill pump](#FillPumpfillPump-FA8734D8) is driven by a [Servo motor](#Servomotorservomotor-FA8734D8). The Universal Product Valve ([UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6)) is pneumatically activated, and the timing is coordinated from the servo to ensure correct speed and accurate filling.

The servo motor drives the fill pump. The servo motor contains a motor combined with a roller screw. This results in a reliable high-speed filling system. The servo motor is oil cooled and lubricated to keep a correct working temperature.

Before production, air is purged from the system and a column of product stands ready for filling. This is activated on the **TPOP**. The [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6) is closed at the start of production.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000522939.png)

*   Fill pump
*   Servo motor
*   **UPV**

Fill stroke:

*   As the [Filling valve](#FillingValvefllingValve-C864EDE9) opens, the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-8D8FB2FD) moves forward to push product out of the [Pump chamber](#PumpChamberpumpChamber-FA8734D6) through the [Filling valve](#FillingValvefllingValve-C864EDE9).
    
*   The [Filling valve](#FillingValvefllingValve-C864EDE9) closes at the end of the fill stroke
    

Charge stroke:

*   The [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6) opens and the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-8D8FB2FD) moves backward to charge the [Pump chamber](#PumpChamberpumpChamber-FA8734D6).
    
*   At the end of the charge stroke, the [UPV](#OutletUPVoutletUPV-FA8734D6) closes.
    

The process repeats itself throughout production.

The [Leakage detector](#LeakageDetectorLeakageDetectors-8222-FA8734D6) detects any leakage behind the diaphragm in the [Fill pump](#FillPumpfillPump-FA8734D8). The detectors are connected to different alarms on the **TPOP**.

Risk of crushing and cutting hands and fingers

To prevent the valves from leaking, the filling valve servo motors are active in all program steps except **STEP ZERO**, even when the doors are open. Never put fingers or other materials between the piston (9) and the filling pipe (8).

### Piston Pumps - Check Piston Centring

Equipment Status

Program Step

Special Equipment

Adjustment pin TP No. 2929048-0000

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

#### Preparations of the Piston Pump

1.  Disassemble the piston pump, follow the sub procedure
    
    *   [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms](#section1643) (see Procedure [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms](#section1643)).
        
        or
        
    *   [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms and Seals](#section1644) (see Procedure [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms and Seals](#section1644)).
        
2.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    The piston surface can easily be damaged, which can lead to premature failure of the diaphragms. Never use a vice to hold the piston unit.
    
    Remove the six [Screw](#Screwscrew-F9EE0EB1), the [Connection plate](#ConnectionPlateconnectionPlate-F9EE1061) and the [Rear diaphragm](#RearDiaphragmrearDiaphragm-F9EE12E5) from the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-F9EE14C7).
    
3.  Remove the [Nut](#Nutnut-F9EE16B3), the [Washer](#Washerwasher-F9EE1932), the [Plate](#Plateplate-F9EE1BE2), and [Front diaphragm](#FrontDiaphragmfrontDiaphragm-F9EE1DAB).
    
4.  Reassemble a [Piston unit](#PistonUnitpistonUnit-F9EE1FB9) with a [Connection plate](#ConnectionPlateconnectionPlate-F9EE1061), six [Screw](#Screwscrew-F9EE0EB1) and a [Piston](#Pistonpiston-F9EE14C7).
    
    **Note:** The procedure is valid for variant Base, Midi, and Mini. The procedure for variant Micro is similar to that procedure and therefore not described.

6.  Reassemble the pump cylinder
    
    *   Slide the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderpumpCylinder-F9EEC5E5) over the [Piston unit](#PistonUnitpistonUnit-F9EE1FB9). Align the [Guide pin](#GuidePinguidePins-F9EED7BD).

7.  Remove the [Plug](#Plugplug-F9EF0505).
    
8.  Turn the roller screw using a screwdriver, until the [Piston unit](#PistonUnitpistonUnit-F9EE1FB9) is lined up with the end of the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderpumpCylinder-F9EEC5E5).

#### Check Piston Centring in Pump Cylinder

1.  Check the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-F9EE14C7) position in the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderpumpCylinder-F9EEC5E5). Use the [Adjustment pin](#AdjustmentPinadjustmentPin-F9EF62F4) to detect if there is any deviation in the piston centring. The adjustment pin must without any difficulty be able to run in the gap **A,** around the piston in the pump cylinder. If the gap **A** is not according to the table below the feeler pin will get jammed and the piston needs to be repositioned.
    
    **Note:** The large end of the adjustment pin is to be used for variant Base, Midi, and Mini. The small end of the adjustment pin is to be used for variant Micro.
    
2.  If there is a deviation in the centring of the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-F9EE14C7) adjust the alignment of the [Servomotor](#Servomotorservomotor-F9EF7BE6) and [Motor cradle](#MotorCradlemotorCradle-F9EF82C8) by turning the screws, see Procedure [Piston Pump - Set Piston Centring](#section1641).

### Piston Pump - Set Piston Centring

Equipment Status

Program Step

Special Equipment

Adjustment pin TP No. 2929048-0000

The [Screw](#Screwscrew-F9FDCF92) in the [Distance](#Distancedistance-F9FDD27C) between the [Servomotor](#Servomotorservomotor-F9FDD455) and [Motor cradle](#MotorCradlemotorCradle-F9FDD711) , can be used for adjusting the servomotors contact surface against the motor cradle. Turning the screw will adjust the axle position of the servomotor and effect the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-F9FDD96D) centring. If the piston is leaning towards one side of the pump cylinder the screw on the opposite side needs to be adjusted to compensate for the incorrect position of the axle.

#### Centre Piston - Work Sequence:

1.  Make sure that the [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE12E1) is loosened, and that they are not in contact with the [Motor cradle](#MotorCradleMotorCradle-F9FE150B).
    
2.  Check the position of the [Piston](#PistonPiston-F9FE16C2) in the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderPumpCylinder-F9FE18F1) with the [Adjustment pin](#AdjustmentPinAdjustmentPin-F9FE1A40), to find out which way the piston is leaning.
    
    **Note:** The large end of the adjustment pin is to be used for variant Base, Midi, and Mini. The small end of the adjustment pin is to be used for variant Micro.
    
3.  Measure the gap at the point where the adjustment pin got jammed.
    
4.  Loosen the four [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE1C29).
    
5.  Make adjustments by turning the [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE12E1).
    
    **Note:** See the tables and illustrations below for guidance.
    
6.  Slightly tighten the [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE12E1) not used for adjustments, they must just be in contact with the [Motor cradle](#MotorCradleMotorCradle-F9FE150B).
    
7.  Tighten the [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE12E1). Tighten the [Screw](#ScrewScrew-F9FE1C29).
    
8.  Check if the [Piston](#PistonPiston-F9FE16C2) is centred in the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderPumpCylinder-F9FE18F1). Repeat the procedure until the [Adjustment pin](#AdjustmentPinAdjustmentPin-F9FE1A40) can run through the gap without getting jammed.

### Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms and Seals

Equipment Status

Program Step

Special Equipment

Vacuum generator TP No. 1304364-0101

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

#### Piston Pump - Disassembly

1.  Check that the gauge on the vacuum pump reads **\-0.7 to -0.8 bar**.
    
2.  Disconnect the [Vacuum hose](#VacuumHosevacuumHose-FA1033A5) from the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-FA103591). Plug the vacuum hose.
    
3.  Loosen the [Pump head](#PumpHeadpumpHead-FA1037E5) by removing the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-FA1039AC). Make sure that you do **not** lose the [Guide pin](#GuidePinguidePin-FA103B9E).
    
4.  Loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrew-FA103E43) and slide the piston pump in the direction of the arrow.
    
5.  Remove the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-FA104023).
    
6.  Remove the [Pump cylinder](#PumpCylinderpumpCylinder-FA1041D7). Make sure that you do **not** lose the [Guide pin](#GuidePinguidePin-FA10441E).
    
7.  Loosen the [Screw](#Screwscrew-FA1045FB) until you can lift and turn the [Bracket](#Bracketbracket-FA104800) as shown in the illustration below.
    
8.  Remove the [Cover](#Covercover-FA1049EE).
    
9.  Remove the [Clamp](#Clampclamp-FA104BD8) and remove the [Piston unit](#PistonUnitpistonUnit-FA104DCA). Make sure that you do **not** lose the guide pin (by the arrow).
    
10.  Place the piston unit on a clean suitable working area.

#### Piston Unit - Change Diaphragms

Risk of damage to the equipment.

The piston surface can easily be damaged, which can lead to premature failure of the diaphragms. Never use a vice for holding the piston unit.

1.  Remove the [Nut](#Nutnut-FA10EDCC), the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-FA10F579), the [Cap](#Capcap-FA10FDEB) and [Front diaphragm](#FrontDiaphragmfrontDiaphragm-FA1105CA) from the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-FA110D36).
    
2.  Remove the [Screw](#Screwscrew-FA1115C9), the [Connection plate](#ConnectionPlateconnectionPlate-FA1122CD), the [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-FA112E92) and the rear [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-FA1136AA).
    
3.  Use a soft cloth and cleaning solution according to the **OM** to clean the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-FA110D36).
    
4.  Place the new rear [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-FA1136AA) , the new [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-FA112E92), and the [Connection plate](#ConnectionPlateconnectionPlate-FA1122CD) on the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-FA110D36). Make sure that the diaphragm is correctly placed in the recess of the piston.
    
5.  Fold the new rear [Diaphragm](#Diaphragmdiaphragm-FA1136AA) over the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-FA110D36). Check for folds, smooth out if necessary.
    
6.  Tighten the [Screw](#Screwscrew-FA1115C9).
    
7.  Assemble the new [Front diaphragm](#FrontDiaphragmfrontDiaphragm-FA1105CA), the new [O-ring](#O-ringO-ring-FA10F579), the [Cap](#Capcap-FA10FDEB), and the [Nut](#Nutnut-FA10EDCC). Make sure that the diaphragm is correctly placed in the recess of the piston
    
8.  Fold the new [Front diaphragm](#FrontDiaphragmfrontDiaphragm-FA1105CA) over the [Piston](#Pistonpiston-FA110D36). Check for folds, smooth out if necessary.

### Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms due to Breakdown

Equipment Status

Program Step production

Special Equipment

Vacuum generator TP No. 1304364-0101  
Diaphragm insert tool TP No. 1094870 (Micro)

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

**Note:** The installation of new diaphragms require the filling system to be cleaned and sterilised before production can start again. This can be done with the other side in production, if the process equipment is connected to the machine with separate product lines. Perform CIP and SIP before starting production on the serviced side.

4.  If one side is still in production, step that side down to tank filling.
    

2.  Risk of damage to the equipment.
    
    The vacuum system creates vacuum for the piston pumps on both Side 1 and Side 2 in all program steps. If the vacuum system is interrupted in **production** or **end production**, the piston pump diaphragms can be damaged. Make sure that the machine is in **tank filling** (or in a lower program step) on both Side 1 and Side 2, before removing the vacuum hoses from the piston pumps.
    
    Disconnect the vacuum [Hose](#Hosehose-FA1470CC) from the pump to be serviced, at the [Leakage detector](#LeakageDetectorleakageDetector-FA147FEC). Use a [Hose-hose connection](#Hose-hoseConnectionhose-hoseConnect-FA148942) and a [Blanking plug](#BlankingPlugblankingPlug-FA1492B1) to plug the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA1470CC).
    
3.  Check that the gauge on the vacuum pump reads **\-0.7 to -0.8 bar**.
    
4.  If it is desirable to run production on the side where the service work is not performed, step that machine side up to production.

### Universal Product Valve - Check

Equipment Status

Program Step

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

#### Check before Removal

1.  Make sure that:
    
    *   The [Spring](#Springspring-7221DF0D) is not fatigued. (When the [Spring](#Springspring-7221DF0D) is in rest position there should be no space between the coils.)
        
    *   There is no play in the [Rod end](#RodEndrodEnds-722208FD) and the [Ball](#Ballballs-72220DE1) moves freely.
        
    *   The radial play is < 0.3 mm in the [Bushing](#Bushingbushings-722219A0).
        
    *   The [Air cylinder](#AirCylinderairCylinder-72221F40) does not have external leakage or internal leakage between the two internal chambers. If any doubt, change the [Air cylinder](#AirCylinderairCylinder-72221F40).
        
    *   The radial play is < 0.3 mm in the [Bushing](#Bushingbushing-72222E3F) and in the [Swivel flange](#SwivelFlangeswivelFlange-72223388).
        
    *   The [Spacer](#Spacerspacer-7222372D) is not worn or missing.
        
    *   The [Throttle check valve](#ThrottleCheckValvethrottleCheckValv-BA349604) does not leak air, and are tightened against the [Air cylinder](#AirCylinderairCylinder-72221F40).
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004344472.png)

*   Spring
*   Rod end
*   Ball

*   Bushing
*   Air cylinder
*   Bushing

*   Swivel flange
*   Spacer
*   Throttle check valve

#### Check after Removal

1.  Remove the valve, see part of procedure [Universal Product Valve - Overhaul](#section1658).
    
2.  Make sure that:
    
    *   the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA858629) is not damaged
        
    *   the [Gasket](#Gasketgasket-FA858813) are not damaged
        
3.  Check the overtravel with the [Spring](#Springspring-FA858AC7) attached
    
    *   overtravel should be **0.3 mm to 0.7 mm**.
        
4.  Check the valve rubber components for damage.

*   Valve
*   Gasket
*   Spring

#### Final Steps

1.  Install valve (parts of procedure [Universal Product Valve - Overhaul](#section1658)).
    
2.  Check valve setting (procedure [Universal Product Valve - Set](#section1651)).

### Universal Product Valve - Set

Equipment Status

Program Step

#### Set Overtravel

**Note:** The setting is to be done with the spring unit installed.

Make sure that the valve closes completely. A small overtravel is to be set.

1.  Lift the [Yoke](#Yokeyoke-FA872563) to open the valve. Then let the valve close by itself.
    
2.  Measure the gap **A** and make a note of it.
    
3.  Push the [Yoke](#Yokeyoke-FA872563) downwards until the piston reach its end position.
    
4.  Measure the gap **A** again. It should be a difference of 0.3 to 0.7 mm between the two measurements. (=overtravel).
    

#### Basic Setting of Throttle Valves

1.  Close both the [Throttle valve](#ThrottleValvethrottleValve-FA87275F) and [Throttle valve](#ThrottleValvethrottleValve-FA8729CA) completely by turning the screws.
    
2.  Open the [Throttle valve](#ThrottleValvethrottleValve-FA8729CA) by turning the screw:
    
    *   Turn 4 revolutions counter clockwise.
        
3.  Open the [Throttle valve](#ThrottleValvethrottleValve-FA87275F) ) by turning the screw:
    
    *   Turn 7 revolution counter clockwise.
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209484.png)

*   Yoke
*   Throttle valve
*   Throttle valve

#### Set Spring

Make sure that the spring is attached as shown in the illustration.

**Note:** Put a little grease on the springs end and open about 1 mm gap the springs first turn.

3.  Insert the left end of the [Spring](#Springspring-FA87B30E) into the first hole in the [Small holder](#SmallHoldersmallHolder-FA87B5A3) . Turn the spring until it fits into all holes.
    
4.  Insert the right end of the spring in the hole on the [Spring holder](#SpringHolderspringHolder-FA87B7FD) and turn until all, but the last [Hole](#Holehole-FA87BAB8) on each row are filled. There should be one empty on each row and the end of the spring should be just in or about to enter the last hole in the lower row.
    
5.  Make sure that the [Ball](#Ballballs-FA87BD0C) moves easily.

### Re-Suction Device - Clean the Leak Detection System

Equipment Status

Program Step step zero

Remaining fluids and steam.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure. Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

Burn hazard.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot. Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

3.  Remove the [Housing](#Housinghousing-FA8C2C78) and the leaking resuction diaphragm according to [Re-Suction Device - Change Diaphragms](#section1655).
    
4.  Clean the [Housing](#Housinghousing-FA8C2C78).
    
5.  Install a new diaphragm and re-install the [Housing](#Housinghousing-FA8C2C78).
    
6.  Prepare a clean container and fill it with one litre of clean water.
    
7.  Disconnect the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA8C2E78) between the [T-pipe](#T-pipeT-pipe-FA8C3095) and the [Ejector](#Ejectorejector-FA8C32CC).
    
    **Note:** Never disconnect the[Hose](#Hosehose-FA8C34FE) between the [Ejector](#Ejectorejector-FA8C32CC) and the sensors.
    
8.  Disconnect the [Ejector](#Ejectorejector-FA8C32CC) from the [Housing](#Housinghousing-FA8C2C78).
    
9.  Connect a piece of [Hose](#Hosehose-FA8C375E) to the vacuum side of the [T-pipe](#T-pipeT-pipe-FA8C3095).

8.  Put the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA8C375E) into the water and blow with compressed air through the hose you disconnected from the [T-pipe](#T-pipeT-pipe-FA8C3095) until all the water has been sucked through the [Ejector](#Ejectorejector-FA8C32CC).
    
9.  Remove the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA8C375E) from the container and blow some more compressed air through the ejector to dry the system.

### Universal Product Valve - Check

Equipment Status

Power must be turn ON.  
Air must be turn ON.  
Steam must be turn ON.  
Water must be turn ON.  

Burn hazard.

Allow the filling system to cool down before working on or near it.

The surfaces on the filling system are hot and can cause serious burns.

#### Check with Valves on Machine

1.  Make sure that:
    
    *   The [Spring](#Springspring-71CDA36E) is not fatigued. (When the [Spring](#Springspring-71CDA36E) is in rest position there should be no space between the coils.)
        
    *   There is no play in the [Rod end](#RodEndrodEnds-71CDA36E) and the [Ball](#Ballballs-E4C825A8) moves freely.
        
    *   The radial play is < 0.3 mm in the [Bushing](#Bushingbushings-E4C865A6).
        
    *   The [Air cylinder](#AirCylinderairCylinder-71CDA36E) does not have external leakage or internal leakage between the two internal chambers. If any doubt, change the air cylinder.
        
    *   The radial play is < 0.3 mm in the [Bushing](#Bushingbushing-71CDA36E) and in the [Swivel flange](#SwivelFlangeswivelFlange-E4C9F463).
        
    *   The [Spacer](#Spacerspacer-71CDA36E) is not worn or missing.
        
    *   The [Throttle check valve](#ThrottleCheckValvethrottleCheckValv-BA33FDC5) does not leak air, and are tightened against the [Air cylinder](#AirCylinderairCylinder-71CDA36E).
        

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0004344473.png)

*   Spring
*   Rod end
*   Ball

*   Bushing
*   Air cylinder
*   Bushing

*   Swivel flange
*   Spacer
*   Throttle check valve

#### Check after Valves are Removed from Machine

1.  Remove the **UPV** from the machine. See Procedure [Universal Product Valve - Overhaul](#section1663). Make sure that:
    
    *   the [Valve body](#ValveBodyValveBody-13AC3995) is not damaged
        
    *   the [Gasket](#GasketsGaskets-13AC4340) are not damaged.
        
2.  Check rubber components of the valve for ruptures.
    
3.  Check the overtravel. See Procedure [Universal Product Valve - Set](#section1664).
    
4.  Install the valve. See Procedure [Universal Product Valve - Overhaul](#section1663).
    
5.  Check the setting of the valve. See Procedure [Universal Product Valve - Set](#section1664).

### Universal Product Valve - Set

Equipment Status

Power must be turn ON.  
Air must be turn ON.  
Steam must be turn ON.  
Water must be turn ON.  

#### Set the Air Cylinder Link Overtravel

Overtravel is the difference between when the air cylinder piston is against the end of the air cylinder compared to a distance away from the air cylinder end position. Overtravel is required to ensure the correct closing compression of the valve lifter against the valve seat.

1.  Make sure that the valve cone has been set correctly according to the procedure [6.4.2.5-2 Universal Product Valve - Overhaul](#section1663).
    
2.  Turn the main air valve OFF.
    
3.  Make sure that the valve closes completely with spring pressure. Set the [Rod end](#RodEndrodEnd-142BEAB1) so there is a small overtravel.
    
4.  Measure and record the gap A.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000645211.png)

*   Rod end

5.  Turn the main air valve ON.
    
    **Note:** The air cylinder piston must be at the end position of the cylinder.
    
6.  Measure gap A.
    
    *   There must be a difference of 0.3 mm - 0.7 mm between the two measurements. This is the overtravel.
        
7.  Adjust the rod end of the cylinder if needed.
    
    *   Loosen the [Nut](#NutNut-142C09A4).
        
    *   Turn the cylinder [Cylinder rod](#CylinderRodcylinderRod-142C1E2A) to achieve the overtravel.
        
    *   Tighten the [Nut](#NutNut-142C09A4).
        
8.  Recheck the gap A according to items [Reference](TurnTheMainAirValveOFF.-142C2C2E) through [Reference](MeasureGapA.ThereMustBeADifferenceO-142C31E1). Adjust the rod end if necessary.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000645210.png)

*   Nut
*   Cylinder rod

#### Set the Throttle Check Valves

1.  Loosen the [Locking nut](#LockingNutlockingNut-B5DF94E7) and [Locking nut](#LockingNutlockingNut-1216216-B5DF94E7).
    
2.  Close both [throttle check valve](#ThrottleCheckValvethrottleCheckValv-B5DF94E6) and [Throttle check valve for “closing”](#ThrottleCheckValveForclosingthrottl-B5DF94E6) completely by turning the [Adjustment screw (6.5 turns @ 5.5 bar (for ADY, 6 turns @ 5.5 bar))](#AdjustmentScrew6.5Turns5.5BarforADY-B5DF94E7) and the [Adjustment screw (3.5 turns @ 2.5 bar (for ADY, 9 turns @ 5.5 bar))](#AdjustmentScrew3.5Turns2.5BarforADY-B5DF94E7) in as far as they will go (fully home).
    
3.  Open the [throttle check valve](#ThrottleCheckValvethrottleCheckValv-B5DF94E6) by turning the [Adjustment screw (6.5 turns @ 5.5 bar (for ADY, 6 turns @ 5.5 bar))](#AdjustmentScrew6.5Turns5.5BarforADY-B5DF94E7) out 6.5 turns (for ADY, 6 turns).
    
4.  Open the [Throttle check valve for “closing”](#ThrottleCheckValveForclosingthrottl-B5DF94E6) by turning the [Adjustment screw (3.5 turns @ 2.5 bar (for ADY, 9 turns @ 5.5 bar))](#AdjustmentScrew3.5Turns2.5BarforADY-B5DF94E7) out 3.5 turns (for ADY, 9 turns).
    
5.  Tighten the [Locking nut](#LockingNutlockingNut-B5DF94E7) and [Locking nut](#LockingNutlockingNut-1216216-B5DF94E7) to secure settings.

### Functional Description

The [Tank](#Tanktanks-F9FF0882) are provided with a level probe and its floating body is provided with a permanent magnet. The product level is measured by the floating body through magnetic transfer.

### Tank Bracket - Check Level Probe

Equipment Status

Program Step

Remaining fluids and steam.

Release any pressure and drain any fluids before starting any work on the filling system.

The filling system could contain fluids and steam under pressure.

Burn hazard.

Allow the pipes and components to cool down before starting any work on them. If this is not possible, use caution when working near the hot pipes and components.

Pipes and components in the filling system can be hot.

1.  Check the function by measuring the resistance between the wires.
    
    *   **Black and brown**.The resistance decrease proportionally according to the position of the floating body.
        
    *   **Blue and brown**.The resistance increase proportionally according to the position of the floating body.
        
    *   **Black and blue**.Shows the total resistance independent of position of the floating body.
        
        **Wires**
        
        **Position of the floating body**
        
        0%
        
        50%
        
        100%
        
        **Black and brown**

        4.5 Kilo-ohm
        
        9 Kilo-ohm
        
        **Blue and brown**
        
        9 Kilo-ohm
        
        4.5 Kilo-ohm
        
        1 Ohm
        
        **Black and blue**
        
        9 Kilo-ohm
        
        9 Kilo-ohm
        
        9 Kilo-ohm
        
2.  Check for short-circuit. Measure the resistance between each wire and the housing of the level probe.

### Vacuum System Functional Description

The purpose of the vacuum system is to make sure that the diaphragms are always in contact with the piston pumps. This ensures that the diaphragms do not fold or break prematurely.

Compressed air enters the system through the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-FA018340) and is regulated with the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA018974). The vacuum is continuously measured by the [Pressure guard](#PressureGuardpressureGuard-FA018F6A) and the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA018974) opens when the vacuum is above -60 kPa (-0.6 bar) and it remains open for 10 seconds to build up the vacuum again. If the vacuum is above the allowed value for more than 30 seconds the blue alarm occurs. If the vacuum rises above -50 kPa (-0.5 bar) the yellow alarm occurs. The vacuum itself is generated in the [Ejector](#Ejectorejector-FA019407) as the compressed air passes through it and out the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA0197BE). The passing air sucks out the air in the rest of the system and creates the vacuum. The vacuum is preserved with the [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-FA019ACC).

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209550.png)

*   Connection
*   Valve
*   Pressure guard
*   Ejector
*   Hose
*   Non-return valve

There is one vacuum cabinet for each side of the machine. The system is then divided at the [T-connection](#T-connectionT-connection-FA019F3D) and supplies both piston pumps for that side of the machine. The [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-FA01A42B) and [Non-return valve](#Non-returnValvenon-returnValve-FA01A6CA) ensures that if one diaphragm leaks, the other piston pump will not be contaminated.

The vacuum system is always supplied with compressed air, even if the machine is stepped down to program step Zero.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209549.png)

*   T-connection
*   Non-return valve
*   Non-return valve

### 110305181/110305182

**Description**

Compressed air enters the system through the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-FA023022) and is regulated with the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA0233BD). The vacuum is continuously measured by the [Pressure guard](#PressureGuardpressureGuard-FA028956) and the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA0233BD) opens when the vacuum is above -60 kPa (-0.6 bar) and it remains open for 10 seconds to build up the vacuum again.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the vacuum is above the allowed value for more than 30 seconds the blue alarm (S1) 110305181 or (S2) 110305182 occurs.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000214053.png)

*   Connection
*   Valve
*   Pressure guard

**Troubleshooting**

*   Check all the hoses and connections in the system for leaks. Repair any leaks that you find.
    
*   Check if the sight glasses of the drain detectors are loose. Tighten any loose sight glasses.
    
*   Make sure that the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA0233BD) is functioning by starting it manually. Press the button on the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA0233BD) to start it. Check the value on the [Pressure guard](#PressureGuardpressureGuard-FA028956) when the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA0233BD) is open. The value will change if the valve is functioning.
    

### 110305191/110305192

Compressed air enters the system through the [Connection](#Connectionconnection-FA02C507) and is regulated with the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA02CA1F). The vacuum is continuously measured by the [Pressure guard](#PressureGuardpressureGuard-FA02D448) and the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA02CA1F) opens when the vacuum is above -60 kPa (-0.6 bar) and it remains open for 10 seconds to build up the vacuum again.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the vacuum rises above -50 kPa (-0.5 bar) the yellow alarm (S1) 110305191 or (S2) 110305192 occurs.

Check the value on the [Pressure guard](#PressureGuardpressureGuard-FA02D448) when the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA02CA1F) is open. The value will change if the valve is functioning.
    

### Vacuum System - Clean

Equipment Status

Program Step air on

Special Equipment

Clean 1 litre water container

Consumables

Clean water, 1 litre

1.  Change the leaking diaphragm and empty and clean the leaking piston pump according to [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms](#section1643) or [Piston Pump - Change Diaphragms and Seals](#section1644).
    
2.  Remove the cover from the [Vacuum box](#VacuumBoxvacuumBox-FA037ECD).
    
3.  Prepare a clean container and fill it with 1 litre of clean water.
    
4.  Disconnect the [Hose](#HosehHose-FA03837D) from the cleaned piston pump and put the disconnected end in the clean water.
    
5.  Open the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA038882) with the [Switch](#Switchswitch-FA038BB2) and run the vacuum system until all the clean water has been sucked up. This flushes out most of the contamination from the vacuum system.
    
6.  Connect the [Hose](#HosehHose-FA03837D) to the piston pump to make that side airtight and to make item [Reference](OpenTheWithTheAndRunTheVacuumSystem-17D1C595) below possible.
    
7.  Fill the container with clean water again.
    
8.  Disconnect the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA038F7C) from the [Drain detector](#DrainDetectordrainDetector-FA039225) on the uncontaminated side and put the disconnected end in the clean water.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209548.png)

*   Vacuum box
*   Hose

*   Valve
*   Switch

*   Hose
*   Drain detector

9.  Open the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA038882) with the [Switch](#Switchswitch-FA038BB2) and run the vacuum system until all the clean water has been sucked up. This flushes out the last contamination from the vacuum system.
    
10.  Disconnect the [Hose](#HosehHose-FA03837D) from the cleaned piston pump to prepare the system for drying.
    
11.  Open the [Valve](#Valvevalve-FA038882) with the switch and run the vacuum system for one minute and suck air to dry the system.
    
12.  Connect the [Hose](#HosehHose-FA03837D) to the piston pump
    
13.  Connect the [Hose](#Hosehose-FA038F7C) to the [Drain detector](#DrainDetectordrainDetector-FA039225).
    
14.  Install the cover.

Ice water
---------

### Functional Description

**Note:** The ice water cooling of the product tank is disconnected for the machine variant AW.

The ice water that flows through the TT/3 ice water system is supplied by the customer's external ice water system. The TT/3 must be supplied with a flow of 85l/min and the ice water must have a temperature of 1 to 7˚C (33.8 to 44.6 °F). The flow and temperature are both measured and logged by the TT/3.

The ice water circulates through the **HEPA** cabinets and the cooling mantle of the product tank before it returns to the customer's external ice water system. The **HEPA** cabinets must be continually cooled with ice water to ensure a high hygienic level. The mantle of the product tank is only filled from program step tank filling to program step production end. During these program steps, the cooling effect keeps the product in the tank cool.

When a **CIP** or **SIP** is performed on the TT/3, the ice water shall not be on in the mantle. If the ice water is on, the rapid heating during these procedures can cause problems with expanding steam and water. To avoid these problems, the ice water is pumped out from the mantle and returned to the customer's external ice water system. By pumping the ice water back to the external ice water system, there is also no waste.

When the ice water is removed from the mantle of the product tank, it is first collected in the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FBDF76). When the water tank is full, the [Pump](#Pumppump-F9FBEA9A) starts up and returns the ice water to the external ice water system. When the level in the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FBDF76) is low, the pump stops again.

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000209582.png)

*   Water tank
*   Pump

### Trouble shooting 110305711/110305712

**Description**

When the ice water is removed from the mantle of the product tank it is first collected in the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FC6923). When the water tank is full the [Pump](#Pumppump-F9FC73B4) starts up and return the ice water to the external ice water system. When the level in the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FC6923) is low the pump stops again.

**Conditions to set the alarm**

If the [Pump](#Pumppump-F9FC73B4) runs continually for more than 60 seconds or if it starts and stops more than 15 times when draining the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FC6923) the yellow alarm 110305711/110305712 occurs.

**Trouble shooting**

*   Make sure that all the valves are functioning correctly and are in the correct position.
    
*   Make sure that the pump is running correctly.
    
*   Make sure that the level probes in the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FC6923) are functioning and are correctly set.
    
*   Make sure that the level relay is correctly set. The conductivity of the ice water media has an effect on the sensitivity of the system.
    
    \- If the [Pump](#Pumppump-F9FC73B4) runs continually for more than 60 seconds the R-value probably needs to be increased according to [Level Control Relay - Set](#section1770) or [Level Control Relay - Set](#section1771).
    
    \- If the [Pump](#Pumppump-F9FC73B4) starts and stops more than 15 times when draining the [Water tank](#WaterTankwaterTank-F9FC6923) the R-value probably needs to be decreased according to [Level Control Relay - Set](#section1770) or [Level Control Relay - Set](#section1771).

Logger SM1000
-------------

### Functional Description

The logger is part of the Installation to Performance (**ITP**) system.

The main function of the **ITP** system is to make sure that the different supply parameters to the machine are within the specified limits. The machine will only work at maximum efficiency if these specifications are met.

**Measured Parameters**

The measured supply systems are:

Supply system:

Measured parameters:

**CIP**

Return flow on side 1

Return flow on side 2

Return pressure on side 1

Return pressure on side 2

Ice water

Inlet flow

Inlet temperature

Product

Pressure on side 1

Pressure on side 2

Steam

Steam pressure

All of these measured parameters are continually recorded on a logger. This log can be used both on the logger itself and on a computer for more detailed analysis.

**Alarms**

If the measured parameters are outside of the specified limits, a blue or yellow alarm will be triggered. These alarms mean that something inside or outside of the machine must be corrected.

The alarm levels have been set so that the machine will function at maximum efficiency. If the specified parameters are not followed, the machine will malfunction and require more downtime.

**ITP Logger**

The **ITP** logger is situated in the filling section electrical cabinet and records all of the measured parameters on its memory card. This memory card has enough room to record continually for 15 months.

The log from the **ITP** logger can be used to diagnose the supply systems and to find the cause of any alarms that may occur. This diagnosis becomes much easier if you move the log files from the memory card to a computer, where you can use an add-in for Microsoft Excel to present the data in several different ways.

Logger RVG200
-------------

### Functional Description

The logger is part of the Installation to Performance (**ITP**) system.

The main function of the **ITP** system is to make sure that the different supply parameters to the machine are within the specified limits. The machine will only work at maximum efficiency if these specifications are met.

**Measured Parameters**

The measured supply systems are:

Supply system:

Measured parameters:

**CIP**

Return flow on side 1

Return flow on side 2

Return pressure on side 1

Return pressure on side 2

Ice water

Inlet flow

Inlet temperature

Product

Pressure on side 1

Pressure on side 2

Steam

Steam pressure

All of these measured parameters are continually recorded on a logger. This log can be used both on the logger itself and on a computer for more detailed analysis.

**Alarms**

If the measured parameters are outside of the specified limits, a blue or yellow alarm will be triggered. These alarms mean that something inside or outside of the machine must be corrected.

The alarm levels have been set so that the machine will function at maximum efficiency. If the specified parameters are not followed, the machine will malfunction and require more downtime.

**ITP Logger**

The **ITP** logger is situated in the filling section electrical cabinet and records all of the measured parameters on its memory card. This memory card has enough room to record continually for 15 months.

The log from the **ITP** logger can be used to diagnose the supply systems and to find the cause of any alarms that may occur. This diagnosis becomes much easier if you move the log files from the memory card to a computer, where you can use an add-in for Microsoft Excel to present the data in several different ways.

### Recorder - Printing Records

1.  Insert the CompactFlash card into a **CF** reader or a USB-drive into the computer that has the Jumo PCA software installed.
    
2.  Start the Jumo PCA 3000 software.
    
3.  If this is the first time that the software is being used for the password; enter 9200 with the user **ID** of Master.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000402877.png)

4.  From the `Archive` menu, select `Read in data`.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000402876.png)

5.  Find the [Folder for the data source](#CompactFlashCardFolderCompactFlashC-3099496E) in order to read in the data.
    
    **Note:** The files in the folder will not be shown.
    
6.  Set the [Target folder](#TargetFolderTargetFolder-30995A16) for the data.
    
    **Note:** When you do the calibration you make note of the time that it was accomplished. This will be where you can get that chart for that period of time.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000402875.png)

*   Folder for the data source
*   Target folder

7.  Once you read in the data to your target folder you will have the message Data have been read in successfully!
    
8.  Click the [Open button](#OpenButtonOpenButton-3099C2BC) and the chart appears.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000402874.png)

*   `Open` button

9.  Open the chart and put your mouse cursor on the end of your temperature line. All of the data that you need to show the calibration will appear. Do a Print Screen with your computer, in order to get the graph and the data that is showing.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000402873.png)

10.  In order to get an analog print out to accompany the graph from the `File` menu, select `Print Preview,` and then click the [Analog button](#AnalogButtonAnalogButton-3099DC62).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000403215.png)

*   `Analog` button

11.  Select `All data sets` and then click the [OK button](#OKButtonOKButton-3099F051).
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000403214.png)

*   `OK` button

12.  You now have the analog data to go along with your chart. You can circle by hand and initial the time of calibration.
    

![Illustration](https://stsp3lqew6l65ci.blob.core.windows.net/illustrations/0000403213.png)

**Note:** Each channel must be done. Everything that is on the chart recorder must be printed in this manner. When all of the information is printed attach the printouts to the Calibration Report and put it in the CVP.

14.  The calibration is now complete.
